Terms of Reference
Expert for curriculum development
Background
The International Trade Centre (ITC) is a joint agency of the United Nations and the World Trade
Organization, focusing in particular on developing the export capabilities of small and medium-sized
businesses in developing and transition economies. ITC is 100% "Aid for Trade", supporting trade that
delivers inclusive and sustainable development results. ITC’s mandate covers all developing countries and
transition economies with special emphasis on the Least Developed Countries (LDCs), Landlocked
Developing Countries (LLDCs), Small Island Developing States (SIDs) Fragile States and Sub-Saharan
Africa. To support a more inclusive distribution of development gains, ITC works with women, youth, and
marginalized groups in developing countries to empower them through entrepreneurship and skills that
provide gateways to jobs and enterprise creation.
The Building Equitable and Inclusive Transformation (BEIT) project in Iraq, implemented by UN-Habitat, the
International Labour Organization (ILO), and the International Trade Centre (ITC), aims to foster decent
work and affordable housing. This multi-faceted initiative encompasses integrating employment-intensive
investment and local resource-based approaches into Iraq's National Public Works Programme, enhancing
capacity for sustainable and affordable housing, promoting trade-led private sector engagement in climate-
smart construction, and empowering social partners for better labour market outcomes. Through these
components, BEIT focuses on gender and sustainable financing, developing sustainable financial tools and
legislative frameworks, forming SME cluster alliances, and fostering social dialogue and capacity building
among social partners, all to address housing challenges, create jobs, and support SMEs while mitigating
climate change impacts in the housing sector.
Output 3.3 of the project is designed to enhance the capabilities of local businesses, particularly focusing
on young entrepreneurs, to incorporate green and innovative practices into their operations. This includes a
comprehensive approach to support micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) through the
development of sustainable and innovative capabilities, especially in sectors like climate-smart solutions
and innovative construction technology. The project plans to:
1. Reinforce Business Development Services: Strengthening the portfolio of service providers to offer
training, coaching, and mentoring in areas critical for sustainable and innovative business practices.
2. Leverage Peer Learning: Facilitating learning from institutional and company-level peers to help
entrepreneurs effectively understand and implement sustainable practices.
3. Enhance TVET Alignment: Aligning Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) programs
with the needs of businesses to ensure practical and industry-relevant training.
4. Cultivate Partnerships: Establishing collaborations with multinational corporations, training institutions,
and other industry stakeholders for knowledge transfer and skill development.
5. Implement Targeted Activities:
- 3.3.1: Designing and implementing modular training for professionals on sustainable construction,
repairs, resource efficiency, and financial literacy.
- 3.3.2: Developing partnerships with construction material suppliers, universities, and innovators to
mainstream climate-smart solutions.
Created: 2024-07-09 01:45

- 3.3.3: Establishing pilot training sites and model houses showcasing affordable green techniques in
collaboration with UN-Habitat.
- 3.3.4: Strengthening the capacities of organizations supporting MSMEs, with a focus on services in
entrepreneurship and financial literacy.
- 3.3.5: Creating a certified trainee system, a resource repository, regular networking events, and
associated marketing efforts in collaboration with local alliances.
This strategic focus on building capacities, fostering partnerships, and aligning educational programs with
market needs aims to empower young entrepreneurs and small businesses to contribute to economic
empowerment and job creation through sustainable and innovative practices.
Description of Duties/Responsibilities
The work will entail desk reviews of existing subjects and curriculum in the areas of new affordable house
construction, repairs, resource efficiency and financial literacy. This will facilitate the formulation of
recommendations from relevant stakeholders, development of new curriculum, development of resource
materials where relevant. Piloting is also expected with sample students and teachers.
Under the direct supervision of the Youth economic empowerment expert and in close coordination with the
ITC HQ based and Iraq based teams, the selected candidate will be responsible for the following tasks:
Identify key stakeholders in the construction, repair, and maintenance industries, including experts in
energy efficiency and financial management, to inform the curriculum development process.
Assess existing Courses and Curriculum1.
Conduct a comprehensive review of existing courses, curriculum, content and other relevant existing
materials in Iraq in the above mentioned fields to facilitate the potential design of new courses and
curriculum;
Offer recommendations regarding course design, learning content, teaching aids, technology use;
Propose instructional methods such as individual or group instruction, self-study, lectures, demonstrations,
simulation exercises and role-playing;
Facilitate key meetings as needed with various stakeholders from the private and public sector,
government, students, and actors from the civil society
Report on areas of strengths and weaknesses of the current curriculum and propose changes;
Introduce exercises, illustrations, tutorials, teacher aids, and other methods of learning to enhance
education;
Propose introductory learning and observations for young students in order to inform of potential career,
skills, and trade opportunities that surround them;
Introduce learning principles and instructional designs to enable learners to rapidly absorb the technical
content.
Design new Courses and Curriculum2.
Design teaching curriculum with course outlines, lesson plans, classroom activities and multiple learning
styles and modalities of instruction;
Created: 2024-07-09 01:45

Implement instructional methods such as individual or group instruction, self-study, lectures,
demonstrations, simulation exercises;
Collaborate with stakeholders and entities in the national/international community (teachers, engineers,
technicians, farmers, services, government, IOs etc.) to develop effective learning content in multiple
delivery styles (includes online classroom, field, virtual instructor-led training and blended learning content).
Develop a course implementation plan and pilot the instruction / teaching to students with new developed
materials;
Partnership Development for Material Validation:3.
Engaging with Implementing Partners: Although not directly involved in implementation, the advisor may
need to work with potential implementing partners (e.g., training institutions, professional associations) to
validate the training design and ensure it meets industry standards and expectations.
Building Relationships with Content Experts: Develop relationships with industry and subject matter experts
to review and endorse the training content, adding credibility and relevance to the training modules.
Identifying Implementing Partner in Ninewa:4.
Conducting Partner Identification and Assessment: Undertake a thorough search and assessment process
to identify a potential implementing partner based in Ninewa, with a strong track record in delivering high-
quality training programs. This includes evaluating prospective partners on their capacity, reach, alignment
with the training program's goals, and their ability to effectively engage and impact the target professional
audience in Ninewa.
Establishing Partnership Framework: Develop a framework for collaboration with the identified
implementing partner, outlining roles, responsibilities, expectations, and mechanisms for communication
and feedback throughout the training program's implementation phase. This framework should ensure that
the partner is fully equipped and aligned to deliver the training modules effectively, incorporating the
developed curricula, materials, and evaluation tools.
Facilitating Knowledge Transfer and Support: Provide ongoing support and knowledge transfer to the
identified implementing partner to ensure they have all the necessary information, materials, and
understanding to successfully implement the training program. This includes facilitating workshops or
sessions on the training design, curriculum, and evaluation framework, as well as offering continuous
advisory support during the initial stages of the training implementation.
Documentation and Reporting:5.
Comprehensive Documentation: Prepare detailed documentation of the training design process, including
the curriculum, stakeholder inputs, material development, and proposed evaluation methods.
Reporting: Compile reports outlining the training design, expected outcomes, and recommendations for
implementation and evaluation. These reports will be crucial for the implementing partners and
stakeholders to understand and carry forward the project.
In this role, the advisor would need to possess strong curriculum design skills, expertise in sustainable
construction practices, financial literacy, and adult education principles. Effective communication and
collaboration skills are also vital for engaging with stakeholders and ensuring the training design is aligned
with industry needs and standards.
Copyright
The Consultant has to ensure that s/he has obtained the necessary permissions with regard to intellectual
property rights required to perform his/her services under this consultancy contract and for the subsequent
dissemination by ITC in any form. Documentary proof is to be submitted to ITC. Should any license fee be
due for the use of copyrighted materials of third parties, the Consultant shall request the prior written
permission from ITC. S/he has further to ensure to obtain accreditation to event(s), if required.
Created: 2024-07-09 01:45

Expected Outputs and Timelines
1. Comprehensive Training Curriculum Package (30/09/2024):
- A complete set of training modules, including detailed curricula, lesson plans, presentations, case
studies, and assessment tools tailored to the construction and housing sector's specific needs. This
package should be competency-based, reflecting the input from focus group discussions and stakeholder
consultations, and designed for flexible learning paces.
2. Stakeholder Engagement recommendations and Material Validation Documentation (25/10/2024):
- A detailed approach documenting the process and outcomes of stakeholder engagement activities,
including focus group discussions and expert consultations. It should highlight key insights that informed
the curriculum development and provide a list of identified key stakeholders. Additionally, documentation of
partnership development efforts and validation of the training materials by implementing partners and
content experts should be included, ensuring the training content's credibility and relevance.
3. Monitoring and Evaluation Framework with Tool (25/10/2024):
- A comprehensive framework and set of tools for monitoring and evaluating the training program's
effectiveness. This should include pre- and post-assessment tools, feedback forms, and specific criteria for
measuring competency acquisition among participants. The framework should outline methodologies for
collecting and analyzing data to inform future training improvements and report on the training program's
impact on professionals in the construction and housing sector.
4. Partner Identification Report (25/11/2024):
- A comprehensive report detailing the search and assessment process for potential implementing
partners in Ninewa. This report will include criteria used for evaluation, such as organizational capacity,
experience in similar projects, alignment with program goals, and ability to reach and engage the target
audience.
- A shortlist of potential partners, including an analysis of their strengths and weaknesses, and
recommendations for the most suitable partner(s) based on the program's specific needs and objectives.
The timelines set out above are indicative and will be reviewed with the consultant after the first week of
work.

Travel within the Republic of Iraq and KRI.

Skills
Required:
- Strong skills in developing competency-based curricula tailored to adult learners, with the ability to design
modular and flexible training content.
- Ability to adapt materials and training approaches to different cultural contexts, particularly in regions like
Ninewa, with sensitivity to local needs and practices.
Desirable:
- Proficient in conducting research, stakeholder analysis, and needs assessments to inform curriculum
development and training program design.
- Excellent communication, facilitation, and presentation skills, capable of engaging effectively with diverse
groups of stakeholders and partners.
- Strong project management skills, including planning, execution, monitoring, and reporting, with the ability
to manage multiple tasks and deadlines efficiently.
Education
Undergraduate degree (BA/BSC or other)
- A degree in Education, Curriculum Development, Construction Management, Engineering, Sustainability,
Adult Education, or a related field. - Certifications or specialized training in curriculum design, adult learning
principles, sustainable construction practices, or financial literacy would be highly desirable.
Extensive relevant experience may be accepted in lieu of the university degree.
Experience
- At least 5-7 years of experience in curriculum development, training program design, and implementation,
preferably within the construction, housing, or related sectors. Experience in sustainable construction
practices, resource efficiency, and financial management in the context of construction would be highly
beneficial.
- Demonstrated experience in conducting focus group discussions, stakeholder mapping, and engagement,
particularly with industry professionals, educators, and subject matter experts. Experience working in or
with organizations based in Ninewa or a similar context would be an advantage.
- Experience in identifying, assessing, and establishing partnerships with implementing partners such as
training institutions and professional associations. A track record of successful collaboration with partners
for program validation and implementation.
- Proven experience in designing and implementing monitoring and evaluation frameworks for training
programs, including the development of evaluation tools and methodologies.

Fluency in English and intermediate in Arabic is essential

To help you gather data for the training partners selection report, I'll ask you three key questions that will guide our approach:

1. What specific criteria have you established or been provided with for evaluating potential training partners in Ninewa? This could include factors like organizational capacity, experience in similar projects, or ability to reach the target audience.

2. Have you already identified any potential partners or organizations in Ninewa that work in the fields of construction, housing, or vocational training? If so, what do you know about them?

3. What resources or contacts do you have access to for researching and identifying potential partners in Ninewa? For example, do you have connections with local government offices, industry associations, or other UN agencies operating in the area?

These questions will help me provide more tailored advice on how to gather data for your training partners selection report. Once you provide this information, I can offer more specific strategies for data collection and partner identification.

Certainly! I'll help you prepare for your interview with Rwanga tomorrow and create a step-by-step preparation list. This will help you gather the necessary data for your training partners selection report, focusing on Rwanga as a potential partner.

<antThinking>A preparation list for an important interview like this is a good candidate for an artifact. It's substantial, self-contained, and likely to be referenced multiple times. The user can easily modify it for future interviews with other potential partners.</antThinking>

<antArtifact identifier="interview-preparation-checklist" type="text/markdown" title="Preparation Checklist for Rwanga Interview">
# Preparation Checklist for Rwanga Interview

## 1. Research Rwanga
- [ ] Review Rwanga's website and social media presence
- [ ] Look for any recent news or press releases about Rwanga
- [ ] Identify their main areas of focus and past projects
- [ ] Note any experience in construction, housing, or vocational training

## 2. Prepare Interview Questions
- [ ] Organizational capacity questions
- [ ] Experience with similar projects
- [ ] Ability to reach and engage target audience
- [ ] Resources and infrastructure
- [ ] Expertise in relevant fields
- [ ] Willingness to collaborate and adapt

## 3. Gather Necessary Documents
- [ ] Your organizational capacity assessment tool
- [ ] Project brief or summary
- [ ] List of specific training needs and objectives
- [ ] Any relevant legal or compliance requirements

## 4. Logistical Preparations
- [ ] Confirm interview time and location
- [ ] Prepare any presentation materials or handouts
- [ ] Check and prepare any technology needed (laptop, projector, etc.)
- [ ] Plan your travel to the interview location

## 5. Personal Preparation
- [ ] Review your project goals and requirements
- [ ] Prepare a brief introduction about yourself and the project
- [ ] Anticipate potential questions Rwanga might ask you
- [ ] Prepare your own questions about Rwanga's capabilities and interest

## 6. Post-Interview Plan
- [ ] Prepare a template for recording interview notes
- [ ] Plan how you'll evaluate the information gathered
- [ ] Schedule time for post-interview reflection and analysis
</antArtifact>

Now, let me guide you through this preparation process step-by-step:

1. Research Rwanga:
Start by thoroughly researching Rwanga. Look at their website, social media, and any recent news. Pay special attention to their experience in areas relevant to your project, such as construction, housing, or vocational training. This will help you tailor your questions and understand their potential fit as a partner.

2. Prepare Interview Questions:
Based on your research and the criteria from your organizational capacity assessment, prepare a list of questions. These should cover areas like their organizational capacity, experience with similar projects, ability to reach your target audience, and their expertise in relevant fields. Also, consider asking about their willingness to collaborate and adapt to the project's needs.

3. Gather Necessary Documents:
Ensure you have all the documents you'll need for the interview. This includes your organizational capacity assessment tool, a project brief, and any other relevant materials. Having these on hand will help you provide clear information about your project and requirements.

4. Logistical Preparations:
Confirm the interview details and prepare any materials you'll need to bring. If you're planning to give a presentation or share documents, make sure everything is ready and in working order.

5. Personal Preparation:
Review your project goals and requirements. Prepare a concise introduction about yourself and the project. Also, try to anticipate questions Rwanga might ask you about the project or partnership opportunity.

6. Post-Interview Plan:
Prepare a template for recording your observations and the information gathered during the interview. This will help you consistently evaluate all potential partners and make an informed decision later.

Remember, the goal of this interview is not just to assess Rwanga but also to build a relationship. Be open to learning about their capabilities and how they might contribute uniquely to your project.

Is there any specific area in this preparation process you'd like more detailed guidance on?

3. BACKGROUND & JUSTIFICATION
3.1 OVERVIEW
The fourth largest oil producer in the world, Iraq is classified as an upper middle-income country, and is notably
culturally and geographically diverse. Despite its natural resource wealth, economic growth has fluctuated over the
years because of multiple complex factors, including political unrest, high population growth and urbanization rates,
and oil price volatility. Human and economic development has stagnated as a result of five gruelling decades of
successive armed conflict in particular. Following the more recent periods of strife including the defeat of Islamic
State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) and the more recent months-long popular protests, the country is yet again undergoing
the arduous process of reconstruction and recovery amidst ongoing political and social uncertainty. In 2022, Iraq
ranked 121 of 191 countries in the Human Development Index (UNDP, 2022) and 115 of 163 in the Sustainable
Development Goal (SDG) Index Dashboard (Sachs et al, 2022).
Employment is a particular challenge. Insufficient stable and decent work opportunities are being created for Iraq’s
young population. The labour market is characterized by high rates of unemployment at 16.5 percent (or 1.7 million
people) with significant differences by age and gender: while 14.7 percent of men are unemployed, this rate reaches
28.2 percent among women, and as high as 35.8 percent among youth aged 15 to 24 (GoI, 2022). There are also
significant variations by region with lowest unemployment rates seen in Babylon, at 5.5 percent, and highest rates
in Nineveh, at 32.8 percent – over six times higher (GoI, 2022). In addition, underemployment is a significant
challenge to the country. In turn, a high proportion of workers are in the public sector, while informal employment
dominates in the private sector. These situations exacerbate the country’s stagnant growth, inequalities, and social
and political challenges.
Investment in the housing sector can create much-needed jobs while helping to address the country’s serious
housing shortage. The young and growing population, urban-rural migration, the destruction of housing in armed
conflict, migration and internal displacement have compounded pre-existing barriers to housing construction.
Constraints on the capacities and efficiency of both the public and private sector have left it unable to meet the need
for quality, affordable and sustainable housing. As a result, many live in precarious or substandard housing
conditions, informal settlements, or overly expensive housing.
Through policy dialogue, technical assistance, capacity building and support in addressing key regulatory and
institutional barriers to affordable housing and construction, the Project for “Building Equitable and Inclusive
Transformation (BEIT)”. The project will combine the expertise of the United Nations Human Settlements
Programme (UN-Habitat), International Labour Organization (ILO) and International Trade Centre (ITC) in a multi-
sectoral approach that results in greener, more affordable housing through the introduction of national public work
programme using Employment Intensive Investment (EIIP) approach while creating quality jobs and opportunities
for economic growth. The joint programme outlined in this document has been designed through multiple
government consultations who have voiced their support and commitment (See Annex 5). The following proposal is
also in close alignment with national development priorities, particularly the economic, social and sustainability
targets in Iraq’s Vision for Sustainable Development 2030; the European Union’s Action Document for Support to
Durable Solutions for Iraq’s Displaced Populations (2022); and the United Nations Sustainable Development
Cooperation Framework (UNSDCF) (2019) and other relevant UN frameworks.
3.2 PROBLEM ANALYSIS
The housing sector is central to many of Iraq’s most pressing development challenges. There is a need to generate
additional employment opportunities and, with support for inclusive hiring and efforts to improve job quality, a
strengthened housing sector could create these jobs. Demographic trends, conflict, and displaced populations are
all increasing housing demand in Iraqi cities, though there are not enough suitable and sustainable homes being
built. Constraints in the housing sector value chain are hindering the private sector – including small businesses –
from responding to this excess demand. Through collaboration with civil society organizations (CSOs), public and
private sector stakeholders, the joint programme will work to address these issues.

3.2.1 UNREALIZED EMPLOYMENT POTENTIAL IN THE HOUSING SECTOR
The development of the housing sector has the potential to make a major contribution to the urgent need to create
new and Decent jobs in Iraq. While the rapid expansion of Iraq’s working-age population creates a rare demographic
window of opportunity for economic growth and opportunity, this potential is mostly being squandered. Instead,
Iraq’s inability to create sufficient jobs to absorb the rapidly growing labour force has contributed to waves of social
unrest. Indeed, in Iraq, only 39.5 percent of the working age population aged over 15 are in the labour force (well
below the global average labour force participation rate of 59.3 percent (GoI, 2022)). This is driven in particular by
low participation rates among youth aged 15 to 24 (10.4 percent) and women (10.5 percent) (GoI, 2022).
In addition, much of the economically active population is unemployed or underemployed. The overall
unemployment rate stands at 16.5 percent (or 1.7 million people), with women (28.2 percent) and youth (35.8
percent) disproportionately represented among the unemployed (GoI, 2022). The LFS indicates that 30.8 percent of
the unemployed were long-term unemployed, having been looking for employment for one year or more. This
indicates that unemployment in Iraq is more structural and long-term than it is frictional (short period of
unemployment between two jobs), though this situation has been exacerbated by temporary or short-term
unemployment caused by large shocks such as the COVID-19 pandemic. Among the employed, many are
underemployed; 7.9 percent of employed persons were working less than 40 hours a week, but wanted and were
available to work more hours (GoI, 2022).
The inability of the Iraqi economy to create sufficient quality jobs stems from related constraints in the private sector
and the large differences between public and private sector jobs. Years of conflict, a poor business environment, a
weak financial system, limited support services, and a lack of diversification and competition in the economy have
constrained job creation in the private sector. Thus, the share of employment in the private sector remains relatively
low at only 61.6 percent of those employed. Enlarged public sector employment results in an elevated wage bill
compared with peer countries (IMF, 2021). The large disparity in working conditions between the public and private
sectors can lead many individuals to wait (by remaining inactive or unemployed) until employment in the public
sector becomes available.
A consequence of these challenges is the large share of informal employment, which accounts for 66.6 percent of
all employment in Iraq. These jobs are characterized by many decent work deficits, including low wages and poor
working conditions, as respect for (and enforcement of) worker rights as articulated in the labour law is lower among
informal enterprises compared to formal ones. Furthermore, as highlighted during the pandemic, there are
significant gaps in the coverage and scope of social protection. Only about 5 percent of workers in the private sector
enrolled in social security, which protects covered workers against a limited range of social risks (excluding, for
example, income protection in case of unemployment and maternity). As a result, most private-sector workers are
unprotected, and even those that are covered are vulnerable to falling into poverty in case of uncovered events.
Child labour is also relatively common, due to families’ lack of other economic opportunities, income loss from
violence and displacement, and supply-side challenges in education. The Multi-Indicator Cluster Survey carried out
by UNICEF in 2018 found that 7.3% of children aged 5 to 17 were engaged in child labour. Boys and rural children
are particularly affected, with many children (5.9%) involved in hazardous child labour (UNICEF, 2019).
While job creation should be led by inclusive growth in the private sector, the multiple challenges thereto outlined
above indicate that this will continue to be a challenge in the short and medium term. In such instances,
Governments can and do act as “employers of last resort”, intervening to directly create jobs where the markets fail
in this regard. Such interventions can take multiple forms, from statutory employment guarantee schemes (as in the
case in India) to public employment programmes implemented to respond to short or longer-term unemployment
challenges (as in the cases of Greece and South Africa respectively). Such a scheme does not currently exist in Iraq,
but the Government has expressed its interest and commitment to establishing a programme aimed at supporting
in the direct creation of employment opportunities to address the significant unemployment challenge in the
country.
3.2.2 EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES AND CHALLENGES IN THE HOUSING SECTOR

8
In addition to addressing the population’s housing needs, the growth of the housing sector has the potential to
create more quality jobs. The sector already makes important economic contributions. Construction employs some
16.3 percent of employed persons in Iraq (or 1.4 million individuals), representing the largest sector of employment
in the country, followed closely by public administration (GOI, 2022). It contributes one of the largest shares to GDP
outside of the oil sector. Industries linked to construction materials production is considered to be one of only two
manufacturing sub-sectors in the country with a “meaningful level of private activity”. In turn, the need for
construction workers in the vast and enduring reconstruction and rehabilitation efforts in the country makes this a
sector with continued prospects for job creation in the short to medium term (DRC, 2020).
Improvements in the quality and inclusiveness of employment in the sector are also needed. Many jobs are of low
quality and insecure; 98.5 percent of workers in the construction sector are in informal employment, the highest
rate of any sector for which such data is available. In turn, 94.9 percent of workers in the construction sector are
employed in informal institutions, which indicates that many workers employed in formal-sector companies are
nevertheless in informally employment. Wages are also low; 72.4 percent of employees in the construction sector
are on low pay (below two-thirds of the median hourly earnings of employees at their main job), the third highest
rate of any sector.
A recent study on the working conditions in the construction sector in governorates liberated from ISIS (Anbar,
Diyala, Kirkuk, Ninawa and Salah Al-Deen) highlighted the many vulnerabilities faced by workers in the construction
sector (ICRD, 2020). These including low social security coverage and awareness among workers of their rights under
social security legislation; an almost complete absence of unionization and of collective agreements between
workers and employers in the sector; excessive overtime; low compliance with occupational health and safety
standards, with just under half of workers not provided with necessary personal protection equipment; and a
widespread violations of the labour law, including in relation to paid annual and sick leave and rest days (ICRD, 2020).
Here are some of the key decent work deficits in the construction sector in Iraq:
• Occupational Health and Safety: The construction industry is known for its hazardous working conditions,
with workers facing risks such as falling from heights, exposure to hazardous materials, and accidents
involving heavy machinery. The lack of proper safety regulations and enforcement can lead to work-related
injuries and fatalities.
• Low Wages and Informal Employment: Wages in the construction sector may be low, especially for casual
or informal workers. Many workers might lack formal contracts and benefits, leading to job insecurity and
a lack of access to social protection, such as healthcare and pensions.
• Long Working Hours: Construction projects often involve demanding schedules, leading to long working
hours for the labour force. Extended work hours without adequate breaks can result in physical and mental
strain on workers.
• Child Labour and Forced Labour: The construction industry in Iraq, like many other developing countries,
can be prone to the exploitation of child labour and forced labour practices. Children may be employed in
hazardous conditions, and some workers may be forced into the sector due to economic circumstances or
trafficking.
• Limited Unionization: The lack of strong labour unions or labour representation can hinder workers' ability
to negotiate for better wages, working conditions, and benefits. This lack of collective bargaining power can
leave workers vulnerable to exploitation by employers.
• Discrimination and Inequality: Women in the construction industry face discrimination and unequal
treatment in terms of wages and job opportunities. They are often underrepresented in skilled and higher-
paying roles.

9
Addressing these decent work deficits requires comprehensive efforts from various stakeholders, including the
government, employers, trade unions, and civil society organizations. Implementing and enforcing labour laws that
ensure fair wages, safe working conditions, and job security are crucial to improving the situation. Moreover,
promoting social dialogue and the inclusion of marginalized groups, such as women and migrants, can help create a
more equitable and just construction sector in Iraq.
More opportunities can be created for women and any programme that focuses on affordable housing to promote
employment generation will have to incorporate deliberate corrective measures to ensure the participation of – and
employment outcomes for – women. Some 99.5 percent of workers in the construction sector in Iraq are men. Biases
appear to contribute to this imbalance. Factors such as demographic characteristics and social behaviours (e.g. age,
gender, interview behaviour) are typically ranked higher than qualifications and practical experience by employers
when identifying factors affecting their hiring decisions (UNESCO, 2019)).
The trade union movement in the construction sector in Iraq has faced several challenges over the years. These
challenges stem from a combination of historical, political, economic, and social factors. Observations from the
discussion and workshops with the trade unions in Iraq, the main problems that trade unions encounter in the
construction sector in Iraq:
• Limited Legal Framework: Iraq's labour laws have not always provided robust protection for trade union
rights. In the past, restrictive legislation may have hampered union activities and made it difficult for unions
to organize and collectively bargain on behalf of workers.
• Fragmentation and Divisions: Iraq's trade union movement has experienced internal divisions and
fragmentation. Differing ideologies, political affiliations, and regional interests among various unions have
sometimes led to conflicts and weakened the overall effectiveness of the labour movement.
• Lack of Collective Bargaining Power: Due to low union density and limited legal protections, trade unions in
the construction sector may have struggled to exert significant collective bargaining power. As a result,
workers may face challenges in negotiating for better wages, improved working conditions, and other
benefits.
• Informal Economy: A significant portion of the construction workforce in Iraq operates in the informal
economy, where workers lack formal employment contracts and union representation. This makes it
difficult for unions to organize and protect the rights of workers in this sector effectively.
• Economic Challenges: The construction sector's economic fluctuations and uncertainties can affect job
security for workers, making it harder for trade unions to ensure stable employment conditions and fair
treatment.
Similarly, the workshops and discussions facilitated by the ILO have presented employers' organizations with
challenges that can hinder their ability to effectively represent the interests of employers and contribute to the
growth and development of the industry. Here are some of the key problems faced by employers' organizations:
• Lack of Representation: In some cases, employers' organizations may struggle to represent a significant
portion of employers in the construction sector. Low membership rates and limited participation can
weaken their ability to advocate for the interests of the broader industry.
• Fragmentation: Similar to trade unions, employers' organizations can suffer from fragmentation, where
different groups or associations representing employers in the construction sector may have diverse
interests and priorities. This can make it challenging to present a unified voice and develop coherent
policies.
• Informal Economy: The construction sector in Iraq, like in many other developing countries, has a
substantial informal economy. Many construction businesses operate informally, without formal

10
registration or adherence to regulations. This makes it difficult for employers' organizations to reach and
represent these entities effectively.
• Limited Resources: Employers' organizations may face financial constraints and limited resources, affecting
their capacity to carry out activities such as research, training, and advocacy on behalf of their members.
• Limited Social Dialogue: Constructive social dialogue involving employers, trade unions, and the
government is crucial for resolving labour-related issues and fostering a conducive business environment.
However, in Iraq, social dialogue might be limited, hindering the employers' organizations' ability to engage
in constructive discussions.
• Capacity Building: Some employers' organizations might face challenges in building the necessary capacity
and skills to effectively represent their members and address complex labour and business issues.
Addressing these challenges necessitates collaborative endeavours from a range of stakeholders, encompassing
workers' and employers' organizations, government bodies, and pertinent institutions. Enhancing labour legislation
to safeguard trade union rights, fostering social dialogue, delivering training and capacity-building assistance, and
nurturing a culture of collective bargaining all contribute to fortifying trade unions and augmenting the
representation of construction workers' concerns. In the context of enhancing employers' organizations, strategies
may encompass providing training and capacity-building support, facilitating networking opportunities among
employers, promoting collaboration among diverse associations, and advocating for policies that advance a
formalized and regulated construction sector.
In addition, extended efforts need to be made to support local partners in designing, formulating, implementing and
evaluating policies and programmes aiming to address unemployment and underemployment through public
investment, typically in infrastructure development. Employment Intensive Approaches reinforce and build
institutional and operational capacity to provide productive and decent work that has an economic, environmental,
and social impact. Whilst labour-based construction activities result in short-term employment, the improved
infrastructure they produce contributes to increasing economic performance in other sectors, generating multiplier
effects on employment and income throughout the economy.
3.2.3 NEED FOR GREEN JOBS IN THE HOUSING SECTOR
Green jobs generally referred to decent jobs, which contribute to preserving or restoring the environment. These
jobs can be in traditional sectors such as manufacturing and construction, or in new, emerging green sectors such as
renewable energy and energy efficiency. The housing sector has the potential to create green jobs and to help
diversify the Iraqi economy. There is a strong connection between the climate crisis and the jobs crisis in Iraq, and
there are various channels through which the impacts of climate change will further worsen the quality and quantity
of jobs in Iraq. As countries across the globe eventually move away from their reliance on fossil fuels, government
revenue from oil will weaken, which may result in downward pressures on public employment, reliant as this is on
oil revenue. The potential of agricultural and other sectors may also decline as the impacts of climate change are
increasingly felt.
Against this background, it is essential for the Government of Iraq to support the creation of jobs that are not only
resilient to the impacts of climate change, but also that contribute to adapting the Iraqi economy and society to
those same impacts. But to foster the creation of green jobs, it is also first imperative to support the engagement
and expansion of private-sector businesses in the green economy, and for these to adopt green business practices.
The green skills in the Iraqi labour force must also be strengthened to meet the opportunities presented by green
job creation. In the housing sector, this includes training workers involved in architecture, engineering, and
construction in the use of energy efficient methods, designs and approaches.
The Employment Intensive Investment Programme provides an opportunity for change and innovation. It helps to
reduce future impact of climate change on people, economies and the environment by promoting local-resource

11
based methods for constructing and maintaining assets, while providing employment opportunities and enhancing
the productive capacity of ecosystems. Climate smart investments in housing sector have the potential to create
jobs and sustain livelihoods for many of those who will be the most affected in the informal sector, especially women
and youth. In addition, public works using Employment Intensive Approaches have been key to the extension of
social protection where informal economic activity is the greatest, thus supporting local economic, social and
environmental development in both rural and urban areas.
3.2.4 SHORTAGE OF ADEQUATE AND AFFORDABLE HOUSING
Housing is a key determinant of progress on sustainable development, peace and social stability. Access to housing
is not only a fundamental right and basic human need, but also essential for promoting equality and maintaining
social cohesion, and crucial to averting discontent, especially in politically fragile countries such as Iraq. The social
impact of housing is high, ensuring equal access to adequate and affordable housing can vastly improve quality of
life and living standards and is fundamental for a country’s economic welfare and in assuring a productive and stable
workforce. For a family, housing is at the core of social, economic, and emotional lives and a safe and stable home
is fundamental to physical and mental health and can help to create ladders to other opportunities. Children greatly
benefit from stable housing conditions which facilitates access to uninterrupted education, reduces exposure to
unhealthy surroundings, and provides a sense of safety and security. When a family is burdened with the lack of a
roof over their heads it is hard to imagine getting a foot on other opportunities.
Iraq faces an enormous housing deficit that is only expected to worsen in the future. The ISIS conflict aggravated an
already chronic housing shortage that in 2010 was thought to be around 1.4 million housing units, but now more
recent estimates in 2022 from the Ministry of Construction Housing Municipalities and Public Works projects a 3.5-
million-unit housing shortage (Kardiu, 2022 and Ibrahim, 2022). It is estimated that Iraq’s population will increase to
over 50 million people by 2030 from an estimated 40.2 million in 2021. According to the World Bank, in 1960, 43
percent of the population lived in urban areas, and that proportion increased precipitously to 71 percent by 2021.
Urbanization rates are estimated to continue to climb at an annual increase of 2.91 percent between 2020 and 2025
(CIA, 2020) which will continue to put increasing pressure on cities to supply ample housing, sufficient infrastructure,
and basic services to inflowing populations.
Rapid urbanization can be attributed to many intertwined factors including past policies, inadequate access to
services in rural areas, a lack of employment opportunities, the poor performance of the agricultural sector, and the
hard felt impacts of climate change (Hassan et al, 2023). In Iraq, these circumstances are driving people to migrate
to urban areas seeking improved economic opportunities and a better quality of life. Water scarcity and
unproductive agricultural land in Iraq has also contributed to rapid urbanization. Environmental degradation
including the salinization of water and soils, desertification, and the disappearance of arable land due to poor
resource management and climate change will likely continue to reinforce migration to Iraqi cities. Increasingly,
farmers are being forced to migrate to cities in search of civil and military jobs due to the consequences of climate
change (Hassan 2023 and IOM Iraq, 2022).
Furthermore, the existing housing stock is deteriorating, particularly in central urban areas due to age and neglect
(MOCH and UN-Habitat, 2010). The slow production of new housing coupled with the dilapidation and destruction
of existing housing has had the dual consequence of constricted supply and upward market pressures which have
fuelled soaring housing and land prices, and high rents, particularly in the central urban areas that are well-served
by infrastructure. Meanwhile, Iraq’s wealthy are also snatching up high-end real estate throughout Iraqi cities as
investment vehicles and as a means to safeguard money amidst the currency devaluation, essentially creating a dual
housing market (Shafaq News, 2023).
3.2.5 EFFECTS OF CONFLICT ON HOUSING
The lack of affordable and adequate housing in Iraq has been further compounded by the millions of people
internally displaced during the ISIS conflict which forced families into informal housing arrangements, overcrowded
and substandard living conditions. At the peak of the ISIS crisis, there were 6 million displaced within the country,
mostly in urban and peri-urban areas (IOM, 2021). According to a 2021 survey conducted by the Ministry of

12
Displacement and Migration (MODM), 241,659 people remain displaced in Iraq. They cannot return to their area of
origin, do not have the financial resources to rebuild their destroyed homes, and thus are unable to re-establish their
lives. Among those that have started to return, many experienced challenges, particularly tenants, or those whose
property is either occupied or damaged.
In 2018, the World Bank completed a multi-sectoral assessment on the destructive impact of conflict in seven Iraqi
governorates which found that housing had been the most affected sector, with total damages amounting to around
USD 16.1 billion. Over 138,000 residential buildings were thought to have been impacted, of which half were
destroyed beyond repair. The most severe impact was felt in the Ninewa governorate, followed by Salah al-Din,
Anbar, Kirkuk, and Diyala. Estimates indicate that to address the legacy housing shortage and reconstruction efforts,
approximately IQD 25 trillion (USD $17.4 billion) is needed (UN Iraq, 2022).
The widespread destruction of homes has especially impacted low-income populations, worsening their already
fragile situation. Those displaced by conflict are not only more likely to be in poverty and unemployed but in many
cases, they are forced to pay rent for housing elsewhere even though they already own a home. A report by IOM
(2019), concluded that 81 percent of those displaced during the ISIS conflict already owned their homes, many of
which were then forced to also pay rent elsewhere at the expense of other basic needs. This has created severe
economic burdens for those already living in highly volatile situations, and the need for an additional house has
further constrained the already limited housing supply. Furthermore, according to UNHCR (2019) 250,000,
predominantly, Syrian, refugees reside in Iraq which puts additional pressure on the limited housing stock and puts
more families in highly precarious living situations. At the same time, new waves displacement caused by climate
and/ or territorial disputes continue to further compound the housing deficit.
Addressing housing challenges through facilitating the creation of safe and decent housing can contribute to the
country’s social stability. This means assuring that Iraq’s most vulnerable populations can access adequate and
affordable housing and have access to basic services which will require greatly bolstering housing production for
lower-income segments and making sure that there is security of tenure. This will also require targeting locations
for social housing production to areas where future social unrest could be averted as a result of more stable living
conditions. In doing so, actions also need to be taken to assure that housing is placed in the hands of the intended
beneficiaries through stringent programmatic guidelines and enforcement that make sure resources are not
misappropriated or squandered. UN-Habitat and the GOI will work in partnership to test new models in targeted
areas where social housing could support neighbourhood stabilization.
3.2.6 INEQUALITIES IN ACCESS TO HOUSING
The housing shortage has disproportionately impacted low-income and vulnerable families who get pushed further
and further out of the market as land supplies are constrained and prices escalate, and government programs fail to
adequately respond. One consequence of this is that informal settlements have grown rapidly throughout the
country, increasing by 138 percent between 2012 and 2016 reaching 3,687 settlements, which is a 138% increase
compared to 2013, as the number of dwellings reached 521,947. The population of slum dwellers is about 3,292,606,
(accounting for 12.9%) of the total population in Iraq. For example, in Baghdad, 1,022 informal settlements were
identified, Basra has 667 areas. The lowest governorates were Najaf and Karbala (88 and 89 respectively). The
number of dwellings is estimated around 525, 000 units which represent around 16.5 % of the total housing sector
in Iraq. In Baghdad, the informal settlement sector represents around 26% of the total housing. The total inhabitants
in the informal sector are estimated to be around 3.3 million inhabitants (12.9 %) (IDBG and UN-Habitat, 2020). More
recent statements from the MOP, reported that in 2022, Iraq has over 5,000 slum areas, containing more than half
a million housing units and 3.5 million people, or approximately 10 percent of the population (Zeed 2021, Zidane,
2022).
Over the last three decades, the World Bank (2017) contends that 90 percent of all housing was self-constructed,
likely in an informal manner. Most informal settlements are built on state-owned land, in both urban and suburban
areas. Increasingly, they are also constructed on agricultural land where farmers are razing orchards due to drought
and selling off plots for residential development. Many settlements have also sprouted up on land already assigned

13
to be high-rise housing complexes, public facilities, road reserves, or infrastructure projects such as railway tracks or
airports, presenting enormous challenges to future planned development.
The housing predicament has also led to other ad hoc responses, including households sub-dividing existing plots in
an unregulated manner to make room for other family members or rental tenants. A survey conducted in 2011
revealed that 12.8 percent of urban households are occupied by two or more families, while 21.7 percent are over-
crowded with 3 or more persons per room (COS, 2011).

Producing more low-cost housing that is delivered through discrete housing programs, as will be tested in this
project, can support in assuring that new housing is well-designed, constructed with durable materials and serviced
with infrastructure that abides by building codes and planning regulations. Social housing construction projects can
also produce housing that is more compact and thus better utilizes the limited land supply and is less taxing on
infrastructure. In this respect, directly building social housing not only provides security of tenure and improved
housing conditions, but it can also help stymie the creation of new informal housing settlements through ensuring
affordable housing production is happening in targeted locations and that sustainable development principles apply.
Women in Iraq have less secure access to housing. Landowners are disproportionately male; 73.8 percent of land is
owned by men (FAO, 2017). Even though equal property rights are enshrined in law, women continue to face
challenges exercising their land rights. The situation is especially intensified among females who were displaced
during recent conflicts. A study by the Norwegian Refugee Council (2020) on women’s Housing Land & Property
(HLP) rights in post-conflict Iraq found that women were 9 percent more likely to fear eviction than men, especially
for returnees who were 14 percent more likely than men to fear eviction in the coming six months. Furthermore, 9
percent of displaced women report their housing being occupied by community or tribal leaders, militias, and
security forces. The NRC research outlines four key interlinked challenges women face in protecting and claiming
land: the interplay between formal and customary norms regarding women’s right to own and claim property;
perception and community knowledge of women’s rights to own and claim property; lack of documentation of
women’s property rights; and the treatment of women who are perceived to be affiliated with ISIS. Land and
property rights for women remain an ongoing challenge in Iraq, particularly for female heads of household with
children following the death or disappearance of a spouse. With only a perceived secondary right to HLP, women
usually lose out and have few alternatives in a post-conflict environment. In this respect, greater attention is needed
to ensure that access to housing, land and property rights are equally available to women.
The right to adequate housing is integral to advancing equity and inclusion of women and in realizing basic human
rights. Making sure that women are fully represented in planning and policy development decisions can help to
assure equity and inclusion of women so that all perspectives are heard and ultimately emmeshed in housing
programme design. Affordable housing programs that adopt participatory approaches to decision-making processes
can directly address the housing needs of women and girls and can support women in realizing equal access to
housing and in ensuring security of tenure. Government can have direct control over designing housing programs,
particularly when they are government sponsored, in manner that ensures that women are free from discrimination
and inequality. Housing eligibility for benefits can also be designed in a manner that is preferential to those who
have been historically discriminated against or other vulnerable groups.
3.2.7 GOVERNMENT EFFORTS TO ADDRESS HOUSING
Housing has been enshrined as a top priority in multiple national plans, including Iraq’s Vision for Sustainable
Development 2030 (MoP, 2019), the National Housing Policy (MoCH and UN-Habitat, 2009 and 2017), National
Development Plan (MoP, 2018), the Strategy for the Reduction of Poverty (MoP et al., 2018), and the National Plan
for Reconstruction and Development Framework (GOI, 2018). Within these agendas the need to address the
inadequate supply of housing has been fully recognized, and yet, viable long-term strategies have yet to materialize.
In past decades, the GOI has tested various housing programmes such as donating millions of plots of land to those
who do not already own homes (MoCH and UN-Habitat, 2009), initiating the National and Provincial Investment

self-built or constructed by a small contractor. This type of housing is often suited for incremental expansion to
accommodate additional family members or rental units, as economic circumstances permit. Often, households
subdivide and densify one plot of land, which can result in stresses to the existing infrastructure and ad hoc
development and unplanned densification.
More recently, the GOI has pursued developing large housing estates in entirely new neighbourhoods by attracting
foreign and domestic investment through public private partnerships via the National Investment Commission to
address the housing shortage. The estates offer a mix of housing typologies including high rise buildings as well as
single family estates, but often cater to upper-income households despite significant developer incentives and
affordability project guidelines and requirements. Furthermore, the investment projects have faced significant
hurdles and frequent construction delays due to the events of the past decade and the continued precarious security
situation. The recent economic crisis also caused the diversion of funds from the national budget to anti-terrorism
activities which resulted in stalled payments to contractors and put a pause on investment projects (Fadhil and
Burhan, 2021), leaving Iraq’s ability to attract future investors even as circumstances improve, challenging.
While the GOI has made formidable efforts to bolster housing production through a market-driven enabling
approach, adequate housing remains largely out of reach for lower-income households (Shafaq News, 2023).
Concerted efforts are needed to significantly increase the supply of affordable housing which often entails
government investment, to some degree, including subsidies, soft or forgivable loans, or the formulation of policies
such as inclusionary housing which offers developer incentives and/or requires mandatory set-asides. Therefore,
new financial tools are needed that cater to the housing needs for those who are currently shut out of the market.
In this respect, the proposed project aims to support the government in developing new finance mechanisms that
maximize government resources and at the same time, targets households that need financial support to obtain
decent housing.
3.2.8 CAPACITY GAPS
Housing sector governance in Iraq has long been undermined by a lack of technical capacity, fractured governance
systems, and weak or absent enforcement and control mechanisms. This results in insecurity of tenure, informal and
unplanned development, and a dearth of buildable land. Despite efforts to decentralize governance (under Law 21
of 2006) and increases in the number of public employees over the past two decades, progress has been slow. The
National Development Plan (2018) identified the primary institutional challenges that the country is facing as low
efficiency and institutional performance, overstaffing and low productivity, and financial and administrative
corruption.

Managerial staff lacks basic expertise on housing, land management and urban planning, including administrative
capacities and the aptitude to ensure projects get properly executed. The lack of expertise and capacity at the local
level, especially in the face of ever-changing uncertainties, has impaired planning authorities in cities, especially in
their ability to appropriately plan and budget over the long term. Moreover, overlapping jurisdictional authorities
and responsibilities between the federal, provincial, and local levels has caused significant conflict among
departments, which has stymied local housing development projects and hampered plan implementation.
The proposed project will support the GOI in addressing Iraq’s housing challenges which will require strategic efforts
to build the technical capacity of government employees in addressing the housing deficit particularly for low-
income and vulnerable groups. Building the institutional capacity at all levels of government to develop sound
evidence base policies, produce enabling legislation and regulatory frameworks, create new financial tools and
target funds to support those most in need will not only promote a more equitable society and support in improving
living standards for those most in need, but it also supports economic stability and growth while at same time
creating decent jobs. This approach will require coordinated efforts between the private sector, CSOs, local
organizations, donors, and the government. Better targeting of financial resources and a sound regulatory
framework will ensure funds realize a greater impact, and with proper control mechanisms can assure that homes
actually get built, on time and within budget, and delivered to the intended target population.
3.2.9 CLIMATE IMPACTS ON THE HOUSING SECTOR
In addition to the impacts of quality and access on human development, Iraq’s housing sector has a considerable
impact on pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. Housing is intrinsically linked to climate change to the extent
that is a major producer of emissions but also in the respect that housing protects people from the effects of severe
temperatures and other climate events. In this sense, environmentally friendly and resource efficient housing can
support slowing climate change and preventing the worst of its impacts through climate adaption and mitigation
efforts both in how housing is constructed as well as where it is located. Increasingly, there is a need for resilient
housing that is adapted to rising temperatures and other climate risks. Improvements to the sector therefore need
to address its climate impacts, through climate sensitive design, improved construction practices and materials, and
sustainable site design and locations, including adoption of measures that reduce energy demand.
Housing design and construction, directly affects residential demand for energy for heating and cooling. Estimates
suggest that cities are responsible for 75 percent of global CO2 emissions, in which buildings and transportation
comprise the largest contributors (UNEP Website, 2022). In fact, residential and commercial buildings are
responsible for over one-third of all energy-related GHG emissions (International Energy Agency, 2019). In Iraq, the
largest consumer of electricity is the residential sector representing 48.3 percent of total consumption (Istepanian,
2020b). Heating and cooling are responsible for much of this demand; in Baghdad, it accounts for 69 percent of
energy use in homes (Hasan, 2012).
While Iraq’s uniform building code is not always effective in directing design and construction, it sets some minimum
standards for the construction sector. Further, there are no energy efficiency certification processes or rating
systems. Energy conservation measures therefore remain entirely voluntary. While appliance standards with energy
ratings exists for a limited number of appliances for the GCC, the standards lack enforcement (Istepanian, 2020).
Beyond the environmental cost of unreliable and inefficient energy systems, utility costs can pose significant cost
burdens to households and can make a up a large proportion of housing expenses, particularly for low-income
households. In this respect, installing energy efficient and renewable measures can help support more affordable
and reliable electricity and can realize substantial housing cost savings. Unfortunately, in Iraq, high levels of
electricity and fuel subsidies act as a disincentive to reduce consumption, but at the same time, the dysfunctional
network has resulted in high levels of consumer dissatisfaction, theft of services and corruption which in turn,
prohibits raising tariffs. Further, when households are not being supplied with network electricity, they face the
excessive cost of generators which is nine-fold that of the grid (IEA, 2019b). Generators provide less than 15 percent
of electricity consumed but accounts for more than 90 percent of consumer spending on electricity (IEA, 2019b)
which can amount to as much as IQD 5.8 million (USD $4k) annually. In some scenarios, Iraqis households can spend
eight times the average electricity bill in the MENA region, one of the highest rates in the world (IEA, 2019b) resulting

16
in significant household expenditures and housing cost burden, yet basic cost-effective energy conservation
measures still appear absent in Iraqi homes. For example, solar heaters and photovoltaic panels which can be
extremely cost effective and have enormous potential in Iraq, are not typically utilized in Iraq unlike other MENA
countries. In this respect, an affordable housing programme could be a test bed for energy efficiency solutions in
Iraq, and support raising awareness about the effectiveness and cost savings potential, and at the same time, realize
significant reductions in emissions.
Emissions from buildings can be addressed by making buildings more energy efficient or by minimizing ‘pre-use’
emissions from construction and materials manufacturing and transport. Currently, housing is largely designed and
constructed with little regard for climatic conditions or cultural context which has resulted in highly inefficient
buildings (Al-Taie et al, 2012) and significant environmental and costly consequences borne by importing materials.
Iraq rates fifth most vulnerable country in the world to extreme temperatures and water shortages (UN Environment
Programme, 2017). Without efforts to adapt to and mitigate climate challenges through a more sustainable housing
sector, climate challenges will likely magnify. The World Green Building Council (2023) outlines the business case for
sustainable and affordable housing including the cost of inaction such as follows: spiralling energy demand, increases
in informal settlements and continued unmanaged sprawl that can exacerbate inequality and socio spatial disparity,
the risk of abandoned assets such as infrastructure and public services due to climate scenarios, increased risk of
financial and energy poverty, reduced resilience and increased susceptibility of destruction to less durable
structures, and health risks due to unhealthy housing, pollution and increased temperatures.
Addressing climate change through housing will require a multi-pronged approach. This proposed joint project will
support the wider adoption of alternative approaches to help transform the impact of the Iraqi housing sector on
the environment. The following green measures will be considered in the housing design and construction process:
Traditional building styles and materials: Traditional materials that present green characteristics are used
marginally, in rural areas or in small-scale CSO initiatives. They include stone in lieu of blocks or brick, the use of clay
and straw to make bricks, and reed as a substitute for iron rebar.

technologies and passive cooling solutions. In all three cities where stakeholder interviews were conducted,

Locally adapted design: Building modelling that considers local geographic contexts can also support the

building efficiency, quality, and performance, and further reduce cost.
Locally produced building materials: The international transportation of building materials is a source of pollution.
Local materials can thus have a smaller carbon footprint than equivalent imported materials while their manufacture
creates new economic opportunities.
Advanced construction methods: New building technologies, such as modular or pre-cast housing and bringing
standardized building components to market, could be used as a strategy to ramp up production and produce cost
effective durable and sustainable housing, which could realize enormous environmental benefits and lower both
construction costs and utility expenses.
Solar panels and water heating: A report by the International Energy Agency (2019b), asserts that the falling price
of renewable sources offers feasible alternative power solutions and can increase reliability and reduce the cost of
electricity supply. Because solar sources are particularly good in Iraq, the report further contends that if the solar
industry were developed it could currently outcompete oil-fired generation in terms of levelized costs of electricity

Energy efficient materials, appliances and equipment: According to the International Energy Agency (2019)
programmes to encourage energy conservation and efficiency should be given priority in Iraq. Measures such as
utilizing high-efficiency cooling systems can deliver immediate benefits and the realize significant cost savings.
Further, the IEA contends that the use of high efficiency appliances should be coupled with consumer campaigns
that raise awareness on energy efficient measures and potential cost savings. Insulation is also sometimes used as

Water conservation: Iraq depends on neighbouring countries for an estimated 70 percent of water supply and river
levels have dropped an estimated 40 percent in the last two decades (IEA, 2019b). Untreated water along with other
factors such as salinization of the water supply, inefficient water management, governance and regulatory
frameworks, and upstream supply issues from neighbouring countries are contributing factors to Iraq’s water
scarcity. In 2020, 18 percent of the population were considered to live in water-scarce areas (World Data Lab, 2021).
There is a need for better water management systems such as the treatment and recycling of domestic water waste.
Water conservation measures such as energy efficient water pumping systems, grey water recycling, rain barrel
harvesting, drought resilient landscaping, low flow plumbing fixtures could be considered at the community/
household level in Iraq.
Sanitation systems: 85.7 percent of households across all governorates have access to basic water services (UNICEF
MICS, 2018). However, only 40 percent have access to safely managed water and around 23 percent to safely
managed sanitation (UN, 2021). While most Iraqi’s have access to some form of improved sanitation (99% urban/
90% rural) only a small proportion are linked to a piped sewage network (33 percent urban/ 4 percent rural) and
instead depend on septic tanks or sewage holes (UN-Habitat website). Further, existing water and sewage
infrastructure in Iraq, including treatment plants and pipe networks, are largely in disrepair; 83% of wastewater is
insufficiently treated posing significant health and environmental risks (UN-Habitat website). Improved sanitation
systems are needed, as those in old urban centres are overburdened by densification. In newly urbanized areas, they
are often very basic. Septic tanks are not properly maintained, and liquid waste pollutes ground water. Furthermore,
the investment in sanitation systems is an additional cost to low-income households in areas where infrastructure
is lacking.
Energy standards and green rating systems: Ratings systems help to assess and ensure that buildings meet a broad
range of predefined green standards. There are many good international examples of green rating systems (i.e.,
BREEAM, GBC, LEED) that can be adapted and adopted to fit within the Iraqi climate and geographical context.
Furthermore, the development of energy codes and standards that set the minimum energy performance
requirements for both new buildings and existing buildings should be enmeshed into the uniform building code that
enshrines the construction of adequate and healthy homes into law. Energy standards can include equipment and
appliances including lighting, plumbing, commercial and industrial, and consumer products.
Compact Development: To achieve more sustainable development patterns that reduces climate impact and
bolsters resilience, Iraq will need to move towards more compact development that utilizes land more efficiently
and reduces infrastructure burdens. Compact development can reduce sprawl and car dependency, create more
walkable and accessible environments, and increase efficiency in providing infrastructure and services. Increasing
density can have significant impact on reducing the carbon footprint, lowering emissions, and preventing continued
environmental degradation. Furthermore, sustainable housing includes choosing site locations that are more
resilient and less vulnerable to climate risks and hazards (flooding, drought, dust storms, fires, etc.). At the same
time, all housing is to an extent vulnerable to climate change and therefore, should be constructed in a manner that
is more resilient and suitably constructed to local climatic conditions. New construction should be designed and
constructed deliberately responding to the local climatic risks so that it can withstand climate events, for example,

3.2.10 KEY CHALLENGES IN THE SECTOR’S VALUE CHAIN
The capacities of the housing sector to meet the demand for more and higher quality housing are insufficient.
Housing in Iraq is mainly supplied through self-construction, most of which is informal. The government and the
private sector are also involved in the provision of housing, but the overall supply of housing is insufficient. The
formal supply of housing is characterized by high prices as well as housing units that are not adapted to the needs
of the households, with estimated costs even higher for self-construction. The quality and sustainability of housing
also suffers as a result of weaknesses in firm capacities and organization across the value chain.
Analysis of the current situation and stakeholder interviews highlight how the potential of the sector to grow and
reduce costs is held back at multiple points by factors including the unreliability of land titles, skills shortages, limited
capacities and coordination in the private sector, poor urban planning and overburdened infrastructure, financial
constraints, and the burdens of administrative costs and procedures (Figure 1). Creating quality jobs, expanding the
supply of housing, and better managing the sector’s climate impact will require solutions to the most serious
constraints in the housing sector value chain.
