Governance and regulation
According to several stakeholders, the biggest barriers to construction are administrative. More specifically, the
regulatory framework governing the access and operation of housing and construction services, as well as the
procedural framework in place to attract and facilitate investments into these sectors act as significant barriers to
the development and growth of these sectors. Furthermore, these rules are not always respected. This is due to
weak enforcement of rules and regulations in general and is not specific to the construction sector. Construction
permits represent another high cost that investors cannot always predict with precision, as there is subjectivity in
the process.
Iraq’s housing laws are generally fragmented, piecemeal, and outmoded. A new housing law was proposed as part
of the plan for Housing and Reconstruction in Liberated Areas, covering technical, legislative, administrative, and
financial aspects of housing. However, the passage of the law has been stalled. The Federal Budget Law (2023-25)
adopted in June includes a considerable increase in capital expenditure, with housing and construction among the
sectors with the largest growth in allocations, as well as commitments to invest in various construction and
infrastructure projects across the country. Land allocations have also been used in an attempt to improve access to
housing, though these initiatives have had limited success in addressing barriers to accessing affordable housing for
low- and middle-income Iraqis.
From the household perspective, constructing a home through formal means often entails an expensive, and long
and arduous bureaucratic process. Policies and practices which constrain the responsiveness of the market, such as
restrictive zoning and planning regulations, and lengthy and costly bureaucratic procedures escalates prices and
diminishes quality, and generally leads to underinvestment in the housing market (World Bank, 2020). According to
a UNESCO (2019) report, procedures for allocating land, registering property, and obtaining construction licenses
are burdensome and hindered by heavy bureaucracy, which ultimately result in higher housing prices. Beyond the
residential sector, the World Bank’s Doing Business report (2019) found that obtaining a construction permit can
entail up to 11 procedures and 167 days. Further, registering a property entails five procedures, can take up to 51
days and costs up to 7.3 percent of the property value. A transfer of title deeds requires several signatures from
regional and national authorities which can require extensive travel, time, and back and forth (Fleet, 2019).
Priorities for the project addressing challenges in governance and regulation include supporting public works,
addressing the governance of affordable housing, and strengthening capacities for policy formulation and
implementation on construction sector development.
Planning and infrastructure
Weak urban planning and infrastructure development affect construction, increase the uncertainty facing investors,
and reduce the ultimate quality and sustainability of housing in Iraq. There is a disconnect between urban planning
and urban development in Iraqi cities. The lengthy process of approving new plans often leaves them obsolete by
the time they are made official. For example, the Master Plan of Baghdad was only recently approved after decades
of work and revisions. Consequently, construction projects are developed either informally or with special permits
that do not always comply with these plans. Planning may also not take into consideration the needs of residents.
For instance, one Erbil contractor reported that some formally authorized plots of land in his city meet the
requirement in terms of minimum surface area but have an elongated shape that complicates design and
construction.
Unplanned urbanization and underinvestment in infrastructure result in overburdened infrastructure. Building
construction in new developments sometimes precedes the full provision of infrastructure and basic services.
Although the electrification rate in Iraq is reported to be 100%, electricity supply is unreliable, Iraqi households and
businesses experience frequent outages and the problem is accentuated in the summer months when cooling
systems are used. While roads are eventually built, it is not uncommon for sanitation systems to remain basic,
causing ground pollution. Cities often suffer from drainage problems. Even minor rainfall can cause partial flooding
on roads, which in turn affects traffic.

21
Local planning capacities will be strengthened through the project. In addition, multi-stakeholder capacity
development, policy dialogue and strategy design activities under the project will include support for stronger urban
planning that is better integrated with infrastructure and housing development.
Land
Iraq faces an acute shortage of buildable land in urban areas to satisfy housing demand. While many factors are
behind this, informal housing and affordable housing deficits are, in part, the result of weak land governance,
administration and enforcement systems. Restrictions on use are classified in the title, and whenever a construction
permit or transfer of property happens, the land use of a property can come under review with the authorities, but
this is often done in an arbitrary manner. Furthermore, the conversion of land for housing construction is
disconnected from larger development frameworks and fails to plan for the appropriate density and scale the city
would need to effectively meet future housing demand. Limited official statistics on land use, paper-based land
registry systems and the lack of an e-cadastre also complicates the measurement and tracking of shortages and
further inhibits planning for future development and complicates private investment decisions.
The cost of land and issues with land titles can be major constraints to real estate development. Although land prices
were not raised as a major constraint by stakeholders in Erbil and Basra, where new urban areas are being developed,
land was reported to be rare and expensive in Baghdad. Stakeholders reported that fraud on land titles had become
a common business. Information on deaths, inheritance, and individuals who expatriate is sold, as these life events
provide others with the opportunity to illegally take over physical assets administratively.
The illegal occupation of land by informal settlements, motivated by the scarcity of affordable homes, is a further
constraint to investment and construction. The informal occupation of land also increases the households’
vulnerability as they can be evicted and lose both their shelter and the investment in the self-construction.
Sometimes they also lose their investment in the land as the informal or illegal occupation of the land does not mean
they didn’t need to pay to occupy it. Furthermore, if the land is not suitable for construction, the households are
also exposed to disaster risks such as floods, land erosion and landslides.
Finance
Financial underdevelopment is a barrier to construction and limits the affordability of housing. Iraq remains a largely
cash-based economy. Because of the limited access to housing finance, only high and medium-high income
households can afford to buy quality homes. In most cases, new homes that are self-built or constructed by small
contractors are paid for either in cash through household savings or by borrowing from family or friends. In the case
of investment projects, homes are often financed by the developer in instalments, with the first payment often
taking place before the housing unit is completed (off-plan sales). Sometimes, developers only require a certain
percentage of the total price to be paid before the household can move in. The household continues to make
payments over a few months (a couple of years at the most) and the individual property title is transferred after the
last payment is made. Financing rules may need to be adjusted to foster improved housing affordability while
discouraging purely speculative investment in housing.
Housing loans are typically provided by state-funded lending institutions through the Real Estate Bank (REB) and
National Housing Fund (NHF).
• The Real Estate bank is one of four state owned special purpose banks in Iraq established in 1948. It is a
Central Bank of Iraq (CBI) fund that provides long term financing to private banks which, in turn, can offer
housing loans to individual clients. In 2021, the REB was recapitalized with IQD 1 trillion ($685 USD million)
(CBI, 2021) and the Iraqi government announced a new lending initiative for the purchase and construction
of homes. The loans provided are interest free with a repayment period of 20 years. The government also
announced that all interest on past and current loans were to be cancelled.
• The National Housing fund (NHF) was established in 2004 under the Ministry of Construction and Housing
to provide small and short-term loans to low- or middle-income borrowers who formally own a plot of land
and wish to build on it. In February 2021, the Fund was also recapitalized with IQD 900 billion (USD $616
million) (CBI, 2021) and the MOCH launched a new housing initiative through the NHF for the construction

22
of new housing, or the purchase of units. The loans are interest free, with a one-time administrative fee of
5 percent of the loan value, and a repayment period of up to 20 years. Recent reports indicate that the loan
amounts fall far short of the market price, though 103,000 loans had been issued and 104 apartment
complexes have been financed across fourteen governorates as of July 2022.
Most available loans are provided to public sector employees (or those for whom they can act as a guarantor), for
whom collateral and income verification is obtainable. In general, access to home loans tend to benefit middle-
income groups as opposed to the lower income groups. Private sector housing finance does exist, but not to a
significant extent. Loans from private banks are typically personal loans that are small in value and short-term. Iraq
banks provide very limited services, primarily limited to conventional cash transfers.
The housing shortage (estimated at up to 3.5 million units) is such that there is still a large effective demand amongst
clients who do not need to rely on housing finance. The constraint on offtake will only be felt by existing developers
when the pool of such clients shrinks down. This constraint, however, is a barrier to entry to more players who could
find in lower-income households a market they could serve.
Commercial lending is also limited. State-owned and private banks do offer loans but at very high interest rates and
are often fully securitized, requiring a guarantor. Instead, entrepreneurs often borrow from family and friends. None
of the construction and real estate companies interviewed relied on construction finance from banks, either public
or private. The construction financing that is available through government-led initiatives is reserved for well-
connected investors.

Project activities directly related to the development of relevant financial instruments and support for regulatory
reform and sector development will help to address the challenges that both homebuyers and MSMEs in
construction face in accessing finance.
Skills and labour
While labour is available, skill shortages hinder employment and housing construction. Employers have identified
potential skill gaps for bricklayers and stonemasons, carpenters and joiners, and concrete workers, as well as for
cartographers and surveyors, construction managers, and mechanical engineering technicians (UNESCO, 2019).
Contractors hire local labour (Iraqis or refugees and migrants present in Iraq) because it is available and because
they must meet the minimum requirement for Iraqi workers. They also hire locally based foreign workers as they
ask for lower wages than Iraqi workers and are perceived as being easier to manage and less demanding. Contractors
hire workers internationally when they require specific skills not available locally (to construct high-rise buildings in
Erbil, for instance) or when a foreign company brings its staff to the project site. This can, however, be constrained
by regulatory restrictions on the recognition, access, and operation of foreign professionals in the architecture and
engineering sectors. These restrictions may hinder efforts to fill skills gaps in the near-term and to develop the
capacities of local workers through skills transfers from experts. Limited knowledge and skills on the adoption of
new technologies and sustainable construction limit the potential to improve housing.
Architects have somewhat limited involvement in the housing sector, affecting the quality of construction. The legal
requirement to have an architect sign off on construction plans before they are approved by the municipality is not
always respected. Developers sometimes choose to save on costs and buy plans from architects that were not drawn
specifically for their project. This affects design negatively, both in terms of quality and creativity. There is no Iraqi
or local identity that shows on new constructions. Construction techniques haven’t changed in decades and there is
very little innovation used in construction.

Capacity development targeting firms and workers through the project will build skills for enhanced productivity and
sector sustainability. Stronger coordination between firms and support for housing and employment programmes
will emphasise skill development to drive inclusive growth through the sector. As such, these activities will contribute
to the goals of the EU-funded TVET Reform Project, which aims to improve the effectiveness of the technical and

Materials
While domestic manufacturing is considerable, construction materials are often imported to reduce costs or to
access specific products not made locally, particularly finishing materials for larger development projects. Iraqi

the foundations are mostly supplied by local producers.

account for a large share of domestic production and the tight control of trade policies gives the government
dominance over construction sub-sectors as it chooses the suppliers and subsequently the cost and quality of the

Materials are imported from many different countries but mainly from neighbouring Iran and Turkey, as well as
Europe. The recent ISIS conflict resulted in significant production losses coupled with intensive housing damage in
affected areas resulting in a greater necessity to import a larger share of manufactured products. Imported materials
do not always meet quality standards. Imports enter the Iraqi market relatively easily, but quality controls at the
different points of entry are not systematic, either because of the large amounts to be controlled or because of
corruption.

The cost of imported construction materials creates uncertainty and is a significant factor behind the high costs of
housing in Iraq. The cost of imports varies with the exchange rate and the IQD continues to be volatile. As many
materials are imported, the devaluation of the IQD has increased the cost of construction. In Erbil, construction
companies that had signed contracts with locked-in prices suffered from price increases and had to deliver at a lower
margin or at a loss (especially on Government contracts as there was no flexibility to revise the terms of the
contracts). Developers, on the other hand, were not much impacted by increases in the IQD cost of imported
materials as their sale prices were denominated in US dollars, thus passing on the exchange rate risk to the home
buyer.
Beyond exchange rate uncertainty, the prices of many building materials are affected by global trends. For instance,
steel used to be imported from Ukraine. After February 2022, supply from Ukraine was interrupted, creating a
disruption on the market. The cost of materials can also vary based on the (formal and informal) tariffs paid at the
border, which can vary widely at the discretion of the controller and between points of entry. Some points of entry
are controlled by the Government and others are controlled by militias. Volatile prices in construction materials can
be particularly challenging for smaller firms to manage, as they are less likely to hold large inventories, purchase in
bulk or hold sufficient cash reserves.
Construction sector structure
While there are many firms of all sizes active in Iraq’s construction sector, limited capacities at the firm level and
little coordination between these actors limits their potential and contributes to poor housing quality and high
prices. The construction sector is dominated by micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs), the majority of which
are individual businesses, and to a lesser degree, conglomerates. MSMEs face several constraints in scaling up
business in Iraq due to factors such as lack of available finance that supports business expansion or construction
finance, expensive and arduous bureaucratic and administrative constraints including registering land and obtaining
permits, and a fragmented marketplace. Many smaller businesses operate informally and lack of compliance with

Given the scale of their involvement in the sector, improved cooperation with foreign-owned firms and enhanced

Construction firms are either hired directly by households or a contractor hired by the household (in the “owner-

developer incentives and soft subsidies, these larger developments remain overly expensive for most middle- and
lower-income households.
Increased private sector investment will be a key driver for growing the construction sector – and housing sector
more generally – in Iraq and is needed to support the adoption of new technologies and sustainable business models,
improve efficiency, generate employment, and improve housing quality and affordability. While Iraq has adopted
legal and regulatory reforms to encourage foreign investment and improve the business climate, including through
the promulgation of the Investment Law and the National Investment Commission (NIC), there still remain significant
challenges in terms of the administrative and procedural framework that make it difficult to attract and retain
investors into these sectors. The bureaucracy attached to obtaining licenses, land and permits which can take several
years (Al-Mawlawi, 2019), complexity and lack of clarity in regulations, unpredictability of the policy environment,
and lack of coordination among government agencies are all factors that complicate the existing investment
environment.
The government is directly involved in only a small fraction of housing construction, typically intended for public
employees. Public construction projects are first proposed by a public entity such as the MOCH and then requires
the approval of the Ministry of Planning and the Ministry of Finance, the latter of which provides the required funds
for the project. The contract is then awarded to a state-owned company or a private contractor, and each
administration monitors their select construction projects. Although there are a number of state-owned
construction firms in Iraq, private businesses are responsible for most value added in the sector. Public tenders are
often affected by lengthy project delays, high construction costs, and a lack of local materials and skilled workers.
From an administrative perspective, public tenders entail complicated bureaucratic processes, and a lack of
coordinated planning further aggravated by budget shortfalls which also greatly impedes the sector’s productivity.
Corruption is another important factor; public projects are often awarded through nepotism resulting in poor quality
or incomplete projects. Consequentially, there is a high level of mistrust in the government within the construction
sector due to a long track record of delayed payments, stalled projects, procurement opacity, and the absence of
contract guarantees.
Current policies and practices are also widely perceived to be insufficient to address the threats from climate and
other natural disasters, for example. The incorporation of green or sustainable elements in construction is rare, but
there is potential to develop this further. The importance of construction standards was made clear recently by the
earthquake that hit Turkey and Syria and destroyed thousands of homes.
Small businesses in the materials and construction sectors will benefit from their involvement in the project’s
assistance on affordable housing and sector development, which includes firm-level capacity development and

25
enhanced sector coordination. Support for skill development in the sector will similarly contribute to addressing
these challenges.
Maintenance and renovation
Maintenance and renovation costs can be significant and have been cited as a major contributor to the current
dilapidated state of the existing housing stock by multiple stakeholders. Homeowners often rebuild their houses
after ten years or so in order to better adapt the structure to their needs, as the original designs are often not well
suited to the demands of the owners. Renovations are also motivated by the rapid deterioration of construction, a
result of poor maintenance and the poor quality of the initial construction. For example, in two (low-rise) residential
complexes built by developers visited in Erbil, most houses were identical, but a few were distinct, having already
been rebuilt by their owners.
Many of the high rises built in previous decades face neglect and deterioration. Large residential developments
require more complex operations and management systems. Stakeholders believe such management tools are
currently lacking on the market, which will lead to their quick deterioration. To better support the entire building
life cycle – from planning to construction – and continuing maintenance and operations, Building Information
Modelling (BIM) has been proposed as an internationally recognized and useful tool to support cost savings,
reductions in construction duration, and increased building performance in the architectural, engineering and
construction (AEC) sectors. BIM is a project management platform that includes a suite of software tools that can
integrate data sets for multiple project tasks into 3D models, and functions as a collaborative platform that connects
all project parties.
While retrofits to the existing housing stock to mitigate climate impacts and adapt to climate risks are needed,
insufficient capacities and the lack of effective price signalling for homeowners further reduce the sustainability of
Iraqi housing. The project’s support for a strengthened construction sector will create opportunities for additional
investment in maintenance and renovation.

4. DESCRIPTION OF THE ACTION
Against the backdrops discussed under the problem analysis section, the proposed project aims to stimulate decent
work opportunities for young women and men while addressing urgent need for affordable housing, especially for
lower income and vulnerable people in Iraq. Action on job creation through affordable housing construction involves
implementing specific strategies and initiatives. The project seeks to introduce a public works programme
complementing support for addressing existing gaps within the Government and the private sector through
Employment Intensive Investment Programme (EIIP) initiative. Furthermore, it aims to improve access to adequate
and sustainable housing to create better living conditions for low-income and vulnerable populations; and build the
capacities of the housing sector – including government actors and micro, small and medium enterprises, and civil
society organizations – as a driver of economic growth.
The proposed actions will foster the following key elements while realizing the desired outcomes of the project:
Investment in affordable housing projects: Governments, both at the local and national levels, allocate funds for
the development of affordable housing projects. These funds come from public budgets, private investments, or a
combination of both. Allocating resources to affordable housing construction creates a demand for labour and
materials, generating jobs in the construction sector.
Public-Private partnerships: Encourage public-private partnerships which allows collaboration between
government agencies and private developers as well as MSMEs involved in the housing sector. These partnerships
can help leverage private sector expertise and funding while ensuring that affordable housing remains a priority.
Such collaborations can lead to more significant housing developments, translating into more and better job
opportunities.
Diverse job opportunities: Affordable housing construction does not only create direct jobs but also generates
indirect and induced employment opportunities in related industries like architecture, engineering, real estate,
finance, and property management. Fostering a diverse job market can lead to a more sustainable and robust local
economy.
Streamlining regulatory and legal frameworks permitting processes: Facilitating revisions to the legislative and
policy framework that better enables affordable housing delivery including simplifying and expediting permitting
processes can speed up construction timelines and reduce development costs. This can create a conducive
environment for builders, attracting more investments and subsequently generating employment in the
construction sector.
Building affordable housing technical competency for government officials: Capacity development of government
actors, both at the national and governorate level, can support in building the skills and aptitude necessary for
building an integrated affordable housing ecosystem, including developing effective policies and programs based on
sound rules and regulations, administrative and compliance procedures, sound planning, and feasible finance
mechanisms.
Updating the National Housing Policy: Updating the NHP can help build knowledge and evidence-based regarding
Iraq’s current housing challenges, which will in turn support in building a concise and comprehensive road map to
address these complex challenges.
Capacity building and skill development for local businesses: Investing in skills development for MSMEs and
entrepreneurs in the housing and construction sector can improve the quality of labour available for affordable
housing projects. By providing MSMEs with specialized skills and certifications, they become more efficient and
effective to create employment opportunities and can contribute to the successful completion of housing
developments integrating green and innovative practices.
Promoting small and women-owned businesses: Encouraging the participation of small and women-owned
businesses in affordable housing projects create economic opportunities for underrepresented groups, especially

27
women, who represent low rate of participation in the labour market. Policies and regulatory framework that
prioritize women to participate in the labour market stimulate job creation and support local economies.
Social partners engagement: Involving workers’ and employers’ organizations in the planning and construction of
affordable housing have multiple benefits. It helps to advocate for workers’ rights at work and build trust with
employers and government counterparts at national and local level. It also creates a fertile ground for effective social
dialogue and collective bargaining.
Climate change: Addressing climate change through the construction of sustainable affordable homes that are
denser and located in compact communities thereby utilizing land and infrastructure more efficiently, and which
integrates climate sensitive design principals and energy efficiency measures will support in raising environmental
awareness and enable testing innovative and sustainable housing solutions specific to the Iraqi climate context. As
the world transitions to a more sustainable future, the construction industry can be a significant driver of change.
By advocating for and facilitating the adoption of environmentally friendly construction practices, such as green
building technologies and materials, the project can help create new opportunities for decent work. Simultaneously,
investing in the training and upskilling of construction workers to meet the demands of the green economy can
ensure that these jobs not only contribute to environmental sustainability but also offer fair wages, safe working
conditions, and social protection. The project can act as a bridge between governments, employers, and workers in
the construction sector, fostering social dialogue and cooperation to develop policies and practices that
simultaneously address climate change challenges and promote the creation of quality employment opportunities.
4.1 THEORY OF CHANGE
IF the alignment of national policies and regulations with international labour standards and their enforcement in
the construction sector, including on eliminating child labour (Oc.1) and green affordable housing and decent
employment in Iraq (Oc. 2) will be increased; and, IF the business environment and participation of local MSMEs and
investors in the construction sector will be improved (Oc. 3), while the influence on labour markets of employers’
and workers’ organisations involved in social dialogue with the government will be also strengthened (Oc. 4), then
decent work and improved living conditions, including for the most vulnerable, will be supported in Iraq (Impact),
as long as the political and economic situation in Iraq is stable; there is no epidemic outbreak; there is no climatic
disturbances preventing the growth and expansion of selected value chain; a political commitment exists to enacting
policy reforms, implement PWP and National Housing Policy; the investment in affordable and green
housing; national beneficiaries introduce recommendations developed under the programme in their institutions
and working procedures; GoI has political will and commitment towards strengthening social partners.
4.2 PROJECT IMPACT
The overall impact of the project is to stimulate decent work and improve living conditions, including for the most
vulnerable, in Iraq. The objective is aligned with the EU Action Document (NDICI ASIA/2021/043-218) - Support to
durable solutions for Iraq’s displaced populations: integration into the national labour market and national systems
for education and social protection and its specific objective 1.1: promote an economic transformation that creates
decent jobs and increases productive capacity.

international labour standards and their enforcement in the construction sector, including on eliminating child

4.3.2 OUTCOME ONE: DESCRIPTION
Improved alignment of national policies and regulations with international labour standards and their
enforcement in the construction sector, including on eliminating child labour.
The creation of a public work programme in Iraq is highlighted as a priority for both economic reform and sustainable
development. In the White Paper on Economic Reform adopted by the Government of Iraq in 2020, the Government
highlights the ambition of “creating legal and regulatory frameworks needed to operationalize public works
programmes”, under the second axis focusing on macroeconomic reform and employment creation (GoI, 2020: p.
62). Here, public works are seen as a means of creating sustainable employment opportunities - particularly for low-
income households, those on low pay, or the unemployed - on the one hand, and of contributing to local
development and infrastructure through small, locally defined projects on the other. Similarly, the Iraq Vision for
Sustainable Development 2030, as drafted in 2019 by the Ministry of Planning, also identifies the establishment of
public works as one of the key investment pillars to create job opportunities in the immediate term, in recognition
that initiatives and policies to foster job creation in the private sector are more likely to bear fruit in the medium- to
long-term (GOI, 2019). Most recently, in November 2022, the new government under its Development Programme
has shown interest to invest and implement in National Public Works Programme, especially in the housing and
construction sector.
A range of humanitarian and development actors have been implementing cash-for-work programmes across Iraq
for several years now though the interventions vary in their design and objectives, including in terms of targeting.
Within this context, a PWP is indeed a key tool for the government to create employment in the immediate term to
complement the clear gaps in employment creation in the private sector.
Under this outcome, the ILO, leveraging its vast experience in designing and implementing PWP, is planning to
mainstream the Employment Intensive Investment Programme (EIIP) and Local Resource Based (LRB) approaches
with gender responsiveness and sustainable financing mechanisms within the National Public Works Programme
which is planned to be designed and piloted in the selected two governorates of Iraq. Besides identifying sustainable
sources of financing, this would require initiating evidence generation, assessments, and analyses to inform
programme design parameters and implementation modalities, along with drafting and adopting key policies,
Standard Operation Procedures (SOPs), and implementation guidelines. Additionally, these processes will need to
go hand in hand with core capacity-strengthening activities both at national and sub-national levels to strengthen
the ability of the government to effectively implement the programme, in coordination with UN-Habitat and ITC
with expertise in the housing and construction sector. This will entail enhanced investment opportunity to achieve
sustainable and long-term impacts on employment, economic growth, and poverty reduction.
In parallel to the above, the core component of outcome 1 includes technical support to the government in fighting
against child labour, labour governance, and gender equality in the housing and construction sector.
4.3.3 OUTCOME ONE: OUTPUTS AND ACTIVITIES
Output 1.1: Improved capacities of ministerial and decentralised actors for Public Works Programme design and
implementation integrating Employment Intensive Approaches focusing on the housing sector.
Under output 1.1, the ILO will provide technical support to developing Public Works Programme through
Employment Intensive Investment Programme (EIIP). The approaches used at the EIIP focus on strengthening and
empowering institutions to create an enabling environment for socio-economic recovery and development through

29
policies that promote decent work at public infrastructure delivery. The ILO will act as a technical facilitator for public
and private sector sectors to effectively plan, design, and implement EIIP interventions for providing developing
sustainable infrastructure and productive employment opportunities. The ILO offers technical assistance to relevant
ministries and local authorities to develop their capacity in mainstreaming employment-intensive approaches. Such
assistance includes assessing the employment potential of existing programmes, reviewing procurement processes,
developing technical guidelines, conducting technical trainings, and promoting community involvement.
Furthermore, the ILO under this output will be working across three dimensions: policy, institutional capacity, and
direct implementation.
The policy work will ensure the inclusion of decent work principles; Local-Resources based approaches; gender
responsiveness; and sustainable financing and procurement mechanisms. Specific construction sector will be
focused on, such as the bricks manufacturing within housing sector.
In addition, the ILO will develop operational tools and guidelines to implement and monitor the public work
programme with a focus on infrastructural interventions in the housing sector adopting EI Approaches.
On implementation/ demonstration level, the EIIP approaches will be integrated into the construction interventions
under the housing sector including the relevant infrastructure around housing. Also building local capacities through
different training activities targets the local governmental partners and implementing agencies and private sector
contractors.
The quantification of created jobs in the project has been highlighted by the EU as the key indicative result to
strengthen the business case of the investment. Therefore, the ILO will lead the process of quantifying and reporting
employment impact through EIIP monitoring and impact assessment processes.

4.4 RESULTS CHAIN OUTCOME TWO
4.4.1 OUTCOME TWO: INTERVENTION LOGIC
If the awareness and capacities of local, provincial, and national government staff on affordable housing planning
and policy are increased (Op 2.1); if the accessibility and awareness by the relevant public actors of the national
regulatory and legal framework applicable to affordable housing delivery are improved (Op. 2.2); if the availability
of financial tools and models for affordable housing applicable to the Iraqi context is enhanced (Op 2.3); if the
coordination and local planning capacity for local government and key local representatives in two neighbourhoods
selected for pilot project is expanded (Op 2.4); and, if the availability of multi-story green affordable housing units
including basic infrastructure (roads, water, sanitation and hygiene facilities and electricity) for communities in two
Iraqi governorates is increased, then green affordable housing and decent employment in Iraq (Oc. 2) will be also
increased, as long as participants see the need for and engage in affordable housing policy dialogue); investors to
engage in development of new finance models; housing directorates and local government are committed to fully
implementing neighbourhood plans; there are no interruptions that would limit opportunities for plan
implementation or restrict mobility; a commitment exists from local & national government to invest in affordable
housing.
4.4.2 OUTCOME TWO: DESCRIPTION
Increased green affordable housing and decent employment in Iraq

37
Housing has been duly recognized as a top priority by the government of Iraq. The necessity to rapidly bolster
housing production and ensure Iraqi’s have access to adequate housing is clearly articulated in multiple national
plans, including Iraq’s Vision 2030, the National Housing Policy, National Development Plans, the Poverty Reduction
Strategy, and the National Plan for Reconstruction and Development Framework. Within these agendas the
imperative to address the inadequate supply of housing is fully recognized and ambitious targets have been set, but
unfortunately, efforts continue to fall short of intentions due to the multitude of intertwined and ongoing
impediments previously mentioned.
In this respect, this outcome aims to build the knowledge base of the Iraqi government to effectively tackle the
complexity of housing challenges as the country transitions to a long-term development agenda. A central aspect of
this outcome is that it is not only intended to build the skills and tools necessary to formulate effective policies and
programs but also to heighten the political awareness on the necessity to rapidly address the affordable housing
deficit and the imperative for government to invest accordingly. At the core of this outcome, lies a ‘learn by doing’
model whereby UN-Habitat will assume a technical assistance role, in effort to transfer the knowledge, skills and
capacity to GOI counterparts through a mentorship approach. Achieving this goal will require intensive collaboration
and a strong commitment from the government to actively engage in these endeavours.
UN-Habitat’s support will adopt an ecosystem approach, whereby the proposed outputs and activities seek to
address housing holistically namely, through- policy, planning, finance, governance, housing development, and
addressing climate change. The outputs themselves, represent a continuum of activities where ultimately green
social housing units are constructed through two pilot projects, which in collaboration with ILO and ITC will produce
decent jobs and bolster the capacity of MSMEs. Tapping into UN-Habitat’s vast experience in housing and sustainable
development, the proposed project activities will aid the GOI in building the foundation necessary for building
effective affordable housing programs and enabling private investment to support these activities. Furthermore, the
project in its entirety, will directly address the impact of housing on climate change and will raise environmental
awareness at institutional and community levels. The project will introduce climate adaptation and mitigation
measures into the green social housing units and will demonstrate proof of concept for future green housing efforts.
4.4.3 OUTCOME TWO: OUTPUTS AND ACTIVITIES
Output 2.1: Increased awareness and capacities of local, provincial, and national government staff on affordable
housing planning and policy.
Under output 2.1, UN-Habitat will provide capacity building and technical assistance support to government
counterparts to build sufficient institutional competency to fully address affordable housing challenges in Iraq. UN-
Habitat will provide hands-on trainings that address the many facets of housing including but not limited to:
understanding the SDGs and other global agendas, principles of sustainable development, land management
strategies, strategic affordable housing planning, policy and program development, fundamentals of green
sustainable housing, housing and land finance tools, development finance, housing norms and standards, and
understanding basic housing economics including supply and demand principles.
The aim of this output is to support in building the knowledge base necessary for the government to effectively
tackle Iraq’s affordable housing challenges independently and for the long-term. The output also aims to facilitate
the Government’s commitment to invest in affordable housing through building a stronger foundation to better
comprehend and address the myriad of housing challenges. Capacity building will also focus on government enabling
approaches to support a better functioning housing sector as a whole, including enabling private sector investment
which can facilitate a more productive and sustainable housing market. Recipients of capacity building will be
targeted toward government staff involved in housing activities including ministries and directorates, at the national,
governorate, and local levels. Furthermore, capacity building will mainstream climate action throughout the training
curriculum to ensure addressing climate challenges is fully integrated into all aspects of addressing the housing
ecosystem. All efforts will also be made to ensure inclusion of women in all activities as well as the inclusion of
vulnerable populations.
Following the series of trainings and workshops, ongoing dialogue and continued knowledge exchange will be
supported through a peer exchange platform. UN-Habitat will deploy a web-based tool where participants can

38
continue to tap into UN-Habitat expertise and stay connected to their peers. In this respect, a mutual support
network is created and the opportunity for continued learning and exchange can extend beyond the trainings and
project duration.
UN-Habitat will use a combination of consultancy services and staff time and expertise to develop topical training
modules relevant to Iraqi capacity needs and for the delivery of trainings. Six to eight half day interactive training
modules (amounting to a 3-4 day training course) will be developed. Training materials may be adapted so that they
can be delivered to both national and provincial government staff or other stakeholder groups.
Under Output 2.1, efforts will also be made to support the MoCH in updating the National Housing Policy to better
reflect Iraq’s current housing situation and to build a cross-sectoral and multi-stakeholder roadmap to effectively
address Iraq’s entrenched housing challenges in the future. The first Iraq National Housing Policy (INHP) was
launched by the Ministry of Construction and Housing (MOCH) in 2010 with support from UN-Habitat to address the
multitude of housing issues facing the country and to develop actionable steps to remedy the situation. In 2017, the
policy was updated which included an assessment of the 2010 policy progress. The policy update concluded that
little had been accomplished as intended due to lack of sufficient stakeholder coordination and the rapid social and
economic changes that occurred during this period (2010-2015).
Given the vast changes that have of occurred since 2017, including recent economic shocks, the rapid expansion of
informal settlements, a precipitously escalating housing deficit, and the advent and impact of the COVID pandemic,
an update to the Policy is needed. An updated policy will evaluate the progress made since 2017 including more
recent government actions to address housing such as the expansion of loans available to homebuyers and the
progress the GOI has made in developing an enabling private sector approach through the National Investment
Commission, including the extent to which it has contributed to affordable housing, if at all. An important step in
building a robust housing ecosystem is to examine recent policy and programme effectiveness as well as continued
gaps in addressing housing so that corrective courses or new actions can be developed to address Iraq’s persistent
housing challenges more effectively and target available resources accordingly.
In this respect, UN-Habitat will support MoCH in updating the National Housing Policy which better reflects upon
and addresses current realities. The update will take a pro-poor and rights-based approach that reflects human rights
principles including the right to adequate housing. In this respect, the need to address housing challenges faced by
low-income and vulnerable populations will be a central to the National Housing Policy update.
For the National Housing Policy update, UN-Habitat will contract with an International Housing Policy consultant and
tap into project staff expertise to provide ample technical assistance to MOCH to undergo a comprehensive policy
update that reflects more current housing realities in Iraq at present. UN-Habitat staff will closely coordinate with
MOCH to ensure they commit staff and resources to the policy update, and ensure they are fully dedicated to taking
on a leadership role in the process.

Output 2.2: Improved accessibility and awareness by the relevant public actors of the national regulatory and
legal framework applicable to green and affordable housing delivery
Under output 2.2, UN-Habitat, with the support of an International Housing Policy Expert consultant and in
partnership with MoCH, will undertake a comprehensive assessment of the regulatory and legal framework related
to green and affordable housing. The aim is to identify the necessary reforms required to enhance the facilitation of
government-supported green and affordable housing initiatives.
Much of Iraq's housing laws are outdated, lack specificity or are non-existent, particularly concerning green and
social housing and other initiatives to address the housing needs of low-income and vulnerable populations. To
address these deficiencies, UN-Habitat and MoCH will engage in consultations with predefined stakeholders,
including Civil Society Organizations (CSOs), financial institutions, Ministries, and Housing Directorates. These
consultations will help to discern the practical implications of existing rules and regulations—going beyond their
theoretical intent.
Drawing insights from stakeholder interviews and document reviews, the assessment will encompass an evaluation
of applicable laws and regulations, a comprehensive gap analysis, and the formulation of concrete recommendations
for revisions. Moreover, the assessment may identify legislative gaps and propose instruments to bridge these policy
deficiencies. This may include recommendations for the development of a National Housing Act or National Social
Housing Regulation Act, or the establishment of processes to ensure fair and transparent beneficiary selection,
codified within the law.
The consolidated technical report will include the following components:
1.) An inventory or existing rules and regulations applicable to public sector initiatives that support green
and affordable housing delivery;
2.) An assessment of existing rules and regulations to determine which laws impede or enable public
investment in green and affordable housing;
3.) Recommendations for revisions to specific laws and/ or the formulation of new laws or regulations.
Recommendations will be vetted through a consultation process to validate findings.

green and affordable housing initiatives within the country. The assessment will comprehensively document all
existing legislation that enable the provision of environmentally sustainable and affordable housing and identify any
gaps and deficiencies to the current legislative and regulatory framework. Additionally, the assessment will examine
the extent to which these legal frameworks promote, enforce, and monitor equality and non-discrimination,
particularly concerning gender-based considerations, within the housing sector (CLIP SO 3-2).
In addition to conducting a comprehensive review of applicable laws and regulations, and drawing upon other
pertinent research, this undertaking will encompass conducting stakeholder interviews. These interviews will
provide critical insights into the practical implications of these laws and the extent to which tangible barriers exist.
Stakeholders to be engaged in interviews may include government ministries, state-owned housing enterprises
(SOEs), banks, financial institutions, planning authorities, and private developers or investors.
The overarching objective of this evaluation is to determine whether the existing rules and regulations either
facilitate or hinder the development and realization of green and affordable housing projects, as supported by
government policies and initiatives. This assessment will serve as a valuable reference tool, offering a clear and
detailed overview of the legal landscape in this regard.
Activity 2.2.3: Draft recommendations for revisions to regulatory and legal framework in a technical report that
would better enable affordable housing policy and programme development
UN-Habitat in close coordination with MOCH will then draft recommendations for necessary revisions to the
regulatory and legal framework related to green and affordable housing. The activities under this output will be
consolidated into one technical report. The consolidated report will be vetted through expert technical reviews and
a validation workshop comprised of the stakeholders earlier consulted during the initial assessment activities. The
final report will articulate how the existing framework could be improved to better enable public sector support for
affordable and green housing development and delivery. Recommendations to remove gender-discriminatory
clauses related to HLP (CLIP SO 3-2) including customary and traditional barriers to HLP rights will also be made, if
applicable. Following final drafting of the report, UN-Habitat and MOCH will seek formal endorsement. UN-Habitat
will also support the MOCH in advocacy and building the political support necessary to realize the adoption of the
new or revised legislation and regulations contained within the report.
Output 2.3: Improved availability of financial tools and models for affordable housing applicable to the Iraqi
context
Under output 2.3 UN-Habitat will support the GOI in developing sound financial mechanisms that will support the
scaling up of affordable housing production in Iraq. Developing an affordable housing program entails many
interlinking factors, levels of government, and various sectors, and can be a tremendously intricate undertaking.
Housing programmes must consider the options available to finance a project which often winds up in a complexity
of layers involving both private and public capital as well as a mix of sources including loans, grants, and subsidies
and at distinct stages of the development process including – preconstruction, construction, and ongoing operations
and maintenance. Additionally, the level of subsidy required needs careful consideration; typically, the lower the
income group served, the deeper the required subsidy. Many good international examples exist of housing finance
models that make housing projects financially feasible while also maximizing government resources. This output will
engage international and national finance experts to develop new affordable housing finance models that are
feasible in the Iraqi context taking into strong consideration the country’s underdeveloped financial institutions and
the lacking capacity to deliver innovative lending models.
Developing new financial tools in Iraq will require a nuanced understanding of the interplay between public and
private sector actors in the delivery of housing and serviced land, and the underlying financing options available or
that can be made available. Considerations for the most appropriate interventions, subsidy and financing
requirements, target beneficiaries, type of housing stock, location, and tenure type must also be carefully weighed
for appropriateness to the local context and the specific challenges new financing tools are aiming to address. The
design and delivery of new finance mechanisms will be contingent upon sufficient assessment of the many interlaced

43
factors that need consideration, such as, capacity, goals, impact, time and cost effectiveness, and resources (budget,
revenue streams and labour force) which will all be carefully weighed when determining which financial models are
best to pursue. Considerations will be made as to how private sector finance can be better leveraged with limited
government resources while still offering attractive investment potential, and that also aligns with broader
affordable housing goals. This output aims to convene housing finance experts to develop such new mechanisms
and will deliver concrete financial scenarios for consideration by the GOI.
UN-Habitat will contract with an international Housing Finance Expert to provide the necessary technical assistance
in achieving this output. Output components will include:
1. An assessment of Iraq’s current affordable housing finance models
2. An international case study report. 3-4 case studies will be selected that are most applicable to Iraqi
financial context.
3. A technical report proposing new financial mechanisms- which includes 2-4 new financial models that could
be considered by the GOI and financial institutions to support the production and delivery of affordable
housing in Iraq.
This output will include these three technical reports which will be consolidated into one final submission.
Activities Narrative:
Activity 2.3.1: Assessment of government investment in all housing initiatives including sources and uses of funds,
status and evaluation of program effectiveness and results, stakeholder involvement, capacity gaps etc.
UN-Habitat’s project staff and International Housing Finance consultant, in close collaboration with the Ministry of
Construction and Housing (MoCH), and with support from government-sponsored financial institutions, including
the National Investment Commission, National Housing Fund, and Real Estate Bank, will undertake a comprehensive
analysis of the government's financial commitments to housing programs, focusing on various aspects including:
- Government sponsored housing programmes: identification of housing initiatives supported by the GOI
including responsible administrative entities.
- Sources and uses of public funds: an examination of the sources and allocation of finances dedicated to
housing initiatives.
- Target beneficiaries: identification of the intended beneficiaries various housing programs, paying
particular attention to low-income and vulnerable groups such as women, internally displaced persons
(IDPs), and other vulnerable populations.
- Program status and effectiveness: the current status and effectiveness of these housing programs, aiming
to understand their impact and outcomes, and identifying areas in need of improvement.
- Capacity gaps: identification of gaps in the capacity of institutions responsible for administering housing
programs.
- Finance or completion gaps: identification of any barriers that may hinder the effective provision of
financing or completion of housing projects in particular affordable housing.
- Equity and Inclusion: evaluation of the extent to which Iraq’s housing programs promote equity and
inclusion, particularly concerning women, IDPs, and other vulnerable populations.
The research will also incorporate the identification of legislative and regulatory barriers to affordable housing
finance, as outlined in Output 2.2. The findings will provide the foundation for the development of new financial
models aimed at enhancing affordable and equitable housing solutions in Iraq.

44
Activity 2.3.2: Consultations with key financial stakeholders to determine both bottlenecks and opportunities for
affordable housing investment.
UN-Habitat, in coordination with MOCH, will engage in consultations with a range of housing finance experts.
Consultation will encompass domestic developers, investors, government and private financial institutions,
contractors, state-owned enterprises (SOEs), investment commissions, as well as relevant Ministries and local
authorities. The overarching goal of these consultations is to discern and delineate both impediments and
opportunities for investment in affordable housing, and to support the development of new finance mechanisms.
Where appropriate, UN-Habitat will coordinate these consultations with the International Trade Centre (ITC) and
the International Labour Organization (ILO).
To further facilitate the development of innovative financial models applicable within the Iraqi context, a dedicated
technical working group will also be convened. Comprising both national and international experts in housing
finance, this group will convene as needed, with a minimum of three meetings during the output process. The
purpose of the working group is to collaboratively avail new financial models feasible in the Iraqi context and validate
the recommendations. In situations where international engagement through a technical working group format
faces logistical challenges such as varying time zones and schedules, alternative means will be explored. These may
include bilateral discussions or other formats designed to solicit expert input. The participation of 3 to 5 international
experts is envisioned.
Activity 2.3.3: Develop housing finance international best practice case studies.
UN-Habitat’s international Housing Finance Expert consultant with support from UN-Habitat project and HQ staff
will devise 3-4 international best practice case studies on innovative housing finance in countries similar to the Iraqi
context. The selected case studies will provide a thorough analysis of successful housing finance models developed
through Government initiatives in countries most relevant to the Iraqi context. The case studies will include the
details on the financial model (sources, uses, etc.), details on the housing types, tenure, populations the affordable
housing supports, examples of successful housing developments, the preconditions for success, and lessons learned.
Criteria for case study selection will be detailed and devised in coordination with the MoCH. Selection criteria will
include factors such as replicability, suitability, scalability, similarities in investment climates, maturity in banking
sectors, affordable housing deficit, and more. Case study findings will be presented to the technical working group
and other stakeholder groups as a basis for discussion, reflection, and weighing the suitability of potential new
models for Iraq.
Activity 2.3.4: Development of new affordable housing financing mechanisms applicable to the Iraqi context.
UN-Habitat’s Housing Finance Expert consultant with support from project staff and HQ housing experts and in
coordination with MOCH, will compile a technical report detailing 3-4 new financial models that the GOI could
consider pursuing that would support scaling the production and delivery of affordable housing. These newly
developed housing finance models will aim to maximize limited government resources while maximizing societal
impact which can take various forms and employ a variety of policy strategies (supply vs. demand, renovation vs.
new build, owner vs renter, single-family vs. multi-family, etc.). The aim of the new finance models will be to increase
access to adequate and affordable housing for low-income and other vulnerable population in Iraq. The proposed
financing mechanisms will be peer reviewed and validated through MOCH, the technical working group and other
key stakeholders. The technical report will also provide additional details and supplemental information on key
considerations for building a successful affordable housing program in Iraq. This can be supported by UN-Habitat
research on affordable housing conducted in 2023 (not published) for the European Union.
UN-Habitat in coordination with MOCH will present the newly developed finance mechanisms from the findings of
the study to pertinent stakeholder groups – particularly those that can support in seeing the tools come to fruition
including potential investors and housing developers.
Activity 2.3.5: Provide technical support and recommendations to GOI in developing and deploying feasible
affordable housing finance models (utilizing both private and public finance including direct and indirect finance).

45
The UN-Habitat Housing Finance expert and project staff will then provide technical assistance to MOCH and other
applicable ministries to build out the finance tools and specifications of their choosing to further pursue and to
engage with financial institutions and investors to discuss next steps. This activity will be pursued assuming MOCH’s
willingness and commitment to invest in new affordable housing programmes. In this case, UN-Habitat will support
in building the programmatic and technical aspects of the newly designed housing program, including further
support with refinement of the finance aspects.
Output 2.4: Expanded local planning capacity in coordination with local government and key local representatives
in two neighbourhoods selected for pilot project.
Output 2.4 will involve supporting building housing planning capacity at the local government level through the
development of participatory neighbourhood plans in the two communities as a precursor to the housing
construction (Output 2.5). The technical support will provide hands-on learning opportunities from UN-Habitat
experts to guide government counterparts through sustainable development planning processes. The planning
process will cover multiple aspects of housing planning that together, will produce one comprehensive
neighbourhood plan for each housing pilot project location.
The neighbourhood planning processes involve creating profiles to comprehensively understand the physical and
social dynamics of the areas where the new housing will be constructed. They will provide a contextual snapshot of
the area utilizing both visual tools as well as available data. Neighbourhood profiles can facilitate decision making
through providing the evidence-base. For example, neighbourhood profiles will provide geographical context as to
where assets and services such as where employment centres, healthcare facilities, schools, and public space are
located within the vicinity. During this phase, local housing staff will be supported by UN-Habitat planning experts
to articulate the profile through narratives and visuals such as GIS maps and Sketchup renderings.
The plan processes will also involve engaging in a participatory planning process to produce a neighbourhood plan
that reflects the vision of the community. Through workshops and active dialogue, neighbourhood representatives
will provide the guidance for developing the plan’s vision and articulation of the community’s priorities. The plan
will entail a holistic approach to future development that integrates the community’s vision and cultural context
with internationally recognized sustainability planning principles such as: compact development principles, public
space standards, street and sidewalk guidelines, environmental sustainability principles. During this phase,
government housing staff will be supported by UN-Habitats urban planners and designers to develop renderings and
graphics that reflect the community’s vision for the future, as well as the specific site plans for the planned
development. UN-Habitat will contract an urban planning and design consultancy and national GIS and information
consultant to support UN-Habitat project staff with neighbourhood planning activities. It is the intent of this output
to build the planning capacity of local urban planning and housing staff through hands-on technical support and
knowledge exchange from UN-Habitat. Local staff involved in the planning efforts will be selected through MOCH
and the Housing Directorates in coordination with UN-Habitat. Through technical assistance from UN-Habitat, these
local staff members will learn the steps involved in creating sustainable and liveable communities and the
fundamentals of urban planning international best practice. To the extent possible, UN-Habitat staff will workwith
local planning staff in the two pilot locations to support hands-on training and learning.
The different elements of area-based planning that local government staff will gain exposure to and receive technical
assistance, include:
1. Developing neighbourhood profiles: detailed profiles that cover both physical and social aspects of the
surrounding neighbourhood in which the pilot housing units are to be developed.
2. Designing participatory planning processes: this activity is focused on building and equitable and inclusive
approach to planning efforts by actively engaging with community members and various stakeholder
groups. It aims to ensure that the voices and perspectives of those impacted the housing development
considered and incorporated into the decision-making process

46
3. Developing site plans/designs- the site plans will include the technical lay-out of the future housing
developments. It will include architectural and urban design elements such as: housing density and layout,
open space, sidewalk and street networks, landscaping , etc.
These activities will be compiled into two comprehensive neighbourhood plans (one for each pilot location). The
plans will help to guide the future housing developments, both in terms of design as well as in shaping program
objectives and guidelines.
Activities Narrative:
Activity 2.4.1: In collaboration with appropriate local authorities and other relevant counterparts identify site
locations in each of the two governorates for the pilot housing projects.
UN-Habitat project staff will coordinate with the appropriate Ministries, local authorities and other relevant
counterparts to identify a list of potential site locations in each of the two governorates for the pilot housing projects.
Criteria for weighing potential sites will be established and assessed on factors such as: environmental impact,
climate risk, topography conditions, proximity to transportation and amenities, surrounding future planned
development, costs and processes for acquisition, plot size, etc. Site visits with government counterparts will be
conducted on the short-listed list of plots. Once sites have been selected – UN-Habitat will proceed with working
with appropriate departments to secure the proper permissions, approvals and permits for housing development. It
is anticipated that there will be no land acquisition cost and that the government will retain land ownership but
grant development rights. This is activity is a necessary and often time consuming, precursor to neighbourhood
planning efforts.
Activity 2.4.2: Conduct consultations with key local stakeholders including local officials, businesses, CSOs, NGOs,
community members, etc.
Once the development sites are selected, UN-Habitat and government counterparts will proceed with outreach
activities to inform local stakeholders of the upcoming activities, gauge potential partnerships, and collect initial
input and local insight. Community outreach activities will be instrumental to neighbourhood planning and housing
development activities. UN-Habitat is fully committed to gaining community acceptance and utilizing local insight to
envision new neighbourhoods and housing developments that are liveable and sustainable - and directly reflect the
needs and desires of the community - which is at the core of this output.
Activity 2.4.3: In collaboration with appropriate local authorities, devise neighbourhood profiles for each pilot
area.
In collaboration with local authorities, UN-Habitat’s urban planning consultants will create neighbourhood profiles
for each pilot area. UN-Habitat staff will coordinate with local officials to identify local staff that will be responsible
for creating neighbourhood plans with technical support and hands-on training from UN-Habitat planning staff.
Working with local staff, UN-Habitat will support in building the framework and processes involved devising
neighbourhood plans. This will entail series of steps, such as:
1. Data collection from government agencies, local authorities, and other sources.
2. Interviews and questionnaires may be utilized to gain further insight from residents, community leaders,
local business or CSOs to determined community needs, concerns and aspirations.
3. Creating Visual and graphic elements including photos, maps, GIS, or renderings may be added to the
community profile to better visualize the spatial element and context of the neighbourhood concept.
4. A physical environmental assessment which entails an exercise mapping the neighbourhoods infrastructure
and assets including- road networks, local businesses, schools, transportation, public spaces, and other
amenities.

47
5. A culture assessment involves creating an understanding the social fabric which might include locations of
NGOs, charities, cultural groups, social services as well as understanding the general cultural diversity of
the neighbourhood.
Once the appropriate elements of the neighbourhood profile are determined, a roadmap for completion will be
devised with local staff. It is expected that the assigned local staff will take the initiative to complete all activities
under this output, through guidance and support provided by UN-Habitat.
Activity 2.4.4: Engage community members in a participatory planning process in two pilot locations.
Participatory planning processes for affordable housing development involve actively engaging community members
and stakeholders in decision-making, ensuring that their input and needs are considered throughout the planning
and development phases. UN-Habitat will support local government planning staff in learning the steps and methods
involved in developing an effective participatory planning approach. Each pilot project location will host a minimum
of two community meetings where participatory approaches will be applied. During the conceptualization of the
housing program, guiding principles will be devised and applied through the stakeholder engagement process which
provides the normative context for establishing the housing program. The guiding principles will establish the belief
and values that will be applied when executing the program. The participatory planning effort will also establish a
community vision and will help to inform the development of neighbourhood plans that reflects accurate cultural
and social dimensions and desires of local residents.
Activity 2.4.5: Develop site plans reflecting participatory planning input and neighbourhood profiles.
UN-Habitat's team of Urban Planning consultants, in collaboration with input from Architecture and Engineering
consultants, the Lead Engineer, Construction and Quality Control Supervisors, and project staff, will offer technical
support to local personnel in the development of site plans that align with international sustainability standards. Site
designs are foundational to the development of new housing projects, serving as the blueprint that dictates land
utilization, organization, and development.
The initial phase of the site design process involves the creation of conceptual designs, which strategically allocate
spaces for buildings, commercial zones, public amenities, and green areas. These site plans will comprehensively
incorporate environmental design considerations, encompassing factors such as building orientation, population
density, green spaces, and various climate mitigation measures, as well as initiatives for environmental protection
and conservation.
To enhance visualization and understanding, these conceptual designs will be transformed into visual
representations of the sites. This will be achieved using visualization software, such as SketchUp, AutoCAD, and GIS,
enabling the creation of renderings and maps that illustrate the site's layout and features.
Adaptations in the level of technical assistance provided will be contingent upon the skill levels of the local
government housing staff. In some instances, UN-Habitat may take the lead in generating the visual components of
the site plan, all the while ensuring that local staff are exposed to these tools and provided with hands-on learning
opportunities. This approach aims to create site plans that reflect international sustainable development principles
while simultaneously bolstering the capacity-building of public sector housing professionals.
Activity 2.4.6: Compile and disseminate comprehensive neighbourhood plans in two pilot locations.
In partnership with MOCH and local authorities, UN-Habitat staff and Urban Planning consultant, will compile the
plan components into consolidated neighbourhood plans for each pilot location. These plans will encompass various
components of the aforementioned activities conducted in collaboration with local planning staff, which includes
the neighbourhood profiles, the site plans for the new pilot neighbourhoods and the community vision which reflects
the inputs from community members and other stakeholders engaged in the participatory planning processes. The
plans will be openly shared and promoted with community members and stakeholder groups via print copies and
social media channels. Ultimately the plans will serve as the guiding framework for the design and realization of the
future housing developments. The plans will also serve as a model for future sustainable neighbourhood planning
activities throughout Iraq.

48
Activity 2.4.7: Determine and finalize policy aims and programmatic guidelines for housing pilot projects based on
neighbourhood plan(s) findings and recommendations.
During this phase, UN-Habitat in consultation with MOCH, Housing Directorates, and local authorities will develop
the precise program details for the two upcoming housing developments. This entails adopting an area-based
approach to discern the most suitable interventions, which encompasses subsidy and financing requirements, target
beneficiary identification, rent setting mechanisms, and tenure types. These considerations will be evaluated for
their appropriateness within the local context and with regard to the specific challenges the program aims to
address.
Furthermore, the program's design and implementation will encompass a comprehensive assessment of numerous
interconnected factors. These factors include capacity assessment, strategic goals, anticipated impacts, time and
cost-effectiveness, as well as resource allocation considerations such as budgetary constraints, revenue streams,
and available labor force. All of these elements will be carefully weighed when formulating the program's objectives
and establishing the guidelines for the pilot housing units.
Output 2.5: Increased availability of multi-story green affordable housing units including basic infrastructure
(roads, water, sanitation and hygiene facilities and electricity) for communities in two Iraqi governorates.
In output 2.5, UN-Habitat in partnership with the GOI will deliver a proof of concept that green social housing in Iraq
is a viable means to address the housing deficit for low-income and vulnerable populations. The activities will entail
a partnership approach with all levels of government, to pilot a total of 200 social housing units in two governorates
(100 each). The pilot project will demonstrate sustainable development principles in Iraq through the construction
of compact (2-3 stories) development which utilizes land more efficiently and is less taxing on infrastructure. In
partnership with ILO and ITC these activities will integrate PEIP job creation in the housing and infrastructure
construction activities and support in building SMEs green and affordable housing competency. This output will
entail all pre-development, development and offtake activities including processes such as determining the financing
mechanism (and risk sharing), rent setting, beneficiary selection, resident participation plans, and ongoing
operations and maintenance.
Housing designs will consider the local climate context and will utilize sustainable building materials, to the extent
possible. With support from ITC, this output will entail extensive research on available sustainable building materials
and cost-effective energy efficient and renewable measure that will be incorporated in the housing units that
ultimately results in quantifiable greenhouse gas reductions. The project will prepare a comparative assessment on
the various possible approaches to maximize building performance, including factors such as the overall value
proposition, lifecycle assessments, the availability of materials, transportation costs, and availability of skilled
workers, while carefully weighing the assumptions and potential risks involved with each measure. Working with
sustainable design experts, the housing will incorporate all feasible green measures including design, materials and
appliances.
This output intends to serve as a test bed for new and innovative approaches to green housing in Iraq and to serve
as a centrepiece for building environmental awareness at the community level. Throughout the activities detailed
below, UN-Habitat will collaborate closely with local government staff who are involved in housing planning, to build
local capacity in activities related to undergoing housing construction projects.
Activities Narrative:
Activity 2.5.1: Conduct detailed site surveys on the pre-identified pilot housing site locations.
UN-Habitat’s Lead Engineer in coordination with construction & QC supervisors and other project staff to conduct
detailed site surveys on the pre-identified pilot housing site locations to understand the topography, soil conditions,
