environmental factors and any hazards or limitations. The findings from the site surveys will inform the final site
layout, determining building orientation, and influencing the architectural design of the housing units. The site
assessment will also inform the requisite site preparation activities and foundation design.

49
To ensure all parties involved in the project are well-informed about the site’s particulars, the site assessments will
be done in coordination with local authorities. The collaborative approach will ensure a shared understanding of the
site's characteristics and ensure effective project planning and execution. If required, an environmental impact
assessment will also be conducted.
Activity 2.5.2: Partner with engineers and architects to develop building designs and models most suitable in each
climatic context aimed at improving climate resilience, adaptation and mitigation standards for each of the three
regions including selected building materials, building orientation, vernacular architectural elements etc.
Contract with engineers and architects to develop building designs and models most tailored to the climatic
conditions of each region. The primary objective is to ensure that these designs aling with climate resilience,
adaptation, and mitigation objectives. This entails factors such as the selection of appropriate building materials,
strategic building orientation, and incorporation of vernacular architectural elements. The tendering of contractor
services with input from ITC will be integral to achieving desired results and in achieving project integration.
This activity will also include conducting extensive research on the availability of energy-savings measures that are
available (or can become available) in the Iraqi marketplace. The research will include an assessment of the expected
environmental benefits such as ghg reductions. The research approach will employ life cycle assessments to evaluate
returns on investment and the potential for utility cost savings. A comparative analysis will be devised to identify
the most suitable and cost-effective "green" measures for each project location, prioritizing the best value
proposition.
This activity will also incorporate a gender analysis gender analysis of risk, need, demand, barriers, and supply on
proposed adaptation and mitigation strategies (GAP III). The selection of building materials and energy measures
will be done with input with ITC.
The selection of building materials and energy-saving measures will be conducted in consultation with ITC, tapping
into their expertise and ensuring an integrated approach to project decision-making.
Activity 2.5.3: Undertake pre-construction activities for the construction of social housing units.
UN-Habitat’s Lead Engineers and Construction and Quality Control Supervisors and project staff will be responsible
for pre-construction activities in close coordination with MOCH and local authorities. Installation of infrastructure
and basic services will be contracted out through a competitive bid process. A number discreet steps are included in
the preconstruction phase of housing development which include:
o Permits and Approvals: in coordination with local authorities, obtain all necessary permits and approvals
for each of the (2) targeted governorates ensuring compliance with local building codes, zoning and other
regulations.
o Site plans: Finalize detailed site plans and multi-story (2-3) building designs
o Finance: Develop pro-forma – determine sources and uses of funds for housing developments (including
investments and subsidies) and secure financing. Develop a comprehensive budget including construction
costs, materials and labour expenses, and contingencies. Secure additional project financing (if applicable)
and establish financial arrangements – contracts and agreements.
o BOQ: Develop a Bill of Quantities (BoQ) for construction of affordable housing units and construction of
basic infrastructure are developed. A detailed project schedule will also be devised for all construction
activities.
o Contractor Tendering: Tender applicable construction and/or engineering services through a competitive
bid process and select qualified contractors. Contractors will be selected with input from ITC and ILO to
ensure project integration.

50
o Site preparation: in coordination with local authorities clearance of construction site and installation of
infrastructure and basic services including roads, water, sanitation and hygiene facilities and electricity and
public facilities on each site location.
Activity 2.5.4: Construct 200 multi-story affordable green social housing units in compact neighbourhoods (100
per pilot location).
UN-Habitat’s Lead Engineers and Construction & QC Supervisors will be responsible for oversite of all construction
activities conducted by housing construction contractors who will be contracted through a competitive bid process.
Throughout the construction activities, UN-Habitat staff will effectively collaborate with contractors, subcontractors,
and skilled laborers to ensure that the housing development is constructed efficiently, safely, and in accordance with
the design and quality standards. Effective project management and communication are essential to the successful
completion of the housing development. This activity will entail constructing 100 multi-story (2-3 story) green social
housing units on each of the two sites. Discreet steps under construction activities include:
o Foundation construction: construct foundations based on architectural and engineering plans
o Framing of building (2-3) story – framing includes erection of walls, floors, and roof structures. Framing
materials will be selected in close consideration of availability of local building materials, durability of
materials, and environmental considerations
o Utility installation: Plumbing, electrical, HVAC, energy savings appliances (renewables and efficiency). This
step includes pipework, wiring, and ductwork.
o Exterior: roofing, siding, insulation, and windows
o Interior work: walls are framed and insulation is installed. Drywall or other finished are applied and windows
and doors are installed
o Quality Control, Safety and Inspections: Regular inspections are conducted to ensure that construction
meets safety and quality standards. Safety precautions, including barricades, signage, and protective gear,
are in place to protect workers and site visitors. Compliance with occupational safety regulations is critical.
Final inspections by local building authorities are carried out to verify compliance with all relevant codes
and regulations. Permits are issued for occupancy once the project passes inspection.
o Unit off-take according to pre-defined tenure type, beneficiary selection process and beneficiary placement
support
o Ongoing maintenance and operation plan: Determine ongoing maintenance needs and commensurate
funding streams (tender property mgmt., if applicable).
Activity 2.5.5: Develop ongoing beneficiary participation and resident services plan.
This activity entails the development of a comprehensive Housing Beneficiary Participation and Engagement Plan.
This structured process is designed to guarantee the inclusion of the voices, needs, and concerns of the housing
beneficiaries within the framework of the housing project(s). The overarching goal of the engagement plan is to
ensure that the perspectives of those poised to benefit from the housing units are not only acknowledged but
actively incorporated into the project's ongoing operations and activities.
UN-Habitat project staff in coordination with local government housing staff will undertake the task of formulating
beneficiary engagement plan, ultimately fostering housing projects that are community-driven and responsive to
local needs. The plan will be developed with resident input and engagement through interactive dialogue such as
workshops, interviews, and/ or focus groups. The plan will serve as the foundational structure for sustaining resident
participation in decision-making processes over time.
The plan will delineate the mechanisms through which direct beneficiaries of the housing units can continue to
actively participate in decision-making processes. This may encompass the establishment of tenant councils,

51
facilitating resident to identify additional supportive services they require, or involving them in the programming of
community events and dialogues. The plan will aim to building inclusive and people-centered communities, ensuring
that the diverse voices within the community are not only heard but valued in shaping the trajectory of the housing
projects.
Activity 2.5.6: Unit off-take according to pre-defined programme guidelines
After the construction of the housing units, a structured process for allocating these units to housing beneficiaries
will be put into action. This responsibility falls under the purview of UN-Habitat in collaboration with the Ministry of
Construction and Housing (MOCH), which will be tasked with creating all the necessary procedural documents.
The offtake procedure encompasses several key elements, beginning with the determination of beneficiary eligibility
through the formulation of a comprehensive beneficiary selection criteria. This criterion will encompass evaluating
income requirements and establishing a system for prioritizing specific target populations.
Prospective applicants will be required to navigate an application process, including income verification, as well as
an interview and screening phase. The notification of housing availability and the call for applicants will receive
support from local NGOs, MOCH, Housing Directorates, and local officials.
Furthermore, the beneficiary selection process will entail the development of waitlist policies and procedures. Once
beneficiaries are selected, they will proceed to sign a lease agreement, and they will be expected to adhere to
residency and compliance rules and regulations. Throughout the entire process, UN-Habitat will be responsible for
the selection and placement of beneficiaries, working within the established mechanisms to ensure a fair and
transparent allocation of the housing units.
Output 2.6: Increased awareness of housing environmental footprint and urban policies
In this output UN-Habitat intends to utilize one model unit in each of the pilot areas to serve as “Centres for Green
Technology”. The facilities will be established to serve as community environmental resource facilities and as
regional training hubs for ongoing environmental awareness activities including demonstrating the green
technologies incorporated into the housing units, training programs for a variety of stakeholder groups, and ongoing
awareness raising activities among the communities. These activities will be developed in coordination with ILO and
ITC so that the facilities can host a variety of green related trainings, workshops and seminars related to the joint
aspirations of the project. Indicative activities include:
o Public awareness campaigns, trainings, and exhibitions for community members on topics such as: disaster
risk reduction, environmental conservation and energy reduction measures that can be realized at the
household and community level, water conservation and recycling.
o Exhibitions for professionals and community members that showcase sustainable building materials, energy
efficient and renewable technologies, in particular, technologies are utilized in pilot homes.
o Environmental awareness workshops to CSO’s, trade organizations and other key stakeholder groups.
o Technical green building and sustainable housing development trainings (code enforcement, procurement,
energy standards and certifications, etc.) for government staff, SMES’s, architects, engineers, etc.
o Green jobs and skills trainings with a particular focus on developing knowledge and skills for unemployed
women, youth, and IDPs
A sustainability plan will be devised to ensure continuance of activities beyond the project duration.
Activities Narrative:
Activity 2.6.1: Construct one model unit on each project site, designed to serve a dual function as both an open
community center and a "Center for Green Technology." These units are intended to demonstrate the green
technologies employed in the housing projects and raise awareness about environmentally sustainable practices,
while also functioning as regional hubs for green training.

52
Each project site will feature a model housing unit designed to fulfill a dual role as a community center and a "Center
for Green Technology." These model units will serve as "regional green training centers" and will be strategically
positioned to showcase the sustainable technologies integrated into the housing projects, fostering green
awareness. Further the Green Centres will promote environmental awareness through hosting events, workshops,
and various activities dedicated to sustainability and green housing.
Activity 2.6.2: Activate and utilize the 'Regional Centers for Green Technology' spaces by organizing monthly
exhibitions, lectures, demonstrations, events, and training sessions. These activities are designed to foster
environmental awareness across the private, non-profit, and public sectors, as well as at the household and
community levels.
UN-Habitat staff with local officials will take the lead in organizing environmental awareness initiatives, working in
collaboration with ILO and ITC to ensure a coordinated approach towards promoting sustainability and green
practices within the community. The green centres will host periodic exhibitions, lectures, demonstrations, events,
and trainings aimed at building environmental awareness. Activities may also be geared to hosting topic-specific
trainings aimed at professionals, businesses, non-profits, and government representatives. Importantly this space
will serve a resource centre for beneficiaries of the housing units on how to maintain, operate and maximize energy
efficient installations utilized within the housing units. and at the household and community level.
To support their functions, the centers will be staffed by community volunteers who will receive training from UN-
Habitat personnel, providing valuable job skills and capacity-building opportunities, particularly for housing
beneficiaries. Additional partners will be identified and pursued to support in providing activities, funding, and
programming.
Activity 2.6.3: Devise a sustainability plan for the "Centers for Green Technology" to ensure their continuity
beyond the project's duration.
To ensure continued operation of the Centres for Green technology beyond the project’s duration, a sustainability
plan will be developed in coordination with MoCH, other applicable Ministries, and local officials. The sustainability
plan will serve to identify new funding streams, project sponsors, and ongoing building operations and management,
including programmatic activities.
The development of the sustainability plan will be a collaborative effort, guided by UN-Habitat project staff, with
input from the donor, government counterparts, and project partners ILO and ITC. The primary aim of the plan is to
ensure appropriate levels of funding can be secured to keep the centres operational well into the future. This
approach seeks to ensure the long-term viability of the centers and their positive impact on the community.
Fundraising plans and activities will begin prior to inauguration of the green centres to ensure solvency and to
maximize additional potential resources to support activities.
If securing long-term funding is not possible, contingency plans will be explored, which may involve transitioning the
units into social housing units to ensure their continued use and benefit to the community.
4.5 RESULTS CHAIN OUTCOME THREE
4.5.1 OUTCOME THREE: INTERVENTION LOGIC
If the partnership between Iraqi public and private stakeholders to designing and implementing a green sustainable
construction sector development strategy will is strengthened (Op. 3.1); if opportunities and capacities of value
chain actors for private sector-led affordable, quality construction and climate-adaptive buildings retrofit are
improved (Op. 3.2); if the capacities of local businesses, particularly young entrepreneurs, for the integration of
green and innovative practices in their operation are enhanced (Op. 3.3); if the regulatory and legal framework for
access to and provision of construction and housing services in Iraq is improved and the related potential for reform
is in line with the broader trade policy reform led by the GoI (Op. 3.4); and, if the awareness and capacities of public
and private stakeholders of the regulatory and procedural framework for investing in the housing and construction
sectors and potential for reform are also enhanced (Op. 3.5), then the business environment and participation of

53
local MSMEs and investors in the construction sector will be improved (Oc. 3), as long as access to primary and/or
secondary data is sufficient; an adequate level of transparency exists in the supply chain; the collaboration and
coordination among policy makers is sufficient and so is the absorption capacity of beneficiaries, ministries and
agencies; sector stakeholders have the necessary maturity level and political support for developing and
implementing needed sector strategies and policies; the commitment towards the reform process from the
Government continues to hold; there is an adequate buy-in and commitment from public-private sector
stakeholders towards strategy implementation; employers are involved in the content development for the National
Quality Framework in order for it to be aligned with their needs; basic necessary skills are available to SME
owners/managers in order to be more competitive in value chains; absorption capacities of the Ministries and
agencies are sufficient.
4.5.2 OUTCOME THREE: DESCRIPTION
Improved business environment and participation of local MSMEs and investors in the construction sector.
Activities under Outcome 3 aim to address challenges in the construction sector that limit the potential contributions
of small businesses to employment generation, the creation of affordable and sustainable housing, and economic
growth and diversification. These include support for the improvement of capacities of firms, the efficiency of value
chains, and environment to access and operate in the construction and housing sectors in Iraq. Due to their
dynamism, MSMEs in particular stand to make a major contribution to the improvement of the housing sector and
will be assisted in this through project’s activities on strategy design and implementation, local organisation, and
training and capacity building. ITC’s experience in working with the private sector and other stakeholders, and
facilitating public-private collaboration on strategy design and implementation, firm-level capacity building, value
chain coordination, and trade and investment policy and regulatory reform, and trade and investment to drive
sustainable and inclusive growth will be leveraged in implementing these elements of the project. Specific attention
will be given to ensuring that safety standards and disaster resilience are promoted.
4.5.3 OUTCOME THREE: OUTPUTS AND ACTIVITIES
Output 3.1: Strengthened partnership between Iraqi public and private stakeholders to design and implement a
green sustainable construction sector development strategy.
A sustainable sector development strategy is needed to provide a solid basis for a strengthened construction sector
by setting common policy priorities and coordinating key actors. In order to maximise the impact of the strategy, the
project includes activities under Output 3.1 on value chain analysis, participatory strategy design, the establishment
or strengthening of an effective public-private sector coordination structure responsible for implementation,
technical and advisory on implementation management including monitoring and resource mobilization.
The strategy will be comprehensive in scope, addressing the development of products and services directed at
increasing productivity, promoting investment, nurturing innovation, enhancing value addition, and improving the
institutional and regulatory environment.
The strategy will address issues that constrain competitiveness and private sector development, while ensures that
developmental objectives are targeted. To this end, the strategy design process will follow an inclusive and
participative approach to ensure that all stakeholders are consulted and have ownership over the resulting strategy
and implementation plan. Women empowerment considerations will be incorporated into the analysis of challenges
and opportunities throughout the sector development strategy, highlighting the needs and priorities of women-led
MSMEs and key recommendations. To this end, women-led MSMEs and relevant public and private sector
organisations representing women in the private sector will be consulted and interviewed during the strategy design
process. Through this approach, the strategy will reflect their needs and priorities by elaborating specific and tailored
recommendations in the action plan.
Findings and recommendations from other existing endorsed plans will be integrated and further developed. A
capacity-building approach will be adopted along the process, with the aim of strengthening the capacity of national
partners to formulate, manage and implement their own strategy.

54
The project will work with stakeholders to design the detailed strategy, including a five-year plan of action, that
allocates responsibilities, and specifies timelines and targets. As a result, the Government of Iraq will own a strategy
for the construction sector that is specific and measurable to ensure well-managed implementation, accountability,
and that the desired results are achieved. These activities will be delivered directly through the project, with the
potential involvement of external experts in an advisory capacity.
Activities Narrative:
Activity 3.1.1: Define strategy design process, roles, including the focal point organization and person, and work
plan.
Define strategy design process, roles, including the focal point organization and persons, and develop a work plan.
This includes the identification and appointment of a Navigator to champion the design and delivery of the strategy
for the construction sector. The Navigator is usually respected individual, likely a senior official from the public sector
from the relevant Ministry or from the Prime Minister’s office, who is appointed to the management of the strategy
for the duration of the design process.
In collaboration with project partners, this activity would entail as well the identification (or formation) of a sector-
level coordination platform to guide the strategy design process and subsequent implementation. This coordination
mechanism will guide the process of strategy design and ultimately take responsibility for guiding its
implementation. This continuity encourages the development of realistic and useful planning for the sector’s future.
Where possible, synergies will be sought with other areas of project governance in the establishment of this
mechanism.
Activity 3.1.2: Conduct comprehensive background research on the structure and functioning of the value chain,
including in-depth quantitative and quality analysis of MSMEs’ participation in the sector, and of market access
and trends for the sector.
Conduct comprehensive background research on the structure and functioning of the construction value chain,
including an in-depth quantitative and quality analysis of MSMEs’ participation in the sector, and of market access
and trends for the sector.
This activity will build on the analysis conducted for the project development, as well as relevant assessments to be
carried out during the inception phase by all partners. This includes a comprehensive analysis of the policy
framework, to ensure alignment with the strategy and avoid potential duplications. A further identification will be
carried out of public sector, private sector, and other actors, including development partners that are directly
engaged in the housing and construction value chain and in establishing the environment in which these actors
operate.
Further assessments will include analysis of production, processing and market related data for the sector, as well
as its impact on socio-economic development. An in-depth analysis of MSME’s participation of the sector may
include a survey of firms to understand their key characteristics, challenges to compete, connect among each other
and with supporting institutions and to upgrade their practices.
A first value chain map and initial analysis that identifies major constraints and highlights the most promising
opportunities, particularly to increase MSME participation and entry points for youth participation, innovation and
sustainability of the sector will be produced. The project’s cross-cutting themes related to inclusive and sustainable
growth will be central to this research.
Expert advice may be sought here and at later stages in the strategy design process on sector research and the
development of specific activities and targets for the strategy’s plan of action.
The output will be a preliminary sector diagnostic which will be presented, discussed and refined during the first
consultation with stakeholders.
Activity 3.1.3: Consultation with sector stakeholders (public and private sector) to present, refine and validate the
sector diagnostics and propose initial solutions.

55
Stakeholders representing various aspects of the construction value chain will meet to discuss and agree on a
common vision and way forward for strengthening economic opportunities, sustainability, and housing affordability.
If possible, this will be done through a single discussion in order to foster consensus-building, though smaller group
discussions may be used with ongoing communication with participants to validate evolving conclusions. The
background research on value chain structure, challenges, and opportunities will be used to structure the
discussions, though participants will be invited to challenge these preliminary findings. The consultation aims to
achieve broad-based agreement on the vision for the strategy and main areas of work to be encompassed.
Stakeholders will be actively involved throughout the consultations which are comprised of ITC-facilitated capacity-
building and decision-making sessions.
The consultation will be highly practical and results-oriented in nature. It is deliberately structured this way so that
upon the conclusion of the consultations, material is produced that feeds directly into the Construction Strategy.
Outputs of the first consultation are as follows:
• Definition of the sector scope,
• Refining and validating the sector value chain,
• Identifying competitiveness constraints,
• Identify and discuss potential solutions to key challenges.
Activity 3.1.4: Development of a detailed plan of action for the strategy, including entry points for greater MSME
participation, closing the skills gaps, developing business models and measures to foster the adoption of
sustainable practices.
The background research and outcomes of the first stakeholder consultation will be consolidated and used in further
elaborating the strategic orientations and specific recommendations that can contribute to enhance MSME
participation and performance in the sector, as well as activities that address supply-side, business environment and
market entry issues, as well as development side challenges. These actions will be explored as responses to particular
challenges identified by sector stakeholders. Recommendations would also include entry points for greater MSME
participation, closing the skills gaps, developing business models and measures to foster the adoption of sustainable
practices.
Activity 3.1.5: Second consultation for the validation of the strategy to refine the strategic orientations and
activities of the plan of action, as well as to validate the coordination body to oversee and guide the
implementation.
The second consultation for the validation of the strategy to develop and further refine the strategic orientations
and activities of the plan of action, as well as to validate the coordination body to oversee and guide implementation.
Bringing together again the stakeholders involved in the first consultation, the second consultation will focus on the
details of the draft actions included, the inclusion of new actions, and the removal of unnecessary actions. The goal
of the second consultation is therefore to reach broad-based agreement on the structure and content of the
strategy’s plan of action. This support improves the design and its relevance to the sector, in addition to beginning
to build necessary momentum for its implementation.
The plan of action has a 5-year timeline. Since recommendations and strategic orientations are necessary but not
sufficient, the plan of action systematically highlights next steps required to implement the strategy and outlines a
timeline for implementing those steps. In addition, the Plan of Action identifies organizations responsible for
implementing the highlighted actions. Project ideas derived from the action plan deliver key entry points for
government action, private sector support and development partners. To ensure successful implementation,
outreach and donor mobilization are built into the design process.
Activity 3.1.6: Presentation of the way forward to the sector-level coordination body for validation.

56
The way forward will describe the core elements of the strategy at the level of the vision and strategic objectives,
with context on the challenges being addressed and concerns of contributing stakeholders. The validation of the way
forward by the sector-level coordination platform, confirms the general scope and priorities of the strategy, as well
as the support of the key stakeholders involved in the coordination body. This ensures that the vision is achievable
and properly aligned with relevant development initiatives.
Activity 3.1.7: Finalization and validation of Iraq’s construction sector strategy, followed by an official launch
ceremony.
Where needed, adjustments will be made to the strategy following the recommendations of the coordination body
and other relevant stakeholders in order to enhance its relevance to sector goals and to best support the effective
implementation of the strategy. The strategy will be available in English and Arabic.
To ensure the strategy mobilizes national and international support required for its implementation, the lead
ministry, with ITC’s technical support, will seek high-level endorsement. In this manner, the Plan of Action will obtain
the commitment of the government to allocate the necessary resources and responsibilities for its implementation.
The endorsement of the strategy will be followed by an official launch ceremony to ensure visibility and gain
momentum towards implementation.
Activity 3.1.8: Support to define and operationalize a public-private sector coordination structure to manage the
implementation of the strategy.
A key success criterion for success of strategy will be the country’s ability to coordinate activities, monitor progress
and mobilize resources for its implementation. To this end, the project’s support will contribute to defining and
operationalizing an adequate governance structure, e.g. sector coordination committee, to build collaboration.
Including the main organisations responsible for the plan’s actions, the sector strategy coordination body will be
established as the body responsible for overseeing the implementation process. This will include coordinating
initiatives and may require their leadership in adapting the strategy as needed and in consultation with stakeholders.
Activity 3.1.9: Capacity strengthening, including coaching to national sector coordination body and its Secretariat.
Successful implementation management of a strategy ensures that all relevant institutions and partners are enabled
to implement activities within a coherent framework. Accordingly, strategy implementation management support
focuses assisting such a framework and providing specialized tools and advice to ensure successful implementation
and monitoring of activities outlined in the Plan of Action (PoA) of the Strategy. The project’s intervention will aim
to capacitate the Secretariat of the established sector coordination structure, so as to guarantee that initiatives
implemented are aligned to the priorities of the stakeholders as defined in the strategy. Technical assistance and
capacity building will be provided as required. Tools and organisational best practices in achieving strategy
implementation will be shared with the coordination body to support tracking, resource mobilisation, sector
coordination, and management of responsibilities in the implementation process.
Output 3.2: Improved opportunities and capacities of supply chain actors for private sector-led affordable, quality
construction and climate-adaptive buildings retrofit.
Building on the findings of the strategy design process, Output 3.2 will support enhanced coordination among small
businesses in the construction sector in order to enhance their performance. The organisation of value chain actors
in MSME alliances in two governorates through the project will assist smaller firms in accessing new markets, reduce
costs and improve firm-level capacities through enhanced information sharing and economies of scale. This
cooperation will provide a model demonstrating the means and benefits of organisation. Output 3.2 activities on
organising local MSME alliances in high-potential areas, local-level planning, design and technical solutions in
construction, and organisational capacity building will provide a basis for cooperation among firms. ITC has
experience on training MSMEs on resource efficiency and circular production resulting in reduction in GHG emissions
over a multi-annual process, increased productivity, cost reduction and enhanced compliance with environmental
standards and regulations. Through the coaching programme on Resource Efficiency and Circular Production (RECP),
ITC will build the capacity of construction MSMEs to optimize the use and management of resources (water, energy,
chemicals and waste) and identify solutions to make production processes greener. The ITC RECP coaching

57
programme has been implemented in over 15 countries and 10 value chains and can be adapted to serve any
productive sector. Active collaboration and dialogue between value chain actors – including international companies
and local suppliers – is facilitated through this approach to ensure joint implementation of resource-efficient and
cleaner production practices.
Activities Narrative:
Activity 3.2.1: Climate-Smart Housing Retrofit Consumer Research, Product-Market combination, and selection of
target areas.
Building on activities under output 3.1, ITC and partners plan to conduct market research on climate-smart housing
retrofit solutions and affordable housing construction in Iraq, with a focus on energy efficiency and climate
adaptation, particularly in high-temperature environments. The research will identify options for new retrofit
products to be offered by MSMEs in the fields of energy-efficient appliances / air conditioning, water efficiency, heat
insulation, and renewable energy solutions within an affordable budget range (e.g. $5,000 - $10,000 package
including installation cost). In the same time consumers assessment will identify the most relevant areas for project
intervention while setting clear selection criteria balancing vulnerability and market requirements. Possible
partnership to serve housing fund recipients will be also explored (e.g. housing fund beneficiaries). These insights
will inform subsequent activities under outputs 3.2 and 3.3, empowering local SMEs to offer tailored, cost-effective,
and sustainable solutions to address climate challenges while fostering economic growth in the construction and
energy sectors.
Activity 3.2.2: Organize market awareness events on innovative climate-smart services and establish MSME
alliances to enhance collaboration, knowledge sharing, and collective bargaining power, strengthening the sector.
This multifaceted activity will create two local associations of construction MSMEs (“Alliances”) that will be both
connected with construction material / innovative climate-smart solution suppliers, relevant service providers (e.g
architectural design services, housing finance) and potential consumers. By creating these alliances, we aim to
provide smaller firms with a platform to collectively address challenges, share insights, and negotiate more
effectively in areas such as procurement and market access. Under this activity, steps will also be taken to stimulate
consumer demand for innovative retrofit products, encourage local Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs)
in the construction sector to invest in this evolving business model, and establish strategic connections with both
international and national construction material suppliers. These suppliers will play a pivotal role in ensuring the
availability of innovative materials at competitive prices as well as training MSMEs on the proper techniques to use
the material, respecting required standards.
Activity 3.2.3: Develop two inclusive, locally-tailored sustainable construction sector development plans,
emphasizing energy efficiency and eco-friendly practices.
ITC will actively engage local construction MSMEs and community representatives in target areas to develop
sustainable development plans. These plans will prioritize energy-efficient and eco-friendly practices through clear
goal-setting, actionable steps, and capacity-building initiatives. They will also promote respect of construction
standards, safety and disaster resilience. We will identify specific needs for training and material support through
comprehensive needs assessments. Ongoing monitoring and documentation will ensure adaptability and provide
valuable insights for the construction sector's long-term sustainability in these areas. These plans will be aligned with
the national strategy devised under 3.1 and will support its implementation locally.
Activity 3.2.4: Definition of the technical designs for the climate-adaptive retrofit products and associated quality
standards and certification processes in partnership with government and private sector.
The implementation of this activity involves a collaborative effort bringing together local and international
architects, builders, material suppliers, academia, government, and other stakeholders. This collective initiative will
build on the market opportunities and possible options identified under 3.2.1 to develop climate-smart and cost-
effective technical designs and packages tailored for Iraqi Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) to retrofit
existing buildings. These designs may encompass various sustainability elements, including enhanced insulation,
energy efficiency, sealing, shade structures, natural ventilation, reflective painting, cool roofing, and solar energy

58
solutions. The goal is to create standardized and pre-agreed fixed-cost packages making sustainable retrofitting
accessible and affordable for MSMEs while addressing climate challenges. To ensure technical quality, the initiative
includes the establishment of rigorous standards, certifications, checklists, and validation processes.
Activity 3.2.5: Creation of an incentive program and social marketing for the adoption of the climate adaptation
retrofit packages by consumers.
More than 200 households are set to benefit from climate-adaptive housing retrofit packages delivered by MSME
members of the Alliances, showcasing their tangible value and the economic returns achieved through energy
efficiency savings. To encourage early adoption and utilize these initial households as model homes to convince
neighbours, we will introduce an incentive program covering 50% of the retrofit costs for the first 50 families in each
area during the first year. This incentive will gradually decrease to 25% in the second year and will be phased out
entirely after year three. Additionally, specific marketing efforts will be deployed to raise awareness, generate
interest, and demonstrate the economic returns of this sustainable investment to the broader community.
Activity 3.2.6: Support to commercial delivery of the housing retrofit packages by local Alliance MSMEs building
on capacity strengthening effort under output 3.3 and quality insurance and certification mechanisms set under
activity 3.2.4.
This activity focuses on providing comprehensive support to the commercial delivery of housing retrofit packages by
local Alliance Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs). Building upon the capacity strengthening efforts
outlined in Output 3.3 and guided by the quality assurance and certification mechanisms established in Activity 3.2.4,
this activity ensures that trained MSMEs and young entrepreneurs possess the necessary skills to proficiently
implement the retrofit packages developed under Activity 3.2.4. Collaborative partnerships with material suppliers
are integral, facilitating the exchange of expertise and technical standards required for effective package installation.
Additionally, a robust certification mechanism, a product of Activity 3.2.4, guarantees that only certified installers
are engaged and that external verification maintains the quality of installation at the highest standards. This
coordinated approach reinforces the successful and reliable commercial delivery of housing retrofit solutions while
bolstering the capacity of local enterprises and entrepreneurs.
Output 3.3: Strengthened capacities of local businesses, particularly young entrepreneurs, for the integration of
green and innovative practices in their operation.
Output 3.3 of the project focuses on strengthening the capacity of local businesses, with a particular emphasis on
young entrepreneurs, to incorporate green and innovative practices into their operations. This output recognizes
the importance of enhancing the skills and knowledge of entrepreneurs to drive sustainability and innovation within
the local business landscape. Here are some key points and strategies outlined in this output:
The project acknowledges that small businesses, especially micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs),
are vital components of the local economy. Therefore, efforts will be directed towards these businesses to help them
build capacity in sustainable and innovative practices with a specific focus on youth.
To achieve the desired outcomes, the project will work on reinforcing the portfolio of business development service
providers. These providers will offer training, coaching, and mentoring services to young entrepreneurs and small
businesses particularly in areas such as climate smart solutions, and innovative construction technology, among
others. An important aspect of this output is the exposure to good practices from peers. This learning from both
institutional and company-level peers can be invaluable in helping entrepreneurs understand and implement
sustainable and innovative practices effectively. The project will ensure a close look at reaching out to relevant
partners. The project recognizes the role of youth in economic empowerment and job creation. It aims to not only
support new entrepreneurs but also provide existing MSMEs with the necessary skills to grow. This involves
collaboration with sector stakeholders and Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) providers.
To stay relevant and meet the evolving demands of the market, the project will focus on better aligning current TVET
programs with the specific needs of businesses. This ensures that the training provided is practical and directly
applicable to the industry and the value chain analysis will feed this process.

59
Collaboration and partnerships will be key to the success of this output. These partnerships may involve recognized
multinational corporations, training institutions, and other industry stakeholders. Such collaborations can facilitate
knowledge transfer, keep pace with market changes, and help build skills that align with the identified value chains.
Activities Narrative:
Activity 3.3.1: Design and implement short modular competency-based trainings for professionals on new
affordable house construction, repairs, resource efficiency, financial literacy.
This activity is focused on designing and implementing short modular competency-based training programs for
professionals in the areas of new affordable house construction, repairs, resource efficiency, and financial literacy.
This activity aims to provide targeted and practical training to professionals, equipping them with the knowledge
and skills needed for sustainable and innovative practices in these areas. The first step in this activity involves
identifying key stakeholders who will be involved in the design and implementation of the training programs. These
stakeholders may include experts in energy efficiency, construction, repair, and financial literacy, as well as
representatives from relevant institutions and organizations. Focus group discussions will be conducted to gather
insights and inputs from professionals to shape the content of such training. Based on the insights gained from focus
group discussions and in collaboration with key stakeholders, the project will co-design the training modules. That
could cover various topics, such as: new affordable house construction techniques that emphasize sustainability and
resource efficiency; repair and maintenance practices that reduce environmental impact; strategies for improving
resource efficiency in construction and repair projects; Financial literacy modules. Training modules on financial
literacy may be customized based on existing materials or resources, or they can be developed in collaboration with
relevant partners who specialize in financial education. The roll out of these materials will have an objective of 200
users.
Activity 3.3.2: Develop partnerships with construction material supplier, universities, and innovators to
mainstream climate smart solutions in Iraq.
This activity focuses on the development of strategic partnerships with various stakeholders to promote and
mainstream climate-smart solutions in Iraq's construction sector. This activity recognizes the importance of
collaboration with key players in the value chain to drive sustainability and innovation. The first step in this activity
is to engage with relevant stakeholders in the construction and housing sector that were already identified as part
of the value chain analysis. These stakeholders may include construction material suppliers, universities, innovators,
and other organizations that play a role in the value chain. Once key stakeholders are identified, the project will
work on establishing partnerships with them. These partnerships can take various forms, including: sharing of
educational resources related to climate-smart solutions and sustainable construction practices; access to cutting-
edge technologies, materials, and solutions that promote sustainability in construction. Collaboration with
universities or incubators can involve supporting research and innovation projects related to climate-smart
construction solutions. In addition to partnerships with stakeholders directly involved in the construction sector, this
activity may extend collaboration to Financial Service Providers (FSPs) at the national or international levels. Building
and maintaining strong partnerships is an ongoing process. The project will focus on nurturing these relationships,
fostering collaboration, and ensuring that the partnerships remain productive and mutually beneficial over time.
Activity 3.3.3: Co-establish pilot training sites and model houses using innovative affordable green techniques in
collaboration with UN-Habitat
ITC will collaborate with UN-Habitat (under Output 2.6) to establish pilot training sites and model houses. This
activity will showcase innovative and affordable green techniques. These sites serve as practical learning
environments and examples for students, professionals, and the community at large. The project will collaborate
closely with a range of stakeholders, including locally established vocational training centers, private sector partners,
universities, incubators, practitioners, and relevant government ministries. The objective of this multi stakeholder
engagement is to create physical spaces where innovative and affordable green techniques are put into practice.
These pilot training sites and model houses will serve as living examples of sustainable construction and design. The
project team, in consultation with experts and stakeholders, will select specific green techniques and practices that
align with the project's goals. These techniques may include energy-efficient building methods, sustainable

60
materials, renewable energy integration, waste reduction, and water conservation, among others. Physical locations
for the pilot training sites and model houses will be identified and secured. The pilot training sites will serve as hands-
on learning environments for students and professionals. Training programs and educational activities will be
conducted on-site to demonstrate and teach the application of green techniques. This can include workshops,
seminars, and practical demonstrations. The model houses and pilot sites will act as showcases for innovative and
affordable green solutions. They will demonstrate the feasibility and benefits of these techniques, encouraging
broader adoption within the construction industry and community.
Activity 3.3.4: Strengthen the capacities of key support organizations working with MSMEs particularly youth-led
companies with new services particularly in entrepreneurship and financial literacy.
Activity 3.3.4 focuses on strengthening the capacities of key support organizations that work with Micro, Small, and
Medium Enterprises (MSMEs), particularly those led by young entrepreneurs. This activity aims to provide these
support organizations with the necessary tools and resources to offer new and improved services, with a specific
focus on entrepreneurship and financial literacy. Here's a breakdown of the key components of this activity: Support
will be provided to selected organizations to enhance their operational and service delivery capacities in the above-
mentioned areas. These services may include mentoring and coaching for young entrepreneurs, workshops on
business planning and management, access to financial education, and assistance in securing financing. Efforts will
be made to foster collaboration and synergies among different support institutions. This ensures complementarity
and shared efforts in supporting the competitiveness of the value chain and promoting entrepreneurship and
climate-smart solutions. Collaboration may involve joint initiatives, knowledge sharing, and resource pooling.
Activity 3.3.5: In collaboration with local alliances create a system of certified trainees, a repository, regular
networking events, and associated marketing.
This activity aims at establishing a system to certify trainees, create a repository of resources, organize regular
networking events, and implement associated marketing efforts in collaboration with local alliances. This activity is
crucial for sustaining and expanding the impact of the project's efforts to strengthen the capacity of local businesses,
especially young entrepreneurs, in integrating green and innovative practices into their operations. This component
involves setting up a certification process for individuals who have completed the training and capacity-building
programs offered as part of the project. A repository or database will be created to store training materials, guides,
manuals, case studies, and other resources related to green and innovative practices. This repository will serve as a
valuable knowledge base for trainees, professionals, and entrepreneurs seeking information and guidance. Effective
marketing efforts will be put in place to promote the project's activities, training programs, and networking events.
Marketing strategies may include digital and traditional marketing channels, outreach to local media, and leveraging
partnerships with local alliances to reach a wider audience.
Output 3.4: Improved regulatory and legal framework for access to and provision of construction and housing
services in Iraq.
An enabling framework for service providers (businesses and investors) to engage in construction and housing
services in Iraq has the potential to contribute to improvements in housing affordability and sustainability, including
through the more active involvement of MSMEs in these sectors.
Access to construction and housing services and effective functioning of such service providers is instrumental to
addressing Iraq’s housing crisis. Increasing opportunities for service providers in this sector to operate in Iraq and
the functioning of various service providers in this space would allow for a more competitive sector – thus creating
the impetus for better quality and competitively priced services within the housing and construction sector in Iraq.
A preliminary assessment revealed restrictions in the ability of service providers in this sector to operate across the
modes of supply of services (i.e. the four modes through which services are traded: Cross-border trade – Mode 1;
Consumption abroad - Mode 2; Commercial presence – Mode 3; and Temporary movement of natural persons –
Mode 4). Restrictions were identification in the context of the setting up a commercial presence in the country,
accessing services abroad, and bringing in foreign labour/skills needed for these services. Among others, regulatory
challenges identified include the disjunct between the legal framework and practical implementation creating space

61
for uneven implementation of laws and informal mechanisms; restrictions in foreign participation in the sector,
ability for foreign ownership of land, and the lack of harmonization and coordination of procurement practices.
Activities to strengthen the regulatory and legal framework on market access for construction and housing services
in the country under Output 3.4 will assist with policy mapping, analysis and planning, dialogue and implementation
through targeted capacity building and the organisation of suitable platforms for discussion and coordination. Across
these activities, the sharing of international expertise and best practices will be led by local stakeholders to address
their concerns, progress towards the goals they set as priorities, and match the capacities of implementing
institutions.
Activities Narrative:
Activity 3.4.1: Undertake detailed mapping of regulatory and legislative measures governing the (a) entry and
operation of service providers in the housing and construction sectors in Iraq (including in terms of access to set
up/engage in operations, engagement of foreign professionals, operation and participation in public-private
partnerships in the sector), and (b) bidding/qualifying for procurement offers in housing and construction related
projects (including in terms of the process adopted to prepare, issue, and evaluate tenders, and award contracts).
The mapping of Iraq’s regulatory and legislative measures is a necessary first step to undertake a regulatory
assessment of Iraq’s construction and housing sector (Activity 3.4.2). The mapping will include both horizontal and
sectoral laws and regulations governing these sectors. Horizontal laws are those which apply to all service providers
(such as investment law, companies act, labour laws, immigration laws, land law, procurement etc.), which are likely
to include restrictions on transfer of funds, limitations on movement of people, caps on foreign equity participation,
etc.; while the sectoral laws covered those which govern the particular industry (such as construction law), as well
as at the sector-specific level which govern particular activities (such as the practice of architecture and engineering).
The objective of the mapping is to collect and tabulate all the regulations and legislations that impact Iraq’s in
preparation to undertake the regulatory assessment. Building upon the preliminary mapping undertaken,
consultations will be undertaken with relevant stakeholders to confirm/validate the laws/regulations/measures
identified and ensure that all relevant measures governing this sector including any provincial level
regulations/measures are covered in the mapping.
Activity 3.4.2: Conduct regulatory impact assessments for the regulatory/legal measures governing the entry and
operation of service providers in the housing and construction sectors in Iraq (identified from the mapping
engagement above).
The objective of this activity is to critically assess the effects of proposed and existing regulations (drawn from the
mapping exercise in Activity 3.4.1) in order to ensure that regulations are efficient and effective to achieve the overall
objective. This is because certain laws such as the regulation placing limits on foreign participation in the market,
function as a trade restrictive measure and therefore impact on services and investments in Iraq. Policy makers
should assess, when designing policies/laws/regulations, the likely impacts and consequences of such measures, and
regulatory impact assessments are a useful framework that can be adopted to assess regulations and ensure that it
meets the overarching objectives.
Accordingly, through this activity, ITC will support relevant stakeholders in Iraq to develop a framework for
undertaking regulatory impact assessments in the abovementioned sectors, drawing from the ‘OECD’s Best Practice
Principles for Regulatory Policy’. (Capacity building based on this framework will be undertaken in Activity 3.4.3
below).
Based on this framework, ITC will work with relevant institutions to select key laws/regulations/policies, as mapped
in Activity 3.4.1 above, and assess the impact of these measures so as understand whether it achieves the intended
objectives and how it impacts the operation of construction and housing services and investments into this sector.
Based on these assessments, and demand from the Government of Iraq, technical assistance can then be provided
to support Iraq’s policy makers to undertake necessary policy and regulatory reforms.

62
Activity 3.4.3 Provide capacity building for officers in relevant institutions on undertaking regulatory impact
assessments – to be applied for future regulatory developments – including through development of a technical
guide and practical training sessions.
Guidelines will be formulated based on the strategy discussed above on undertaking regulatory impact assessments
for the construction/housing sector related laws/regulations/policies. These guidelines will serve to function as a
toolkit that can be used for officers for existing and future laws/regulations/policies – with the objective of
contribution to efforts to promote evidence-based policy making.
Capacity building sessions will be organized for relevant institutions based on these guidelines; and practical sessions
held with relevant officers by working with ITC on the selected measures for the assessment under Activity 3.4.2.
Activity 3.4.4: Undertake diagnostic assessment of the alignment of the procurement framework governing
construction and housing sectors with international guidelines/best practices governing transparency, integrity,
and accountability of procurement processes.
Preliminary analysis undertaken revealed a lack of harmonization and coordination on procurement practices across
government organizations – with regard to procurement, methods, information contained in tender documents,
advertising periods, etc. With regards to procurement within the construction and housing sectors, it is important
for strong coordination and alignment between the activities of the Ministry of Planning and Development
Cooperation (which is the main agency responsible for public contracts in Iraq) and the Ministry of Construction,
Housing and Public Municipalities (which oversees procurement of construction services). An assessment
undertaken by OECD in 2008 reviewed the general public procurement framework and provided pertinent
interventions to enhance transparency, integrity, and accountability. Since then, further developments have taken
place in the regulatory framework governing public procurement.
Having in place a well-functioning public procurement framework that promotes transparency and accountability is
an important factor to attract investments into the sector and ensure that quality services are made available for
construction and housing services in the country. In this context, drawing from international guidelines/best
practices in relation to public procurement, drawing from the WTO’s Government Procurement Agreement (GPA),
the EU's Integrity Pact Toolbox, among others, as well as sector specific guidelines such as the Construction Sector
Transparency Initiative, to build understanding and capacitate stakeholders to work towards a more conducive and
enabling public procurement framework.
Linked with the capacity building initiatives under Activity 3.4.5, ITC will work with relevant institutions to undertake
an assessment of Iraq’s public procurement framework being adopted for construction services. The assessment will
review the regulatory framework and process adopted in place to prepare, issue and evaluate tenders, and award
of contracts for the construction and housing related projects – with the objective of assessing the extent to which
the existing framework is aligned with OECD recommendations and related international guidelines pertaining to
transparency and accountability as noted above.
Activity 3.4.5: Provide capacity building for officers on international guidelines/best practices in procurement
processes with a view to foster alignment of Iraq’s procurement processes in the housing and construction sectors.
Linked with the technical intervention in Activity 3.4.4 above, targeted capacity building initiatives will also be
undertaken for Iraq’s officers in the abovementioned ministries as well as other agencies identified from the
assessment, on best practices in public procurement with specific focus on procurement contexts for construction
and infrastructure related services. This will include training events (virtual and in-person) to raise awareness on
best practices/guidelines available in relation to public procurement and integrating these lessons into the public
procurement frameworks in Iraq for construction and housing services.
Activity 3.4.6: Provide technical/advisory support to undertake regulatory reforms – based on the impact
assessments and diagnostic assessment.

63
Based on the results of the regulatory and diagnostic assessments undertaken through Activities 3.4.2 and 3.4.4
respectively, technical assistance can be provided for relevant government agencies, based on demand, to prioritise
and implement recommendations to facilitate regulatory and institutional reforms.
Relevant interventions can be in the form of providing technical inputs to draft/amend laws/regulations, and
strategize reforms to strengthen coordination among government agencies, improve transparency, etc.
Activity 3.4.7: Organize public-private dialogues (built into the activities covered above) to present and discuss
regulatory and policy reforms to strengthen access to the construction and housing services sectors in Iraq,
including in the context of integrating broad developmental priorities such as sustainability and digitalization into
the industry.
PPDs will be built into the technical activities to present and discuss findings, seek inputs/clarifications, and obtain
validation on policy recommendations/insights formulated.
These dialogues function as an important platform for all relevant stakeholders from public and private sectors to
be informed about the studies/analyses underway, seek buy-in from stakeholders to engage in these efforts, and
facilitate dialogue between public and private sectors on policy reforms, so as to ensure that all stakeholders are
effectively engaged in the policy formulation and implementation process.
The PPDs effectively provide an opportunity to inform the reform process through inclusive consultation as well as
to validate the results of the studies; and ensure that stakeholders are actively engaged in decision making to
strengthen the regulatory and policy framework governing the construction and housing services sector in Iraq.
Activity 3.4.8: Provide capacity building engagements for public and private sector (including economic operators,
professional associations, business associations, etc.), and the academia/civil society on market access issues
relating to services trade – with focus on the construction and housing services sector (covering issues such as the
modalities of services trade, and potential from services liberalization, technicalities of MRAs, etc.).
To ensure that all relevant stakeholders relevant for strengthening the construction and housing services sector in
Iraq are able to provide meaningful inputs and effectively engage in the reform process, it is important that these
stakeholders understand their role in the services framework and the relevance of their engagement in contributing
to a conducive business environment for these services. As explained above, there are a number of different
areas/topics which have an impact on the operation of the construction and housing services sector, and accordingly,
it is important to ensure that all these various stakeholders understand their position in this reform process.
Through this activity, capacity building engagements will be undertaken for the various stakeholders (identified
based on the mapping undertaken in Activity 3.4.1) to understand the operation of trade in services (including the
modalities, potential from services liberalization, technicalities of MRAs, etc.) and explore these concepts within the
framework of the construction and housing services sector. Targeted sessions can be held with stakeholders from
specific institutions, based on request, to dive into these concepts and build linkages with authorities in the
construction and housing sectors.
Guides, infographics and related resources will be developed under this activity, to feed into the capacity building
initiatives. This activity will also see the development of guides, infographics and other resources. The most suitable
modality of capacity building will be decided based on the needs of the stakeholders.
Output 3.5: Enhanced awareness and capacities of public and private stakeholders of the regulatory and
procedural framework for investing in the housing and construction sectors and potential for reform.
Investment is a key driver of the construction and housing sector growth in Iraq. Increased investment –
domestic and foreign – will lead to increased jobs and income for the workers in these sectors, improved
access to finance, increased efficiency, as well as greater adoption of new technologies and sustainable
business models.

64
Beyond economic fundamentals such as market access conditions, and returns on investment, investment related
administrative procedures also play a key role in investment decisions. These may include measures/procedures
related to company establishment and business registration, connecting to infrastructure, capital transfers and
payments, payment of taxes, benefitting from incentives and public programmes, among others.
Iraq has adopted legal and regulatory reforms to encourage foreign investment and improve the business climate,
including through the promulgation of the Investment Law and establishment of the National Investment
Commission (NIC). The NIC, in turn, has established a one stop shop to function as a single point of contact for
investors and facilitate the investment process through streamlined services. However, significant challenges remain
making it challenging for investors seeking to engage in the construction and housing sectors in Iraq. Some challenges
identified from the preliminary analysis include the complexity and lack of clarity of regulations, predictability of the
policy environment, lack of coordination among government agencies, lack of transparency, and the complex and
time-consuming administrative procedures to be complied with. These challenges are not unique to Iraq, and efforts
have been pursued through domestic reforms or international agreements such as the WTO Investment Facilitation
for Development (IFD) Agreement to improve transparency and streamline administrative procedures to make
investment processes easier, faster, and safer.
Accordingly, interventions are designed under Output 3.5 to strengthen Iraq’s investment facilitation measures,
drawing from international guidelines, with the objective to increase flow of domestic and foreign investment into
the housing and construction sectors.
Output 3.5 engages public and private stakeholders to improve the policy environment for facilitating investments
into the housing and construction sectors, and in turn, expanding access to housing and potential of small firms in
the sector to meaningfully contribute to job creation and facilitate sustainable industrial growth. Through targeted
activities on building awareness, assessing needs, analysing potential reforms to administrative processes and
regulations, and providing comprehensive capacity building, stakeholders will be equipped with the necessary tools
to attract and engage potential investors.
Activities Narrative:
Activity 3.5.1: Determine the core group of stakeholders for investment facilitation, including participants from
both public and private sector.
Investment facilitation measures (as reflected in the WTO IFD Agreement) cover a broad scope of laws and
regulations on various elements – and accordingly, it is crucial for the country to identify all governmental agencies
directly involved in the whole life cycle of investment at both national and sub-national levels. These agencies will
need to be part of the assessment process (undertaken in Activity 3.5.2 and 3.5.4) – and form the core stakeholder
group for implementing investment facilitation measures. In addition to the core stakeholder group, it is also
necessary to engage other stakeholders, both governmental and non-governmental, involved in the whole life cycle
of an investment – which can include foreign and domestic investors, research institutes, civil society organizations
that have a practical and ground level knowledge and experience that enables them to provide inputs from various
perspectives. Key agencies already identified include the National Investment Commission, Provincial Investment
Commission, the Ministry of Trade’s Companies Registration Department, Kurdistan Board of Investment, Chamber
of Commerce, and the Council of Ministers.
Accordingly, a mapping will be undertaken of the various government agencies linked to/relevant for overseeing the
implementation of measures/procedures set out in the WTO IFD Agreement; and identification of other relevant
stakeholders (from private sector and civil society) who can be engaged in the process. The core group of
stakeholders will occupy an important role in the needs assessment and business process analysis – as the
information collected and analysis formulated will need to be reviewed and confirmed by all relevant agencies
involved in the implementation process. The overall process will have to be led by a national coordinating agency –
which will be identified in consultation with relevant agencies.
The mapping will be undertaken through a combination of desk research, and stakeholder consultations and focus
group discussion(s) to present the mapping and seek validation/inputs from the relevant stakeholders. In addition,

65
there will be a sub-core group within the overall core stakeholder group comprising stakeholders directly engaged
in the construction and housing services industry. The sub-core group will not necessarily be mutually exclusive from
the overall core stakeholder group – as there may be overlaps in the stakeholders engaged (For instance the National
Investment Commission, and the Companies Registrar will be engaged in both groups).
These activities will be undertaken by investment facilitation expert(s) and a national investment expert (with
capacity to engage in Arabic language and build networks with relevant stakeholders).
Activity 3.5.2: Provide capacity building and awareness-raising for the core group stakeholders to enhance their
knowledge about the objectives and approaches for investment facilitation and the needs assessment.
To facilitate the assessment of investment facilitation measures under Activity 3.5.3 - capacity building initiatives
will be built in for the relevant stakeholders as identified in Activity 3.5.1 - to ensure that all stakeholders are well-
versed and capacitated to engage effectively in this process.
The Needs Assessment Guide for Investment Facilitation – formulated by the WTO to enable self-assessments – and
other related materials will be circulated to all stakeholders in advance of the assessment – with the objective of
providing a good foundation and to ensure comprehensive discussion among stakeholders.
Following this, targeted capacity building sessions will be organized in collaboration with the national coordinating
agency and the core stakeholder group to build understanding on the context of investment facilitation and related
measures, and process for strengthening investment facilitation using the Needs Assessment Guide as a template.
Technical sessions will then be facilitated on each of the sections of the Needs Assessment Guide for Investment
Facilitation – to work through each provision, provide examples on how each provision can be implemented, and
discuss its application in Iraq.
Through these sessions, the objective will be to ensure that all stakeholders relevant for the investment facilitation
process are well-versed on the relevant matters and able to provide solid and useful inputs to feed into the needs
assessment process effected under Activity 3.5.3.
Activity 3.5.3: Undertake a needs assessment of the investment facilitation framework in Iraq – based on the
guidelines developed based on the WTO Investment Facilitation for Development (IFD) Agreement.
At the initial training undertaken in Activity 3.5.2, participants will be invited to fill in a pre-assessment survey to
collect preliminary inputs on relevant procedures/measures, as set out in the Needs Assessment Guide formulated
by the WTO. The Needs Assessment Guide is structured into four main sections – (a) transparency of investment
measures; (b) streamlining and speeding up administrative procedures; (c) focal points, domestic regulatory
coherence and cross-border cooperation; and (d) sustainable investment. Participants will not be required to provide
comprehensive answers and may provide partial answers focusing on their areas of expertise. The survey will serve
as a foundation for group discussion in the in-country self-assessment.
Thereafter, technical support will be provided to work through and complete information on each of the sections of
the Guide and identify challenges/constraints and areas for reform. Consultations will be built into the targeted
capacity building sessions discussed in Activity 3.5.2 above, to present preliminary inputs received from the pre-
assessment survey and obtain inputs/information from the stakeholders on the relevant
laws/regulations/procedures pertaining to each of the articles covered in the section.
This will be complemented with an in-depth study based on the information collected from the stakeholder group,
further desk research and consultations, to review the laws/regulations/administrative requirements and the
practical implementation, assess challenges/constraints identified, and compile information into the needs
assessment guide. The compiled assessment will be shared with the national coordinating agency for review,
consultations held to present the findings, and seek confirmation on the information gathered and analysed
pertaining to the relevant laws/regulations/measures.
Dialogues will be organized under Activity 3.5.7 to present the findings of the assessment to the core stakeholder
group – to seek inputs and validation on the analysis of the challenges/constraints identified – and discuss potential

66
policy reforms in this regard (refer to Activity 3.5.7 for further details). The needs assessment will be further refined
based on feedback received at these dialogues.
A final report will be prepared with an overall analysis of the investment facilitation framework in Iraq,
challenges/constraints faced, and policy recommendations to streamline and strengthen investment facilitation
measures in the country.
Activity 3.5.4: Undertake a business process analysis study on the administrative/procedural steps and relevant
agencies involved in the process for investing in and setting up operations in the housing and constructions sectors
in Iraq.
The business process analysis study will, draw from the investment facilitation analysis, and then dive into the
specific administrative procedures in the housing and construction sectors, with the aim of identifying redundancies
and undue complexities, assess mechanisms, quality, and effectiveness of procedures, and propose suggestions for
practical reform.
This will entail a mapping of the value chain in the housing and construction sector, identifying relevant steps in the
investment process, procedures for setting up a company in Iraq (both as a foreign and domestic investor) in the
construction and housing industry, required authorizations and agencies in charge, time required for obtaining
authorization, fees and charges, time and costs associated with obtaining local services required to undertake
construction and related services.
The results of this mapping will also be used to feed into the formulation of a sub-core group within the core
stakeholder group set out in Activity 3.5.1; and further targeted sessions will be conducted for stakeholders in the
sub-core group pertaining directly to the construction and housing services sectors to explain the context of
investment facilitation in the framework of the particular industry. Relevant stakeholders identified from the
preliminary analysis undertaken by ITC in this regard include the Ministry of Planning and Development Cooperation,
Ministry of Labour, General Directorate of Real Estate, and the Iraqi Syndicate of Engineers.
An analysis of the application of the procedures identified from the mapping exercise will be undertaken – through
desk research, consultations/focus group discussion, etc. – to assess/identify options to streamline procedures,
enhance collaboration among agencies, reduce required authorizations, and digitize documentation requirements,
and improve transparency and reduce corruption.
