A final report will be prepared to present the overall findings, detail the procedures and challenges/constraints
identified, and provide policy recommendations to streamline, build collaboration and smoothen the process in the
construction and housing sector.
The investment facilitation experts referred to above, will be supported by a local expert in the construction and
housing services sector for this activity.
Activity 3.5.5: Develop an investment guide (which can be integrated into an online platform) on the
steps/procedures to invest and set up operations in the construction and housing sectors in Iraq.
An investment guide will be developed providing step-by-step guidance for investors seeking to engage in Iraq. The
guide will detail in a logical manner – the procedures for to set up and operate a business in in Iraq – including
measures for registering labour, engaging foreign employees, registering tax profile, claiming incentives, etc.
Upon development of the investment guide – an event will be organized to present and launch the investment guide
(potentially in collaboration with events organized under Activity 3.5.8) – with the objective of showcasing and
promoting the efforts of the Iraqi Government to strengthen the investment framework for the construction and
housing sector.
Activity 3.5.6: Deliver capacity building for public and private sector stakeholders on investment facilitation and
strengthening investment frameworks, including in the context of aligning investment frameworks with emerging
trends such as sustainability and digitalization, drawing on best practices/lessons learned from other jurisdictions
– including targeted engagements for key stakeholders such as the National Investment Commission, Provincial

67
Investment Commissions, and the Kurdistan Board of Investment, among others (based on a sustained
training/capacity building plan to be developed at the start of the project).
Complementing the targeted capacity building events for the core stakeholder group on investment facilitation,
relevant training/information-sharing materials will be developed such as infographics and video clips on related
content – which can be circulated widely to reach a broader audience.
In addition, further targeted events will be organized for the core stakeholder group and other relevant stakeholders
from the public and private sectors, to explore:
- Developments in investment negotiations, covering multilateral and regional/bilateral agreements – and
relevance for Iraq, and importance of aligning investment policy to facilitate industrial development in the
country.
- Best practices/lessons learned in leveraging investment policy to facilitate transition to digital and
sustainable led industrial growth.
These events will seek to generate awareness of the public and private sector in Iraq on the importance of
refining/strengthening investment frameworks in line with emerging trends – to build competitiveness and attract
sustainable private sector investments into the country.
For the topics referred to above, the content produced will be contextualised for the construction and housing
industry in Iraq, as relevant.
To feed into these training programmes, technical briefs will be developed on the topics mentioned above, to be
shared with participants and can also be made available on online platforms to be accessible in public.
Activity 3.5.7: Organize public-private dialogues to present and discuss regulatory and procedural reforms based
on the analyses.
In order to strengthen collaboration and coordination between the public and private sectors in Iraq, and
importantly, to also ensure that private sector is engaged as an important stakeholder in the policy formulation and
implementation process in Iraq – public-private dialogues will be built in across the activities under Output 3.5.
As noted in Activity 3.5.1, 3.5.3 and Activity 3.5.4 above, public-private dialogues will be organized to present:
- the mapping of relevant stakeholders undertaken for the studies under this Output, and
- the findings of the self-assessment for investment facilitation framework in Iraq and the analysis of the
investment process in the construction and housing sector in Iraq.
These dialogues will be a forum from which to familiarize stakeholders with the interventions being undertaken to
strengthen the investment facilitation framework for the construction and housing sector in Iraq, obtain
feedback/inputs on the analysis, facilitate discussion between public and private sectors on challenges/constraints
faced and feasibility of proposed policy recommendations, and seek agreement from stakeholders on the way
forward.
Reports will be drawn upon based on each public-private dialogue organized to detail the discussion points covered
in the dialogue, agreements reached between stakeholders, and set out the next steps. These reports will function
as a record for the relevant government agencies and institutions to take action on policy reforms, and for private
sector to be able to track and follow-up on relevant matters, including providing the necessary support to facilitate
implementation of the policy reforms.
These reports, upon sign off from the main government agency, can be circulated among all participants in the
public-private dialogue.

68
Activity 3.5.8: Develop tools for facilitating sustainable investment, including domestic supplier databases of
domestic services/material providers in the construction and housing value chains, so that investors can have
easier access to information on available domestic services and suppliers.
A domestic supplier database provides information about the availability and capacity of the local suppliers so that
investors/foreign companies can have easier access to information and connect with the local suppliers. The supplier
database can be hosted on the website of the investment promotion agency (IPA), as part of IPA’s effort to promote
local suppliers and connect them to markets. The supplier database can also serve as a tool to increase transparency
in the market and help businesses assess competition and market conditions.
The tool will be made available in English and Arabic – for accessibility by local and foreign stakeholders. The
development of the database will be effected in collaboration with the IPA with the objective of capacitating relevant
officials to take ownership of the database and keep it updated.
Activity 3.5.9: Analysing and identifying countries with strong home country support measures in infrastructure/
construction/housing sectors and developing targeted initiatives to attract investors from these countries.
Some countries have strong home country support measures in infrastructure/ construction/housing sectors,
including support to identify market opportunities (business intelligence and information on regulations), support
to connect to public and private stakeholders including potential creditors, support on meeting regulatory and
sustainability standards through trainings etc. These home country measures can help increase competitiveness as
well as ensure quality delivery. Home and host country IPAs can work together to exchange information on these
support measures and develop targeted initiatives to benefit from home country measures, both for the investor
and the local communities.
ITC’s experts will organize experience sharing sessions with IPAs in selected countries (to be identified based on
research and consultations) to explore mechanisms/initiatives being implemented and exchange information in this
regard. In line with these sessions, ITC will also develop a best practice guide on relevant support measures adopted
by other selected jurisdictions and assess the feasibility for application in Iraq.
4.6 RESULTS CHAIN OUTCOME FOUR
4.6.1 OUTCOME FOUR: INTERVENTION LOGIC
If the awareness and technical capacities of social partners with regard to the right to organize, collective bargaining
and the participation in social dialogue with public actors are improved (Op 4.1), then the influence on labour
markets of employers’ and workers’ organisations involved in social dialogue with the government will be
strengthened (Oc. 4), as long as the representatives of social partners are committed to participate in the training
and technical support provided; the members are also willing to implement the technical skills acquired to
strengthen their respective organizations further; and, social partners will exert concerted effort towards using
different advocacy platforms towards ensuring their rights to organize and collective bargaining.
4.6.2 OUTCOME FOUR: DESCRIPTION
Strengthened influence on labour markets of employers’ and workers’ organisations involved in social dialogue
with the government.
The ILO has proven experience in promoting social dialogue through consultative processes between social partners
and government to shape labour markets and address labour-related issues all over the world. The ILO's work on
strengthening social partners' representativeness and institutional capacity is guided by its tripartite structure,
where representatives from governments, employers' organizations, and workers' organizations collaborate on
various programs and initiatives.
The ILO also works with governments, employers' organizations, and workers' organizations to strengthen their
institutional capacities. This includes supporting the development of effective organizational structures, internal
governance mechanisms, and strategic planning processes.

69
The ILO also supports the right of workers and employers to form and join organizations of their choice taking its
catalyst role in promoting Freedom of Association (FoA), and advocates for the recognition and protection of
collective bargaining rights. By promoting freedom of association, the ILO fosters the creation of strong and
representative workers' and employers' organizations.
Overall, the ILO's work focuses on empowering social partners to engage in social dialogue and consultative
processes. By strengthening their representativeness and institutional capacity, the ILO aims to foster inclusive and
participatory decision-making that leads to better labour market outcomes and improved working conditions for
workers.
Under this outcome, the ILO aspires to: supporting the national coordination mechanism to implement a roadmap
to strengthen the application of the right to organize and collective bargaining; and supporting institutional capacity
of the social partners to influence the labour market in the construction sector.
Furthermore, beyond Outcome four, ILO, UN-Habitat and ITC have emmeshed engagement with CSO’s throughout
the project design (outcomes one, two, and three). CSO’s will be central to engaging in policy dialogues and valued
partners on the ground - supporting with advocacy, outreach, awareness raising and implementation activities.
CSO’s will be engaged in expert consultations, participatation in roundtable and participatory planning discussions,
serve on technical working groups, and support community-level activities.
4.6.3 OUTCOME FOUR: OUTPUTS AND ACTIVITIES
Output 4.1: A national coordination mechanism is established to implement the roadmap to strengthen the
application of the right to organize and collective bargaining.
Under this output, the ILO will provide technical support to the establishment of a national coordination mechanism
to strengthen the application of Convention 98 - Right to Organise and Collective Bargaining Convention, 1949,
ratified by the Government of Iraq which has been in force since 1962. This will be realized through development of
a roadmap which will be led by the collective effort of the tripartite constituents preceded by a comprehensive
analysis of gaps hindering workers and employers to join trade unions and employers’ organizations.
The ILO along with ILOITC-Turin, will provide technical assistance, training, and capacity-building programs to
governments, employers' organizations, and workers' organizations. These programs aim to enhance their
knowledge and skills related to social dialogue, collective bargaining, and policy formulation that matters most for
their respective members. Parallel to the capacity building programmes, the ILO will provide technical assistance for
social partners and technical drafting committee on the drafting of the new trade unions law.
Activities Narrative:
Activity 4.1.1: Provide support to the government to establish a tripartite coordination mechanism to guide the
implementation of an inclusive roadmap towards enhanced freedom of association.
The project will: Stakeholder Engagement: Identify and engage key stakeholders, including government
representatives, employers' associations, and trade unions. Foster a collaborative and inclusive approach to build
trust and consensus among stakeholders. Needs Assessment: Conduct a needs assessment to identify specific
challenges and opportunities related to freedom of association in the country. Analyse existing legislation, policies,
and practices to understand the current landscape. Implementation of the Roadmap: Facilitate a participatory
process to implement an inclusive roadmap for enhancing freedom of association and right to collective bargaining.
Involve representatives from all three stakeholder groups in the roadmap's development. Drafting Tripartite
Coordination Mechanism: Develop a proposal for the establishment of a tripartite coordination mechanism. Outline
the objectives, scope, roles, responsibilities, and structure of the mechanism. Consultation and Validation: Organize
consultation workshops or meetings with government officials, employers' representatives, and trade union leaders
to present and discuss the proposed mechanism. Address any concerns or suggestions raised during the consultation
process. Legal and Regulatory Review: Review existing laws and regulations related to FACB to ensure they align

5. TARGET AREAS, BENEFICIARIES, AND STAKEHOLDERS
5.1 TARGET AREA SELECTION CRITERIA
Pilot locations will be selected following additional government consultations and during the inception phase, based
on consideration of a broad range of criteria measuring need, capacities to benefit from the project’s interventions,
anticipated support, and representativeness:
o Unemployment rate.
o Poverty rate or other proxy for income.
o Level of housing deprivation (slum areas, informal settlements, lack of basic services, prevalence of
dilapidated or destroyed housing).
o Governorates where affordable housing shortage for low-income households and/or vulnerable groups
(IDPs, widows, disabled elderly) is demonstrable.
o Governorates that have overburdened infrastructure.
o Areas where housing developers and public construction are active.
o Presence of EU and other donor programs.
o GOI focus areas.
o Feasibility in implementation (established and good relations with local government and willingness to
collaborate).
o Demonstrated local capacity to implement (with some added technical assistance, if needed).
o Political willingness to pilot and implement an affordable housing programme, coupled with sufficient
budget allocation for the housing sector.
o Potential for high impact green interventions (design, building materials, energy efficiency installation and
renewables).
o Buildable land is available (or will be) and is well connected to jobs, transportation and other services and
amenities.
o New housing development (if applicable) has mixed-use and mixed income potential.
o Geographically representativeness (together, the selected regions represent diverse geographies and
populations).
5.2 PROJECT BENEFICIARIES
The project intends to benefit the following direct and indirect beneficiaries:
o Young women and men, including IDPs who are seeking decent jobs in the construction and housing sectors.
Through the available data of jobs seekers within the Directorates of Labour and other local channels at
target governorates, the project shall identify the most vulnerable people according to pre-determined
criteria together with project stakeholders and provide them with short to medium term opportunities.
Minimum percentages of female workers and persons with disabilities shall be agreed upon at the
identification criteria.
o Unskilled and Semi-skilled workers in the construction sector obtaining new skills or upgrading their existing
skills. In consultation with the Vocational Training Centres of MOLSA and other vocational training institutes
inside target governorate, the project shall provide opportunities to improve workers’ skills through the
infrastructural interventions. The improvement of skills shall be supported by certification/ accreditation of
these skills to ensure long term advantages for workers benefited from these opportunities.
o Civil Society Organizations: Civil Society Organizations (CSOs): are diverse and encompass a wide range of
community-based organizations, child rights organizations, trade unions, research and policy think tanks,
social and economic development NGOs, youth associations, women's rights groups. They can benefit from
this project in several ways: capacity building, advocacy support, networking opportunities, information

73
and research, participation in policy dialogue, monitoring and reporting, capacity for social dialogue
Enhancing CSOs' capacity in areas such as freedom of association and collective bargaining empowers them
to engage constructively in social dialogue with employers and government authorities.
o Children: The project's approach to combating child labour involves a multifaceted strategy that prioritizes
the well-being and development of children. Working closely with local communities, schools, and families,
child rights organizations and local authorities to identify and rescue children engaged in labour
exploitation, ensuring their rehabilitation and reintegration into society.
o Social Housing Recipients: The primary recipient of housing units will include low-income and vulnerable
households who are unable to obtain adequate and affordable housing through conventional market
mechanisms. A structured beneficiary selection process will be devised which reflects area-based needs
and entails detailed application and selection criteria. The housing provided will be centred around a needs-
based approach and will target resources and assistance accordingly. A set of basic requirements will be
established that every beneficiary must fulfil (i.e., maximum income, does not already own a home). Priority
groups will be identified, and a points-based system will ensure that housing beneficiaries are among the
most vulnerable. A verification process will assess applicants' current living conditions in consideration of
their family and economic circumstances in the context of the surrounding community. To maintain
transparency and clarity throughout the process, clear communication channels about the selection process
and criteria will be established from the outset. Additionally, mechanisms for wait lists, recourse,
complaints, and feedback will be integrated into the selection process, ensuring that it remains accountable
and responsive to the needs and concerns of the beneficiaries.
o Construction value chain businesses: Private sector actors engaged in the housing and construction sector,
including contractors, housing developers and CSO’s (e.g. workers’ and employers’ organizations) will
benefit from support on enhanced public-private dialogue, policy reform, and trade and investment. Newly
established and existing MSMEs in the housing value chain will be supported in strengthening their
capacities and connections with partners and markets / clients. Targeted support will strengthen firms’
adoption of sustainable products and practices.
o Government Representatives: Through consultations with government counterparts, particularly with
MOCH (Ministry of Construction and Housing) and Housing Directorates, Ministry of Labour and Social
Affairs, Ministry of Planning, MOT candidates from government offices who will most benefit from capacity
building will be identified. These individuals selected for training should be mid-to high level and possess
strong leadership qualities and a genuine commitment to participate in training activities. They should also
exhibit a readiness to apply the acquired skills in their work environment and share their knowledge and
experience with fellow staff members. Furthermore, engagement with government stakeholders in
initiating legislative and regulatory revisions and the Housing Policy update will be supported and
coordinated through the MOCH.
o Parliament: The ILO project will extend critical support to the Parliament of Iraq in its efforts to ratify the
new trade union law. This support will encompass technical expertise, legal analysis, and the provision of
international labour standards' insights to ensure that the proposed law aligns with global best practices
and the principles of freedom of association and collective bargaining. The project will facilitate dialogue
between parliamentarians, government representatives, trade unions, and employers' organizations to
have consensus on the law's content. Moreover, it will offer capacity-building programs for
parliamentarians to enhance their understanding of the law's implications and its importance in advancing
labour rights and social justice. By fostering this collaborative approach and providing the necessary
resources, the project aims to facilitate the swift and effective ratification of the new trade union law,
further promoting workers' rights and strengthening industrial relations in Iraq.

5.4 CROSS-CUTTING THEMES AND MAINSTREAMING
Human rights: The project will adopt a human rights-based approach and follows the “Do No Harm”
principles, seeking in particular to ensure inclusive participation and no one is left behind. The Project
uses a pro-poor approach that seeks to improve the right of poor families to adequate housing and youth
employment. Moreover, the Project adopts a participatory approach that will be implemented
throughout the phases of the Project. Community mobilizers will be working closely with the most
vulnerable community groups to ensure that no one is left behind. Vulnerability criteria are included in
the selection of beneficiaries. Households with vulnerable members such as displaced persons, female
heads, widows, elderly and/or persons with disabilities will be given priority in the selection process.
Equity and inclusion of women: Iraqi culture encompasses various societal norms, laws, standards, and practices
that differ between men, women, boys, and girls. To address these distinctions, the project will undertake an in-
depth analysis of the diverse needs of beneficiary groups, including identifying potential obstacles to participation.
The project is committed to promoting the inclusion of women in stakeholder engagement activities, such as
community meetings, workshops, and training sessions, as well as in policy dialogues. To achieve this goal, deliberate
efforts will be made to create platforms and opportunities that enable women to have a voice in local urban
development and, when feasible, in the broader global urban agenda. Additionally, the project will actively strive to
promote access to entry for women and prevent discriminatory practices, particularly in the realms of job creation,
working conditions, and the selection of housing beneficiaries.
Children, youth and the elderly: The project will put youth at the forefront of change where possible, acknowledging
the critical role of youth as a catalyst to more meaningful representation and decision making for future
sustainability. This is done through engaging youth in skill development and policy dialogues. By engaging in
employment opportunities, MSME development, and construction work, youth will become self-reliant and
positively impact Iraq’s efforts toward long-term development objectives. Children and youth will play a pivotal role
in the ILO project's efforts to combat child labour in the construction sector. Through targeted awareness campaigns
and community-based initiatives, the project will engage with children and youth, empowering them with
knowledge about the hazards of child labour and the importance of education. Furthermore, youth will be
encouraged to become advocates against child labour within their communities, amplifying the project's impact by
spreading awareness and encouraging other children and families to prioritize education and safe alternatives to
child labour. By actively involving children and youth in the project's activities, it aims to not only rescue and
rehabilitate child laborers but also foster a sense of agency and leadership among the younger generation,
contributing to a sustainable reduction in child labour in the construction sector.
Disability: The project will pursue a disability inclusive approach through deliberate consultations with
people with disabilities on various aspects of the project (i.e., housing policy, housing design needs,
inclusion in the labour market and construction sector). Further, the needs of people living with disabilities
will be fully considered in the construction of housing and communal spaces through a universal design
approach. Other urban design factors such as, walkability and accessibility measures will be integrated
into urban design to ensure safe access all to buildings, facilities, and public space for the elderly, people
living with disabilities, children, and all alike.
Internally Displaced Persons: Creating effective affordable housing projects and public works programs for internally
displaced people (IDPs) requires a comprehensive approach that addresses their immediate needs while also
fostering long-term stability and self-sufficiency. The project will focus on internally displaced persons to re-integrate
them back to the labour market while addressing their housing needs. Pilot project locations will be selected in areas
where stable jobs and housing situations can support in assuring security of tenure and in fostering social stability.
The most affected Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and host communities in Ninewa governorate will be
considered while target beneficiaries are selected. The project will diligently strive to prioritize actions that promote

79
the inclusion of internally displaced persons (IDPs) in policy dialogue and formulation, and in delivering
programmatic activities. This includes advocacy efforts directed towards local and national government authorities.
Conflict Sensitivity: The proposed project places a strong emphasis on upholding protection and conflict-sensitivity
principles and will adopt an area-based approach. In the initial stages, thorough analyses and assessments of conflict
sensitivity risks will be conducted for each target area. This will ensure a comprehensive understanding of how the
project's planned activities will interact with the local context, taking into account factors like conflict drivers, sources
of tension, and power structures. Measures to mitigate potential risks will be established before the project's
activities are implemented.
The project will also focus on assessing how its activities can contribute to promoting social cohesion within the
communities it serves. Special attention will be given to the location of housing construction and in ensuring that
housing beneficiaries have secure tenure and are not vulnerable to displacement, thereby enhancing social stability
and creating a safe living environment.
Throughout its implementation, the project will strictly adhere to human rights, protection, and conflict sensitivity
standards, including international and Iraqi legal principles such as the Guiding Principles on Internal Displacement
and the IASC Framework on Durable Solutions. In cases where there are indications of increasing tensions during
implementation, the project will collaborate with social cohesion and peacebuilding stakeholders to identify
appropriate strategies for addressing or mitigating these tensions. This may involve adapting project activities as
necessary to maintain a peaceful and secure environment.
Inclusive economic development: Private sector development and economic diversification will be needed to
provide sustainable enhancements to the wellbeing of Iraqis. Creating inclusive opportunities through work with
small business and vulnerable groups will reinforce these developments. The project's activities on MSMEs, skill
development, and employment will be designed to target women's economic empowerment and the creation of
opportunities for youth and displaced persons in particular.
Climate Change: The project aims to put addressing climate change at the forefront through integrating adaptive
and mitigative measures, particularly in the construction of new housing, producing green jobs and in supporting
SMES in adopting green business practices and measures. Housing construction will seek to reduce the carbon
footprint through careful site selection and applying compact and sustainable urban design principles as well as
climate sensitive architectural design and building materials, and integrating renewable and energy efficient
measures where practical. It will also seek to strengthen the evidence base and understanding of the differentiated
impacts of climate change on men and women and the role of women as agents of change and on opportunities for
women as per the UNFCCC Gender Action Plan. Proposed adaptation and mitigation strategies will be based on a
gender analysis of risk, need, demand, barriers, and supply as per the EU Country Level Implementation Plan (2021-
2025). Linkages to the OECD DAC RIO markers for climate change are as follows:
o Urban development and management - supports climate mitigation (2) - ‘compact town planning’ and
adaptation (2) efforts ‘measures to counter overheating and climate vulnerabilities’. (Purpose code: 43030)

and adaptation (2) – More robust building regulation and enforcement practices (2). (Purpose code: 223).
o Heating, cooling and energy distribution –supports mitigation (2)- Integrating energy storage, management
and appliances – renewables directly to homes (Purpose code: 223).

5.5 LEVERAGING PRIVATE INVESTMENT
Insufficient attention has been given to the potential of private investment to support the faster expansion of
affordable housing in Iraq. In addition to the underdevelopment of the financial sector, these investments are
discouraged by uncertainties in the business environment. Increasing the involvement of the private sector in
affordable housing thus requires concrete policy setting, an enabling regulatory framework, transparent and
coherent procurement processes, and the determination of appropriate level of subsidy and commensurate funding
sources, enmeshed with the appropriate levels of risk sharing. The proposed project aims to develop these tools and
methodologies in collaboration with housing finance experts to determine appropriate private finance models in the
Iraqi context.
In order to maximize its impact and support the development of the private sector, the project will leverage
international and domestic private investment to the greatest extent possible across all relevant activities. Activities
directly targeting investment promotion and facilitation, and the improvement of the business climate for
investment, will be complemented by cross-cutting efforts to further integrate private investment in the
construction of affordable housing by working closely with private sector stakeholders. Specific outputs that will
engage private sector expertise and engagement in policy dialogue, include:
• Output 2.1: Revision of the National Housing Policy: The updated housing policy should reflect an enabling
approach, fostering dialogue with private sector actors will collaboratively shape the policy framework and
could facilitate private investment playing a pivotal role filling the affordable housing deficit.
• Output 2.2: Engaging the private sector in policy discussions concerning necessary regulatory and legislative
reforms aimed at facilitating the expansion of both green and affordable housing production- can unlock
substantial private investment, support in streamlining bureaucratic processes, and establish the private
sector as an integral part of the affordable housing solution in Iraq.
• Output 2.3: The creation of new affordable housing financing mechanisms: Collaborating with national and
international housing finance experts to evaluate, assess and develop new green and affordable finance
mechanisms, tailored to the Iraqi context, can help to unleash new investment opportunities that are
financially sound and attractive to private investors.
• Output 3.1: The design and implementation of a green sustainable housing sector development strategy:
Policy dialogue platforms involving private sector and other stakeholders are to be established to
collectively allow for the discussion of priorities for the medium term and establishment and pursuit of
concrete targets in these areas.
• Outputs 3.2, 3.3, and 3.4 include public-private dialogues on specific issues related to sustainable
development and efficiency among SMEs active in housing and construction.
• Output 3.5: Awareness raising on the investment framework: Support is to be provided on investment
facilitation, capacity building, and related areas to attract additional private sector investment.
5.6 MOBILIZING PUBLIC SECTOR INVESTMENT
In addition to leveraging private investment, the project will work to encourage – and support the more effective
use of – public sector investment in affordable housing through its work with policymakers and the agencies involved
in housing and construction, including the strengthening of public-private linkages. This will further increase the
impact of the project’s activities and contribute to a lasting impact on housing.
In most countries, the public sector plays a formidable role in ensuring that a wide range of housing options are
available through concrete policy setting and the formulation of affordable housing programmes. Government
intervention is particularly essential in countries where there is a marked absence of mature commercial banking
systems, construction sectors, and formal labour markets as is the case in Iraq. International examples demonstrate
that governments typically a play role, to some extent, in housing development and provision, whether it is to offer
access to financing, grants, or direct subsidies or program delivery or a combination as such. That said housing is
expensive and there will never be sufficient resources to address the housing needs for everyone. So, while
affordable housing programmes almost always involve a good degree of government intervention, governments

81
typically have limited funds and competencies needed to tackle the issue alone and thus, the private sector is
becoming increasingly important in structuring low-income housing programmes.
It is important to note in this regard that public spending plans in Iraq for the near future are outlined but not entirely
certain. The government’s most recent budget (for 2023-25) a replacement of previous annual budgets) provides
some more predictability for spending over the next three years. The budget outlines expenditures of IQD 199 trillion
(USD $153 billion) and allocates IQD 49 trillion (USD $38 billion) to investment programmes. Within the investment
project budget, the GOI has provided significant allocations for projects contributing to poverty reduction ($1.23
billion) through financing the Iraq Fund for Development ($0.77 billion), Poverty Alleviation Strategy ($0.38 billion),
and Poverty Projects ($0.08 billion). As far as sector specific allocations, the total allocation made to construction,
housing, and public municipalities is IQD 4,960 trillion ($3.79 billion), much of which IQD 3,784 billion ($2.89 billion)
is in capital expenditure. Uncertainty remains, however. Expenditure beyond 2023 is not assured without more
clarity on future resources or the composition of spending, and the extent of the alignment of spending with National
Development Plan (NDP) priorities is not clear (GIZ, 2023). The project partners will coordinate with government
counterparts to identify and secure appropriate budget sources that can be dedicated to affordable housing projects
(poverty alleviation strategies or housing sector specific budget items) and Employment Intensive interventions. The
development of local plans aligned with the NDP is essential to enable local communities to benefit from public
funds and investments, and the project will build the capacities of local partners at target governorates to align their
plans with prioritized needs.
In previous decades, the GOI has undertaken several initiatives to address the nation’s housing challenges.
Unfortunately, such efforts have largely fallen short in supporting those most in need. State sponsored housing has
typically been allocated to public employees through various Ministries, regardless of need or income. Furthermore,
the prevalence of corruption and nepotism has hindered efforts to effectively target lower-income beneficiaries.
Often, those with strong connections tend to be the recipients of government sponsored housing and land programs.
More recently, the GOI has turned its attention to addressing housing through the “New Cities” investment projects.
While this is a commendable step towards addressing the housing shortage, the prices of these housing units far
surpass what would be affordable to even moderate-income families. In this context, this proposed project will
provide technical support and capacity building to the GOI that not only aims to mobilize public resources but also
to effectively target resources to realize the greatest societal impact. This comprehensive strategy involves:
- Raising Awareness: The project will work on building awareness within the GOI about the pressing need for
affordable housing.
- Technical trainings: specialized training programs shall be delivered to GOI – technical authorities to design
development plan on local level to identify infrastructural needs for housing sector and create decent jobs.
- Setting Policy Goals: The project will assist in formulating policy objectives that explicitly address the
housing requirements of low-income and vulnerable populations. This will be achieved through legislative
and regulatory reforms and through the modernization of the National Housing Policy.
- Developing Financial Models: New financial models will be crafted to support the financial feasibility and
expansion of affordable housing production. This will include the identification of potential dedicated
funding streams for affordable housing as well as opportunities for private investment.
Furthermore, the project will include a pilot initiative to create social housing units. This pilot will serve as a
demonstration of the concept that sustainable, cost-effective, and large-scale production of social housing in Iraq is
indeed feasible when the available resources are utilized effectively.
5.7 DEVELOPMENT PARTNER MAPPING
The United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (UNSDCF) 2020 – 2024 and the new
framework 2025 – 2029 is considered key instrument for the UN System to ensure a harmonized and collective
response to national development challenges, as well as to support the national strategic plans related to the
achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals/Agenda 2030. Implementing the UNSDCF through the UN
Country Team, in collaboration and coordination with the GOI, ensures that the implementation builds on existing

82
national processes and contributes to the SDG planning of the GOI. The project will contribute to the UNSDCF on
different levels and outcomes, as well as building on other UN agencies planned and existing interventions.
The approach presented in this proposal aims to enhance and align with ongoing initiatives in Iraq while minimizing
redundancy. It will endeavour to synergise with existing projects, leverage available resources, coordinate effectively
with other stakeholders, and adopt established methodologies through active collaboration and communication
with fellow development partners. Sustaining the backing and support of these development entities is deemed
crucial to achieving the project's goals. Consequently, the project will strive to integrate activities, harness existing
expertise, and capitalize on the achievements of partner organizations. The following development partners with
complementary objectives are currently or recently active in Iraq include:
Numerous development partners have actively participated in housing construction and rehabilitation efforts across
areas impacted by conflict as part of post-conflict shelter reconstruction efforts. An interactive map and
comprehensive database can be found on the Global Shelter and UN-Habitat Cluster dashboard which includes
detailed geographic data on where partners are have or worked or are working and how many units they intend to
build. Partners include UN agencies including UNDP, UNHCR, IOM and UN-Habitat as well other INGOs such as DRC,
NRC and ACTED. Additionally, several Iraqi NGOs have played a role in shelter rehabilitation including local charity
organizations. As of June 2022, close to 90k homes were targeted for rehabilitation or construction of which 58k
have been completed, the majority of which are in Mosul (16.4k), Ramadi (12k) and Falluja (7k). This project will
coordinate with the ongoing activities of the Housing HLP Sub-group partners and with the durable solutions
mechanism and its partners organizations under the auspices the Durable Solutions Task Force in alignment with
Inter-Agency Durable Shelter Operational and Strategic Framework (2021)
While partner agencies have produced significant numbers of housing units as part of the humanitarian response,
their involvement in addressing deep-seated institutional deficiencies crucial for sustained, long-term reform has
been limited. It is likely that as Iraq transitions from disaster response to comprehensive, enduring development
agenda, partner engagement in housing initiatives may recede. On the policy front, the majority of housing related
efforts have centred around research and publications, primarily carried out by entities such as the World Bank,
USAID, IOM, NRC and research institutes. This proposed project aims to take a direct approach through initiating
policy dialogue and building technical capacity of the government to foster a more mature and productive housing
market that effectively tackles housing challenges on a long-term horizon.

6.1 INCEPTION PHASE
The project will begin with an inception phase of six months, which will serve as a foundational period for the project,
where the project's activities, partnerships, resources are further refined, and management mechanisms are
established.
During the inception phase, the work plan will be revised, and therefore, output indicators and targets may be
modified. The results from the inception phase will also be used to adjust the logical framework, enhancing
effectiveness, and aligning with stakeholder needs. The operational budget will be developed and modified
accordingly. A separate M&E plan will be finalized in collaboration between all involved agencies and the European
Union.
Quantitative and qualitative analyses, and implementation of activities to be implemented will take place during the
inception phase, as specified in the Work Plan (Annex II). This will include a joint baseline study. Any additional
partner institutions relevant for activity implementation under the project will be further identified.
Priorities during this period will include establishing project management and governance mechanisms and building
a consensus with key stakeholders on work plan activities.

83
Accordingly, the main objectives of the inception phase are to:
- Build consensus among all relevant parties on project activities to finetune the work plan.
- Enhance the logical framework in line with identified stakeholders’ needs and project goals.
- Establish a robust project management and governance mechanism.

6.2 IMPLEMENTATION MODALITIES
Throughout the project's duration, a range of strategic approaches will be employed to effectively attain the
project's objectives. These approaches have been carefully selected based on the partner agency's expertise, insights
garnered from prior experiences with similar projects, and a deep understanding of operating within the Iraqi
context. Over the course of the project, various forms of expertise will be harnessed, including the contributions of
agency staff and the engagement of national and international experts through subcontracting for specialized
activities.
Additionally, the project will establish technical working groups, engage stakeholders through policy dialogues, and
conduct consultations involving public, private, and civil society advisors. Furthermore, the project will tap into the
knowledge and expertise of steering committee members and government counterparts to facilitate the
achievement of project objectives. A summary of these modalities is provided below (further elaborated in the
Results Chain section):
Expert Guidance: Engaging with individuals or organization with specialized expertise that pertains to the project
objectives, including, for example: affordable housing policy, finance or program design experts, workers or
employers representative groups and other CSOs, subject expert colleagues from headquarters offices. Expert
knowledge will be tapped into for insight, best practices, and to support in the development and weighing of possible
solutions to produce expected outcomes.
Capacity Building: Building the capacity of the GOI including government officials, local authorities and project staff
will include trainings and workshops on multiple topical subjects related to affordable housing policy, construction,
business development.
Policy Development: Technical assistance provided by UN-Habitat will support the GOI in the refinement housing
policies through updating the National Housing Policy and revisions of the legislative and regulatory framework. The
technical assistance will involve support to the GOI in analyzing existing policies, identifying gaps, and proposing
reforms to align with international best practices and the specific needs of low-income and vulnerable populations.
Policy Dialogue: The project will actively engage in policy dialogue by facilitating structured and inclusive discussions
among government officials, CSO’s, subject experts and other relevant stakeholders. These discussions will serve as
a platform for sharing expertise and insight, addressing collective challenges, and shaping housing and labour policies
and programs. Policy dialogue will promote consensus-building and the development of effective, evidence-based
policies that align with the project's collective objectives.
Technical Assistance & Knowledge Transfer: Partner organizations (staff and consultants) will provide hand-on
assistance and expertise to support knowledge building, skills development, and transfer. This approach aims to
foster building the technical competency of the various stakeholder groups, enabling them to eventually tackle
complex challenges autonomously.
Peer-to-Peer Exchange: a knowledge exchange network will be established as part of the capacity building output
which will facilitate continued dialogue among peer networks of housing professionals.

84
Problem-solving: The project partners will provide a pool of experts to support the GOI in trouble shooting issues,
proposing sustainable solutions, and supporting in execution of strategies - that are in alignment with this project’s
objectives and goals.
Awareness Raising: The project will include establishing two neighborhood Centres for Green Technology which will
organize workshops, seminars, and training sessions to disseminate information on sustainable housing practices
and raise environmental awareness at the neighborhood level.
Pilot Projects: The construction of 200 green social housing units will serve as a tangible demonstration that in Iraq,

6.4.1 UNITED NATIONS HUMAN SETTLEMENTS PROGRAMME (UN-HABITAT)
UN-Habitat is mandated in 1978 by the United Nations General Assembly to promote socially and environmentally
sustainable towns and cities with the goal of providing adequate shelter for all. It is a knowledgeable institution on
urban development processes and understands the aspirations of cities and their residents. For over forty years, UN-
Habitat has been working in human settlements throughout the world, focusing on building a brighter future for
villages, towns, and cities of all sizes. Because of these decades of extensive experience, from the highest levels of
policy to a range of specific technical issues, UN-Habitat has gained a unique and a universally acknowledged
expertise in all things urban.
UN-Habitat has developed a holistic and global approach towards urbanization that embraces much more than just
technical considerations. Beyond its traditional core areas — such as city planning, infrastructure development, and
participatory slum upgrading — UN-Habitat, today, also focuses on urban legislation and risk management, as well
as gender, youth and capacity building for all actors involved in the urbanization process. UN-Habitat works in over
90 countries to promote transformative change in cities and human settlements through knowledge, policy advice,
technical assistance, and collaborative action.
UN-Habitat boasts vast experience in delivering technical assistance and capacity building related to housing. The
organization has developed an comprehensive repository of housing resources and toolkits such as SHERPA and
more recently the Housing Value Assessment Methodology (VAM) tool. VAM is currently assisting governments
including Burkina Faso, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Senegal and Ghana in conducting rapid assessments of large housing
projects and national housing programmes. In total, 43 countries have formulated and implemented improved
housing policies based on technical guidance from UN-Habitat. Furthermore, UN-Habitat possesses broad
international experience in endeavours such as slum upgrading, housing construction and renovation. Recent
projects in the MENA region including Iraq, Palestine, Syria, Yemen and Lebanon highlight the organization’s
commitment to housing as a human right. Moreover, UN-Habitat engages in the Sustainable Buildings and
Construction Programme (SBC) which aims to promote resource efficiency, mitigation and adaptation efforts, and
the shift to sustainable consumption and production (SCP) patterns within the building and construction sector. This
is achieved through the enhancement of knowledge regarding sustainable construction, the development of
sustainable solutions, and global dissemination of this knowledge and these solutions.
Following are some instances of UN-Habitat’s support provided to other countries:
1. In “The Effective Implementation of Developmental Housing” UN-Habitat offered technical support to the
Kingdom of Saudi Arabia helping to build a robust policy and institutional framework for delivering 300k
social housing units to Saudi’s most vulnerable and low-income citizens.
2. In Lebanon, after the 2020 explosion, UN-Habitat has been actively involved in supporting the
reconstruction and rehabilitation of housing as well as the rebuilding of public spaces in the most vulnerable
areas impacted by the disaster.
3. In Sri Lanka, UN-Habitat's technical support has led to the preparation of the National Assessment of
Sustainable Building Construction and the Sustainable Housing and Construction Roadmap 2020 – 2050.
These initiatives provides guidance to policymakers, regulatory and enforcement authorities, researchers,
designers, contractors and builders to transitions the construction industry towards resource efficient and
sustainable practices, aligning with the nationally determined contributions (NDCs) to the UNFCCC as a
signatory to the Paris Agreement.
4. In Egypt, UN-Habitat supported the government to develop a comprehensive housing profile that served as
the foundation country’s National Housing Strategy, also supported by UN-Habitat. The strategy represents
a unified, integrated vision for the housing sector over a twenty-year horizon. It clarifies the responsibilities
of different sectors and policy frameworks while emphasizing the government’s role in regulation and
empowerment.

88
5. In Darfur, UN-Habitat has assisted internally displaced persons (IDPs) in developing sustainable construction
skills through a "Darfur Early Recovery, Stabilized Soils Blocks for Sustainable Growth" project. This program
utilized a "training of trainers" approach and reached over 1,800 individuals, providing them with training
and practical experience in constructing buildings using locally produced soil blocks. These efforts extended
to major cities, towns, and villages in Darfur.
UN-Habitat in Iraq
UN-Habitat has been active in Iraq since 1996 under the Oil for Food Programme. After 2003, UN-Habitat was largely
engaged in early recovery efforts, particularly those supporting internally displaced persons through the provision
of shelter and reconstruction solutions.
Early UN-Habitat activities in Iraq included the implementation of the Settlements Rehabilitation Programme setup
to assist IDPs and other vulnerable groups in Iraq and overseeing the Housing Sector Observation Programme in
Central and Southern Iraq and the implementation of the Neighbourhoods Rehabilitation Project in Baghdad. After
2003, UN-Habitat was largely engaged in early recovery efforts, supporting new waves of IDPs through the provision
of shelter and reconstruction initiatives, including advising on national urban planning and housing policy. In 2014,
the portfolio of UN-Habitat Iraq expanded to include both humanitarian and development programmes providing
IDPs, Syrian refugees and host communities with dignified shelter and an improved living environment.
Since 2015, UN-Habitat has supported recovery efforts in war-affected areas by building new core houses in-situ;
rehabilitating damaged houses, infrastructure, marketplaces, and water and sanitation facilities; upgrading basic
infrastructure; rehabilitating green public spaces; improving living conditions of IDPs and returnees; protecting HLP
rights and securing tenure rights for vulnerable communities; providing vocational training; and creating jobs for
IDPs and returnees.
In the past four years, the agency has refocused its attention towards community-based reconstruction,
rehabilitation of housing and basic services in urban settlements affected by the conflict, participatory design and
creation of public open spaces, construction of low-cost housing units to support the return of vulnerable IDPs to
their areas of origin, delivery of vocational training, and implementation of informal settlement upgrading projects,
while continuing to provide technical assistance to local and national authorities in urban policy-making and city
planning, urban heritage conservation, advocacy, data analysis, GIS mapping, climate change adaptation, and the
protection of Housing, Land, and Property (HLP) rights of minorities and vulnerable groups.
6.4.2 INTERNATIONAL LABOUR ORGANIZATION (ILO)
The mandate and vision of the International Labour Organization (ILO) is to promote decent work for all workers,
regardless of where they work. For millions of workers and employers, especially for young people in the informal
economy worldwide, decent work remains an elusive goal.
Iraq has been a member of the ILO since 1932 and has ratified 68 ILO conventions, including all eight fundamental
conventions. Since 2004, the ILO and Iraq’s government, workers’ organizations and employers’ organizations have
worked closely as part of the post-war reconstruction effort to bolster decent work and develop the labour market
across the different areas of the country. In 2019, the Decent Work Country Programme (DWCP) for 2019-2023 was
adopted by the ILO, Government, and social partners, representing a shared commitment to promote decent work
in Iraq. The DWCP outlines three guiding priorities, namely supporting private sector development and job creation,
strengthening social protection and addressing child labour, and strengthening labour governance and social
dialogue.
The ILO has over 100 years of experience providing technical assistance to Governments in designing, reforming and
implementing public employment programmes across the world, starting from the responses to the economic
depressions in the 1920s and 1930s all the way to interventions implemented to limit the socio-economic effects of

89
the COVID-19 pandemic and beyond (ILO, 2021)10. Over the course of that century, the ILO has expanded and
specialized its service offer, ensuring the technical assistance provided contributes to the development and
implementation of inclusive programmes that promote sustainable impacts, meet the most pressing challenges of
the time and context, and achieve decent opportunities for participants.
The ILO has provided direct technical assistance to governments to establish programmes across the world with
tailored and highly technical expertise. For example, in South Africa the ILO contributed to the Expanded Public
Works Programme through – among others - the development of technical and managerial capacities, and the
development and adoption of the Code of Good Practice for Employment and Conditions of Work in Special Public
Works Programmes which ensures that employment under the programme is decent. In India, the ILO contributed
to the development of methodologies for participatory planning and selection of employment intensive
environmental works under the Maharashtra Employment Guarantee Scheme and supported the development of
guidelines for State-level implementation of that programme’s successor, the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural
Employment Guarantee Act (MNREGA). This is the largest programme of its nature in the world, providing
employment to an average of 55 million workers each year on the basis of a legislated commitment to the right to
work. In Greece, the Kinofelis programme implements a wide variety of projects that take into consideration the
existing educational level and skills of the participants to best harness and build on participants’ strengths. Here, the
ILO supported in revising and developing implementation guidance notes; provided training and capacity building
interventions for executing institutions; designed systems and processes for programme implementation and quality
assurance; and designed a reporting and monitoring system, among others.
In addition to these specific experiences, the ILO has also developed a wide range of recommendations, toolkits and
guidance documents at the global level made available to all decision-makers and practitioners to support in the
design, implementation and monitoring of programmes.
While it is difficult to summarize the lessons from the numerous programmes supported over this period, below are
outlined some of the overarching lessons learned in supporting the design and implementation of effective and
sustainable programmes of relevance to the context of Iraq.
• Evidence-based programming: The ILO has elaborated a range of tools that can support decision-makers to
generate the necessary evidence not only to inform the effective design of programmes, but also to monitor
programme performance and impacts.
• Inclusive decision-making at all levels for inclusive and sustainable outcomes: The ILO has longstanding
experience streamlining inclusivity and participatory approaches in the programmes to which it provides
support, including in India, Liberia, and elsewhere. The ILO’s tripartite structure represents an important
foundation towards these efforts.
• Streamlining decent work principles: Decent work opportunities under PWP ensure these contribute to
sustainable outcomes and ensures they effectively reduce poverty and vulnerability. As in the case of South
Africa outlined above, the ILO has longstanding experience in advocating and providing technical inputs to
governments to improve the quality of the employment opportunities implemented under PWPs, including
in the integration of training opportunities that contribute to professional development.
• Capacity strengthening for sustainable outcomes: The ILO streamlines capacity strengthening activities in
the majority of its technical assistance to PWPs, to ensure the sustainability of the programmes and their
effective implementation. Here, the ILO utilizes a range of approaches, building on its vast range of toolkits
and guidance documents, it’s strong partnership with the ITC-ILO, and its longstanding international
engagement in this field which enables facilitation of peer-to-peer learning, including through study tours
and site demonstrations, for example.

6.4.3 INTERNATIONAL TRADE CENTRE (ITC)
Established in 1964, the International Trade Centre is the joint agency of the World Trade Organization (WTO) and
the United Nations (UN). ITC is the only international development agency fully dedicated to supporting micro, small
and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) to enable them to benefit from trade. Working with partners to strengthen
MSME competitiveness, ITC helps to build entrepreneurial and employment opportunities, particularly for women,
youth and people in vulnerable situations. ITC’s main clients are MSMEs, business support organizations (BSOs) and
governments in developing countries and economies in transition.
ITC’s mandate combines a focus on expanding trade opportunities for MSMEs with the aim of achieving sustainable
development. ITC’s value proposition pools a unique set of technical and operational capacities to respond to client
needs. ITC will build on its long-standing expertise in data collection and management to provide tools that support
informed and evidence-based business decisions, policymaking and advocacy.
Connecting MSMEs to value chains and helping them succeed in global trade is central to ITC’s mission. ITC addresses
the managerial, strategic and operational needs of MSMEs and helps create market linkages. ITC’s approach to
assessing and building firm-level capacities is harmonized, yet modular to address particular situations. In support
of increased competitiveness and resilience in value chains, ITC mobilizes policymakers, BSOs and the private sector
to build commercial alliances. At the enterprise level, ITC reinforces supply and production in view of market
opportunities, strengthening managerial practices and driving innovation. ITC supports MSMEs in their sourcing,
marketing and market linkage activities.
In response to rising demand for sustainable production and trade, ITC helps MSMEs understand and adhere to
social and environmental sustainability standards along value chains and in benefit from related market
opportunities, production upgrades and efficiencies. ITC also seek to influence how value is created and distributed,
helping MSMEs in developing countries capture higher value goods and services.
In the area of strategy development, ITC holds 20 years of experience, delivering over 100 strategies to more than
70 countries in more than 50 sectors. Strategies are designed to reduce trade barriers, identify growth opportunities,
and chart blueprints for action. An ITC-facilitated strategy sets priorities, allocates resources, and specifies how to
become more competitive. Based on decades of experience, ITC assists with implementing those strategies and
mobilizing international donor resources. Technical assistance is built into every step, to ensure that partner
countries gain the experience to create their own trade development strategies. ITC trade strategies place special
emphasis on opportunities for women, young people, low-skilled workers and remote communities.
In the area of trade and investment policy support, ITC provides tailored support to business, trade support
institutions and policy makers, such as advisory services, technical studies and analyses, public and private sector
capacity building and facilitation of public-private dialogues. Further, ITC has vast experience assisting developing
and least developed countries in their bid for WTO membership and post-accession implementation of
commitments. Specific initiatives were implemented in Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Sudan, and Iraq.
Additionally, ITC has been engaged in implementing the WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement in over 65 countries.
Specific sector-level experience includes for example ITC’s technical support under the Sri Lanka Trade-Related
Assistance Project, funded by the European Union, implemented in collaboration with the Government of Sri Lanka.
The project aims to strengthen institutional capacities to develop and coordinate the design and implementation of
coherent domestic regulatory reforms, trade policies and trade negotiations through public-private dialogues
(PPDs). Under this framework, ITC commissioned a regulatory assessment of services trade and investment (RASTI)
on the priority sector of Architectural and engineering services, and construction services. The regulatory
assessment embedded – inter alia - a mapping and analysis of relevant laws, including investment laws, identifying
trade restrictions within the legislation and relevant measures, followed by a governance review, alongside

91
consultation with sector stakeholders, assessment of the impact of regulations on market structure, prices and
access and consideration of regulatory alternatives.
ITC in Iraq
Since 2020, ITC has been a resident agency in Iraq. ITC is active with local staff and partners operational in Baghdad,
Erbil, Mosul and Basrah. In Iraq, ITC implements programs to support essential reforms and market-based solutions
for inclusive and sustainable economic development and job creation, focusing on the integration of MSMEs into
domestic and international value chains. ITC’s work in Iraq is aligned with and directly contributes to national
development priorities. The policy direction outlined in the recent Iraqi government program (November 2022), is
relevant to ITC, particularly under the following priorities “reforming the economic and financial sectors, especially
agriculture, industry, and banking sectors and supporting the private sector” and “addressing unemployment and
creating work opportunities for youth of both genders”.
ITC is implementing an innovative methodology to link Iraqi MSMEs with an unprecedented network of buyers,
gathering prominent business across the country. ITC provides tailored support to improve firms’ capacities, upgrade
their business models to seize remunerative market opportunities and establish long-term meaningful connections
with buyers.
In strategy design, ITC has successfully facilitated two sector-level strategies endorsed by the Government of Iraq
and under implementation. While in the area of trade policy, ITC provided technical and advisory support to the
Government of Iraq on WTO accession, leading to a revision of Iraq’s tariff structure in collaboration with customs
and the revision and submission of Iraq’s services offer to the WTO by the Ministry of Trade.
6.5 PROJECT GOVERNANCE
A Project Steering Committee (PSC) will be established with responsibility for guiding the project and for approving
annual work plans. Its members will be comprised of Government representatives concerned by the project (e.g.,
MoP, MoCHMPW, MoLSA, MoT) and co-chaired by the Ministry of Planning and the EU representative. Additional
PSC members will be identified during the inception phase and who might include private sector, CSOs, or academic
representatives. The PSC primary roles will include:
- Provides guidance in the overall direction of the project based on established goals and objectives.
- Ensures alignment of the project with other major initiatives in Iraq.
- Reviews and endorses annual workplans.
- Review the performance of the project against the work plans and the project logical framework, and make
recommendations for adjustments as relevant.
- Assess areas of actual and potential risk and provide advice on suitable mitigation measures and gather
lessons learned.
- Supports in project outreach and advocacy, information gathering and dissemination, and connecting
project staff to stakeholder groups and technical experts.
- Facilitate access to management decisions for the adoption of recommended reforms identified in various
aspects of the project.
- Facilitate the overall function of the project management team for effective implementation.
- Support in increasing the project’s visibility within and among government agencies, various stakeholder
groups and the public.
- Ensures that the Action maintains coherence with the national development, housing, labour and trade
priorities of Iraq.
The members of the PSC will meet at a minimum once a year and UN-Habitat will ensure the functioning of the
Secretariat of the PSC as well as provide a review of the achieved results of the past year and provide a forecast of
the planned activities for the following 12 months. A process for information sharing and collaboration for instance,
monitoring and information sharing meetings, will be devised. It will also gather lessons learned, identify possible
bottlenecks and risks and propose mitigation actions. Development partners, implementing programmes with which

92
synergies have been identified, will be granted observer status in order to maximise cross-fertilisation and
opportunities for collaboration. Additionally, technical working groups for various project components - comprised
of steering committee representatives and other technical experts- having a more specific and practical approach in
addressing the possible challenges and opportunities encountered by the project will convene as needed. Quarterly
updates/highlights will also be circulated among steering committee members and technical working groups.
6.6 PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND COORDINATION FRAMEWORK
Joint Project Management and Coordination
The Project Management Team plays a key role in ensuring the success of the project, by overseeing day to day
activities, managing, and tracking of budget and resources, handling administrative oversight including monitoring
and compliance and managing the relationship with partners in Iraq and with the EU. The Project Coordination Team
will be comprised of the Project Administrator, a Project Coordinator, and a Monitoring and Evaluation Officer, and
Advocacy and Outreach Officer. Internal coordination of the programme will be the responsibility of Project
Coordination team alongside focal points from each of the three agencies which comprise the Project Management
Team (see Figure 3). Together, they form the Joint Management and Coordination Team. The team will meet on a
quarterly basis to ensure overall coordination, exchange information and updates, and organize joint activities,
meetings, among other initiatives.
Project Administrator: UN-Habitat, under the supervision of the Head of Country will serve the role of project
administrator, responsible for coordination of all activities, submission of deliverables, and consolidation of
administrative tasks among the three partners and serve as the primary donor focal point.
Project Coordinator: a full-time dedicated Project Coordinator will be hired by UN-Habitat, with input from partner
agencies, to coordinate all project activities across agencies. The Project Coordinator will coordinate all project
activities with agency focal points and among the PSC. The project Coordinator will be responsible for project
submittals, ensuring all benchmarks and project deadlines are met, updates and communications to the PSC, donor
and other relevant stakeholder groups, and the smooth collaboration among the agencies. The project coordinator
will be responsible for completing detailed joint workplans, inception reports, scheduling and documenting joint
meetings, coordinating joint events and communications activities, and more. The project coordinator will also
support in the integration of activities among agencies through continuous communication and strategic planning
activities.
M&E Officer: staffed by ITC, with input from partner agencies will coordinate reporting activities across agencies,
and will be responsible for ensuring consistency, accuracy, and timeliness of all submissions. The M&E officer will
ensure that applicable information is collected, and reporting requirements are completed on time and up to
expectations.
Advocacy and Outreach Officer: staffed by ILO with input from partner agencies the Advocacy and Outreach officer
will be responsible for developing and deploying the joint programme Communications and Visibility Plan to be
developed during the Inception Phase. The role of an Advocacy and Outreach Officer involves developing and
implementing strategic advocacy communication products to promote the project’s objectives, while also engaging
with external stakeholders, including governments, civil society organizations, and the media, to raise awareness of
the initiatives and mobilize support. This role plays a critical part in advancing the project’s objectives by effectively
communicating its messages, policies, and programs to a diverse audience and fostering collaboration with key
partners.
Agency focal points: each agency will designate a staff member to serve on the Project Coordination and
Management team. Each focal point is responsible for representing their respective agency as the primary point of
contact responsible for coordinating activities among agency staff and relaying information back to the joint project
staff members as requested. The focal point will also represent the agency at various coordination meetings

93
including Steering Committee meetings, EU coordination sessions, Project Management Team meetings, and others
as deemed necessary.
A summary of the role of the Joint Project Management Team includes:
• Project oversight and assuring all activities are executed according to the defined workplan and activities.
• Monitoring progress and ensuring that all project activities are on track, submitted on time and meet quality
standards.
• Accountable for project’s outcomes and enforcement of project standards and adherence to compliance
requirements.
• Ensure the overall project coordination of activities across all agencies, identifying synergies and avoiding
duplication of efforts.
• Facilitate communication, information sharing and collaboration among the three agencies to ensure a
cohesive approach.
• Provide updates, discusses challenges and shares lessons learned.
• Plan and execute joint activities.
• Contribute to implementing the Communications and Visibility Plan.
• Assist the evaluation of the programme.
